content:
ry 24, 2016
												Since I've been at it for a while, and I'm waiting for servers to come back up, I think it's time for a bit of a review. Pros:-Beautiful if your system can run it, but the ability to downgrade graphics settings enough to run on a fairly low end machine makes the game possible for more people. -Great controller support if that happens to be your thing.-Everything feels fluid. Classes are given very large kits and balance spamable abilites with complex rotations and cooldowns. Things are smiple enough to let casual players compete most content but exceptional players exceed and tackle the highest level raiding conent when it's released.-Large amounts of midcore content while still providing hardcore and casual content.-The learning curve while long is actually fairly short compared to most mainstream MMO I've played, and you are able to gain an understanding of things faster due to the ability to level/hotswap out different classes as you please. -Reasonbly diverse class list genrally offers a lot of different and unique playstyles.-The dev team is small, but very dedicated and seem to listen to fan feedback reasonably well and puts out major content updates every few months with smaller minor patches to hold everybody over.-A lot of stuff to do, and plenty of replayability.-Final Fantasy tier sound track is naturally beautiful.-You can have all classes on one character. Hotswapable, including crafting and gathering classes.-Fishing-Catgirls-The game is absolutely full of references to different things and amusing humor. Sometimes it's subtle, sometimes it's not. Either way they know what they are doing tears at your soul and they aren't sorry. I like to think of the Square Enix FFXIV dev team as Dr. Evil from the Austin Powers movies.-It comes with an actually good story, this is extremely rare these days in MMOs but it will destroy your heart.-Full cutscene/story replay feature for all those people who skip everything and want to figure out the story later.-It also comes with absurd amounts of side content that only exist to amuse you. -Everything is put together so nicely. One of it's best features overall is that it doesn't do anything badly. -Catgirls-Lots of in game events, probably about once a month or so there is some kind of seasonal event. During some seasonal events including Halloween, Christmas, Easter, Valentines Day, and many more they actually update massive portions of the game thematically. These may also give everything for aestetic gear to mounts.-Magnificently done atmosphere and fight design.-Lots of unique content in terms of fight/boss design. Some fights may have overlapping mechanics that were used in other fights but nearly all of the content feels completely different.-It is still very early in the game's life cycle. If it's anything like it's mother MMO, Final Fantasy XI, then we are close to a quarter done with thousands of hours of content already in the game.  -Y'shtolaCons:-The game is an MMO and can be grind heavy. -Some gear is gated behind time gates (ie only a few pieces of gear a week) and while this cap always gets removed after a while, it adds an unneeded wait for gear.-The difficulty spike can get a bit high at times when you are new to the game and running content for the first time without watching a proper guide.-Old content is reused a lot and that's ok to many because much of it is heavily replayable, but the way gear syncing (Limiting stats on gear that has outpaced older content) is done makes some old content far too easy due to stats not being synced low enough and making non-current content faceroll easy. -While the devs are actively trying to fix things, sometimes the ends don't justify the means with gear. The best example of this would be the relic weapon questline where you grind for gear comparable or better to the best raiding gear at the time, but the steps are meant to be a masochistic grind so it kinda fills it's own purpose.-On the North American servers excluding Gilgamesh and Balmung (Which are both often locked from character creation due to high population) have rampant amounts of RMT offers sent through private chat and not enough is done to combat it.-Crafting can often feel trivial in terms of actual combat gear, but as of 3.2, this issue seems to have been eliminated for the most part.-Much of the seasonal event gear is free if you attended the event, but is put in the cash shop after a long period of time downing the exclusivity of having experienced the event. This is more of a personal gripe.-There is a cash shop purely for visual items (Almost only special sets that were free at one time and a few other special items)-Dps que can occationally become unreasonable -The selling system/overflow storage system works off retainers, basically servants that you can customize. You are given two by default which is enough for many players, but they offer more (Up to six) for a small monthly fee. Very upsetting considering the game is purchased plus pay to play although extra retainers aren't that neccessary for most.-You will re-run old content a lot. While this keeps que times shorter for people trying to level alternate classes, it can be old after a while, but you are given many options for how you level. -Still no dedicated damage parsing feature implemented by the devs, but many parsing utilites do exist (Banned but ok normally as long as you don't talk about them in big public chats). This is only essential for end game raiding for the most part. -The game is still young (First expansion was less than a year ago) and the devs are still working on their proper flow, so occationally they will do some experimenting and ♥♥♥♥ stuff up, although they do normally fix things.A bit of a summary: This game really is great. Overall, having played many other MMOs, I think I've never found another that put everything you could want in a fantasy MMO together so fluidly. It's not that it's unique. If you are looking for some super never before seen gameplay then go be a loli with a giant axe in Tera or go warp into a gatecamp in Eve Online. This game's actual "Uniqueness" literally comes from how well everything is put together, not because it tried to change the key formula. Visually it is stunning. The music goes above and beyond what anybody could ever expect of an MMO and keeps on going. The atmosphere in fights is absolute insanity. I still get shivers when I think about how amazing some of the 8 man raids were. While some of the older content had been defamed due to the added "Unsynced" feature and the lack of proper gear syncing, much of it is extremely enjoyable to go back and play due to the nature of the game. Do not go into this game thinking you are going to be amazing fast. The lack of proper level syncing makes some of the early content too easy and it's unfortunate when new players get haymakered in the jaw because they weren't sufficiently prepared. This is being addressed by the dev team slowly, but it is still a problem that exists. If you can afford the monthly bill and want to ruin your life, then this game is absolutely worth getting. Overall rating: 11/10 I have a catgirl fetish now

content:
20, 2014
												A breath of fresh air in the MMO scene, or rather, a reminder of what it was that made MMOs popular in the first place.What makes FFXIV:ARR so good, is not what it does have, but rather what it doesn't.Gimmicks.Ever since World of Warcraft became such a large player in the MMORPG scene, competitors have risen which attempt to dethrone it with new and "exciting" mechanics, but in doing so forget what an MMO even is.FFXIV:ARR learns from the mistakes of others and sticks to the known strengths of the genre. The holy trinity of Tank/DPS/Healer, Strong and challenging end-game content, deep storyline and world lore, an abundance of content to sink your time into along with major content patches every 2 and a half months.It should be noted, that major content patches in FFXIV:ARR usually contain the same amount of content an expansion for WoW would contain at launch.Yes, the game has a subscription model, but given the spetacular failures of numerous F2P and Cash Shop MMOs that have popped up over the years, combined with how this money is funneled into frequent and high quality updates to the game, is this really a bad thing? Honestly, it's well worth the money.However FFXIV:ARR doesn't just stick to old core values, it does so while breating new life into them that don't undermine their integrity. The holy trinity of MMOs is refered to as holy for a reason, to mess with it is to dance with certain doom. FFXIV:ARR conquers this perplexing problem regarding the need for re-interpretation without becoming gimmicky by altering the way experience works in the game.In traditional MMOs, you make a character, you select your class and you start getting experience points. As you gain experience, your character levels up thus expanding your capabilities with your selected class, until you hit max level then you move to end-game content.XIV:ARR does away with character experience, instead replacing it with class experience. You have an active class, determined by the weapon you are wielding and any experience gained will go into the experience pool for your active class. You don't level your charcter, you level your class. For example, I'm currently a level 50 conjurer, specialising in the advanced healing class "White Mage" and I am also at the same time a level 18 Thauterage, the predecessor to the DPS class "Black Mage".This doesn't make me some weird DPS/Healer hybrid, I can only be one at any one time. If I have a WHM weapon equipped, I'm a WHM and I have access to all the abilities of a WHM of my level and can equip gear for my class. I do not however have access to abilities for classes I have also leveled (except certain cross-class abilities which are sort of how this game does talents) nor can I equip gear meant for a Black mage while I have my white mage active. At the same time, when I switch to my black mage, it is as if I am a fresh character still leveling and only at level 18, the fact I have a class at max level does not affect my game play at all.This is great since it allows for alts without having to give up your character, your identity, your friends, your guild etc, you have it all in one place, without ever undermining the holy trinity.FFXIV:ARR shows that it's possible to approach MMORPGs with a "Don't fix what isn't broken" philosophy without simply remaking yet another WoW.On a final note? I pre-ordered the imperial edition for The Elder Scrolls Online, that set me back $75 USD, I did that before I started playing this and you know what? I've decided to just swallow that purchase and play this instead.It's THAT good.Saying all that however, the game is certainly not without it's faults.FFXIV:ARR is a remake of the 2010 game FFXIV, which frankly? Was absolutely terrible.The original game suffered from poor UI, poor world design, a dull and slow (Even by MMO standards) storyline and terrible optimisation leading to significant technical issues.There is only so much you can do with this and this shows when we look at the current game world.The current world is made up mainly of what was the original open game world which has had the massive bloat cut from it, the areas worth keeping turned into zones which are seperated by zone transitions.These aren't instanced, which is good, but still it does break immersion a bit.Thankfully, this isn't likely to be an endearing issue as developers have acknowledged the size of the world which though acceptable, could use a bit more to it and have said that we will be seeing significant increases to the world's size in major expansions (the first of which is expected in the second or third quarter of 2014).There are also some key class types which are noticably absent from the game, for example the stealthy ambusher, (thief, rogue, ninja etc), however once again the developers have acknowledged this issue and said plans are in place to bring in new classes in future patches and expansions.Typically, I would count this as a major negative when forming my opinion on a game but I have been very impressed with how reliable Square-Enix are for following through on promises and fixing or introducing things where needed.So I'm willing to take their "We are aware of this and we have plans in motion to meet these requests" in good faith, something I am VERY hesitant to extend to many if not most game developers these days.Overall?FFXIV:ARR is the equivilent of a miracle in gaming. Not only rescuing a title otherwise doomed to ridicule, but improving it to such an extent that it deserves a place in the genre's historybooks on account of it's merits.It has it's issues sure, but nothing that comes close to being considered a major con against it's abundance of pros.I highly recommend buying this game, or at the very least, putting it onto a watch list and keeping a very close eye on it over the next few months to see just how well it is cared for for yourself.I'll give this an 8/10 :VTL;DR - This be some seriously good ♥♥♥♥, but it has some things that need attention. Buy it or keep an eye on it!

content:
ber 17, 2015
												I will recommend this game to anyone. My hours are increasing by the days that I play.This game will steal your life and never make you want to go outside. Lol. Just kidding.Pros:NO GENDERBIND. I love this, I can be all the classes without having to make a new character, I don't have to be a certain race to play all the classes. I do everything on one character and it's amazing like that.Crafting is awesome, Most crafting mmos are pretty straight foward. You get the materials, Boom done. That's not it works in FFXIV, In this game, You use your skills, get the materials and use your skills to make the material you're going for. It's like a little mini game to keep you interested. It's a very fun thing to do in game.Community: Omg, where do I start? All the mmos I have played. I immediately go solo, and do everything on my own unless I'm forced to party. This community is WONDERFUL. They're nice, and not rude at all. I've only experienced one rude person in my hours. The guilds are wonderful and want to help new players level up. I was afraid to join a guild but when I did. It was lovely. I was welcomed and offered help when I got stuck. Dungeons, you can't do them alone so having an amazing community is a good thing.Story: The story is literally the only reason why I got this game in the first place, but knowing what I know now. It's a great game all together. The story is engaging, interesting and definately is worth the sub. and with Heavensward. There's even more story now. So it's really worth it to enage fully in the story.End game: Past level 50, or past level 60. This is where this game jumps to the top of my list as Best MMos.Simply because. There's simply NEVER nothing to do. There's so many things to do, to keep you busy. Right when you hit 50. The game opens up even more, You can travel to new places. Fight harder dungeons and earn tombstones for amazing glamours.Music/Scenery The soundtrack is amazing. I find myself listening to it most days when I'm on and taking in the beautiful graphics. When it rains. You can see your avatar wet, when it's windy. Your hair blows. It's very cool to me at least.Races: Also, The races are awesome. You pick one race, then there's two more. Like Miqote. You can be a seeker or the sun or a keeper of the moon. Lots of things to pick from in characther creation. Amazing selections. Lots of hairstyles. Wide Variety of eyes, highlights for hairs and voices etc. It's very nice to have so much selection. ^_^Cons: I only have a one con.Grinding can get repeative, you will have to multiple dungeons, and fight along the same monsters etc etc. That can get boring. But some dungeons are tricky so it's better if you know what you're doing.This game is great. It's worth the sub and worth the extra money to get heavensward. I will continue to play it and tell people to jump into the wonderful world of Eorzea. :D

content:
er 23, 2016
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is Square Enix's way of showing that they care about our experience and is the reason why I love the Final Fantasy series.There is no reason why you shouldn't try this MMO. There is a 14 day free demo (with some chat and levelling restrictions but still enjoyable), and if you like what you play, then you can get the game along with 30 more days of free (non-sub) game time! That's a whooping 44 subscription free days! Now let's get into the pros and the cons.Pros: - Fantastic soundtrack (as expected from a final fantasy game) composed by Nobuo Uematsu.- Polite and helpful player base. (Don't know what to do? Ask a bypassing player and they'll usually answer and provide even more help than you would initially expect.)- Role Playing is an option and you can create custom macros!- Enjoyable story to share with your friends- You can play and level all classes with just ONE character!- Frequent patches - Not pay to win- A plethora of side and main content- Controller support (you can also change button layouts from Xbox to Playstation)- CROSS PLATFORM!- New player friendly (story mode is basically a tutorial that teaches you new things slowly as you progress)- Seasonal events such as Halloween and Christmas- The pleasure of making new friends and joining a guild for the first time.Cons:- Small instanced zones (though it shouldn't be a problem after the Stormblood expansion comes out with the end of PS3 support)- There are a lot of kill and collect quests that may become repetitive (but to be expected of in MMOs)- The story almost seems nonexistent somewhere in the mid-game- Non-story quest dialogue is somewhat uninteresting to read most of the time.I am enjoying A Realm Reborn as a fan of the Final Fantasy series and have barely scratched the surface (yet) and there's not much else to say, go try this game out for yourself.

content:
r 13, 2014
												Honestly, I never review games. All I do is READ them, but this game really caught my eye and I truly believe it deserves one. Final Fantasy XIV has to be one of the most fun MMORPG's on the market to date. You jump right into the story and feel like you're listening to someone read a really well written book. It draws you in and makes you want to hear more and more with every passing hour. First off I would like to point out that Final Fantasy XIV has one of the most beautiful soundtracks I have ever heard in my entire gaming life. It fits really well with every location you reach, and the battle music is one that will bring back memories for all the Final Fantasy Vets who play .Second, I would like to say that the graphics quality is out of this would for any MMO to date that I know of. it may only be DX9 but they gave thee game a full graphics overhaul. Playing on the lowest settings gives you STANDARD DEF CONSOLE graphics, but when you crank up the settings, BAM! you look close and every bit of clothing has texture, every shadow is perfectly cast, and the over all exicution is remarkable.Finally I would like to say that after over 200 hours of in game time, I have made many friends. The community is wonderful. I remember when I was about a level 14 White Mage, I was taking on a level 17 monster and I was low on health. Another Healer out of the blue healed me and a Black Mage helped me defete the enemy and gave me about 5000gil to buy better gear. Everyone playing this game seems to help one another as best they can whenever needed and that is probably the best part of it all. Personal Rating for this game would be a 9/10 just because sometimes when you stop playing for about a week or two and come back to it, you may get confused on where to go and it leaves you to figure it all out. but other than that little disadvantage, I have to say that this is an all around perfect game. And the edition of multi class gaming on one character makes it stand out from all MMOS I have played.

number of helpful: 32 of 33 people (97%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
17, 2016
												I have put a lot of time into this game since it came out in 2013 and I think a lot of that has to do with the community of the players. I haven't played a ton of MMO's before, but of my limited experience Final Fantasy XIV has the best community yet. People are usually very helpful and, depending on your server of choice, there is almost always a place for you no matter what kind of player you are.The game itself is almost a love letter to long-time Final Fantasy fans in some ways. There are so many references and homages to other Final Fantasy games that the most hardcore fans can really appreciate it. Personally I learned a lot about some of the games I either hadn't played or not played a lot. New content is constantly in development and each patch regularly brings enough content to keep me busy until the next one. Not only the frequency but the quality of these patches has been pretty astounding. Each patch usually brings along with it a whole new set of references as well.Graphically the game is quite beautiful. There are plenty of cracks if you look close enough, but the characters and scenery are very well-done. In the pre-Heavensward areas you would be hard-pressed to find details in almost any zone that seem lazy or unintentional. There are many small, hidden spots with their own little stories to tell through short NPC dialog boxes.The story is easily one of the strongest points of the game. As you level up and journey through Eorzea you can really feel your character being tested and tried to become the Hero of Light. Everywhere NPC's will recognize your strength, whether it be as a seasoned Adventurer who has killed literal gods or as a world-renowned artisan that can craft the finest items in the realm. They really make your accomplishments feel just like that.The combat is probably the least notable thing the game has, but the large range of classes and the fact that you can master every one on a single character is very welcome. So far the Heavensward expansion has increased the enjoyability of all classes, really expanding them to be much deeper than complex than before. My personal favorite, black mage, has especially seen some much-needed love in making it less of a bore to play.This is a lot more than I intended to write, but I can't help myself when it comes to FFXIV. I really love everything about it.

content:
6, 2016
 My thoughts on Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn Pros+ Excellent Storyline and storytelling, definitely feels like a final fantasy game.+ Ability to change classes at anytime (Except in dungeons or raids) without creating an alt.+ Beautiful soundtrack composed by Nobuo Uematsu.+ Fun and challenging endgame content that feels rewarding upon completion.+ Game is constantly updated with fresh content periodically.+ (Mostly) Friendly community.+ Great looking game.+ Combat :D (Only past level 30, otherwise it does feels kinda lame.)+ Clean UI interface that is editableNeutral= In-depth crafting system, although I never really got into it myself.= Game isn't PvP focused. This doesn't bother me but it may bother some people.= Subscription fee of $15 USD/month.= No Oceanic servers for Australian players (You have a choice of 250ms or playing with people who speak a different language).Cons- Some Low resolution textures which are quite visible. Although this is slightly forgiven because of cross-platform support.- Players who are not interested in story will find it harder to get interested in the game- Levelling is rather quick, but still feels grindy. Even with the Armoury bonus for receiving your first 50 class.- No skill trees for class customisation.- Character customisation is mediocre. - Not an open world mmo, there is a large amount of loading screens when going between areas.- Ruins your social life. My friends no longer talk to me but that's ok because I now exist a short, pink-haired lizard girl. Conclusion Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is probably the most fun I've had in an mmo for a long time, having tried games such as TERA, WoW, BnS, Vindictus and more. Most of the cons listed I would not consider to be major, and the pros heavily outweigh them. I would recommend trying out the demo beforehand as this mmo may not be for everyone, especially those who do not enjoy PvE content as much. Overall: 9.5/10

number of helpful: 30 of 34 people (88%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
6
												Best MMO on the market right now in my opinion. There's a lot of main story quest which everything is gated behing, however IF you have the patience to get through it and not get caught up in the typical MMO mindset of "must get to endgame as soon as possible" then you'll find a story which (while having many filler quests) is as good as every other Final Fantasy game.Coming from other MMOs the combat does certainly feel slow at first (and it is) but I advanced, got more skills that were off the global cooldown, and faced bosses with more demanding mechanics, I found that the slower pace definitely didn't hinder the game at all.A really good feature that I think many people miss out on is how Square Enix treat previous content too. This is probably the biggest problem in a game like WoW. As soon as a new patch,or expansion releases, previous raids and dungeons become almost completely irrelevant. In FFXIV there's systems in place which makes it so that even at end game, all previous dungeons and bosses still provide relevant rewards for the majority of the playerbase, so while you will be repeating the same content often, there's such a large pool of content TO repeat that it stays more interesting for longer than say a raid in WoW does, where you may be sick of it after you have it on farm and have to just repeat it every week, while progressing through the same raid, with the same bosses and the same mechanics, but on a harder difficulty.It should be added that the zones, music and story in general definitely make for one of, if not THE, most immersive experiences I've had in any MMO in about a decade or so.Criticisms about the volume of story quests shouldn't be ignored (especially the unnecesarry fetch quests etc, I wont defend them), but I think people who say it's an objectively bad thing are missing the point that it's meant to be a story that you progress through like in a singleplayer game. And it definitely feels more rewarding getting through the story to access the endgame as opposed to just doing random meaningless quests and dungeons like in other MMOs.Pretty much this game is great, and for people who want a 'traditional' Pay-to-Play MMO that has an insane amount of polish, and a development team who obviously care deeply for the game, I don't think there's anything that comes even close that's currently available.I think FFXIV has pretty convincingly cemented a spot as one of the best MMOs of the last decade, if not of all time.

r 29, 2016
												This game is absolutely amazing!! I am not a huge fan of MMORPGs, but this one definately won me over. -For one thing, the story and lore is pretty deep and engaging. For me, that is a big thing in any game. It is the one thing that I am finding stands out from other MMOs. I have played multiple ones growing up and even recently (Elder scrolls, neverwinter, WoW, City of Heroes, Everquest, Lineage, etc), and I keep coming back to this one. -Second off, the game is just visually stunning. There have been times where I have just logged on and sat my character down somewhere in the forests surrounding Gridania while I talked to people in my Free Company (guild). -I love the fact that while I can play with people, I never feel like I am forced to interact with people except for the mandatory story dungeons. Even then, I feel you don't get left behind in these dungeons as much as you do in other games. -The community is very nice. I played games where you would go and do a dungeon and just get left behind. I don't have the same problem with this game. Yes, there are a few a-holes here and there, but for the most part people are willing to help you out. Don't know the mechs? Ask and usually someone will explain it to you. I have had random people just come up and raise me and heal me when I was out leveling. People I had just met and had just joined the same FC and me would give me high level gear just because they made it and they saw I didn't have it. Also, they are pretty easy going and funny. Can't count the number of times I have come across a random dance party or mount war in game. Makes for some very times. -You can do pretty much whatever you want with your character. Sick of being an archer and want to try out healing? Go do it! All you need to do is go to the guild to start your quest and get your weapon. After that, all you have to do is switch your weapon and armor to whatever you want to be. You don't loose anything from doing this either. If you are a level 15 archor, you stay a level 15 archer until you decide to level it up again. You just equip your bow and the armor for it and you are ready to go. -Even at end game it doesn't feel like I have to search for something to do. There is still plenty to do even after you finish main quest. There are tons of side quests that have interesting stories and even tie in with main plot. You can get some pretty cool things from doing them as well. There is also an amusment park, housing you can save up to buy (yes, you can own your own house), pony farming, and beast quests, and just so much more. -You can get married in game. It is actually a really interesting feature. I married someone in my FC and we go matching rings that allowed us to teleport to the other person's side. We also got a mount and the people we invited to our wedding got minions. There are 3 different wedding options to choose from. There is a free option (you get the matching rings and I believe a wedding dress/suit). The 2nd option (the one I chose) includes what I have just told you, plus an emote, and you can customize the wedding. The 3rd one I believe you can choose different outfits and a bit more customization. Over all, it is a very cool feature that I absolutely loved using and loved going to them (someone bought me a bridesmaid dress to wear to their wedding). The cons-There is a monthly subscriptions fee. It is cheaper to do the month by month if you only plan on making one character on a server. However, if you plan to do standard, buying more at once is cheaper. (good to note though that they do give you stuff the longer you play the game)-People who like to immediately do things with friends will find the game a little slow until they hit level 20 main story quest. You get your first dungeon when you get to the level 15 main story quest, and you don't get your first mount until you hit level 20 in main story quest. I believe level 15 story quest is also when you finally get to travel outside of your home region. -It is more expensive to buy through steam than it is from their website from what I understand. Keep in mind that the one on steam comes with 1 month free subscription. I do not know if the same applys to the one on their website. Best to do your own research. Overall, it is fun and entertaining game that I would recommend to beginner and upward players.

content:
er 8, 2016
												This game is a true gem. It's horrendous start seems to keep this game under appreciated in most mainstream circles and I honestly didn't know about it until a certain youtuber started talking about/would never shut up about his bird squad and next thing I knew I was knee deep in this game and am loving every minute of it.PROS:-1Char=Any class. 1 Character can aquire and play as every class, no need to make one character for each class and this allows a player to "hotswap" classes as opposed to logging out, changing chars, logging back in-Recruit a friend. While this is only noticed if you dragged a buddy into your addiction, this feature is great because it truly rewards you for getting other players and the rewards greatly help the sherpas out there (2 person chocobos bro)-Environment. I haven't reached 50 and touched Heavenward yet but just the starting areas are truly beautiful. I run the game on max and there are SO many little details they put in to this game that make it feel more open world RPG than MMO. Whether it be the realtime weather (w/ physics (ftw)), The godrays and dynamic shadows, the very subtle character physics (it took me getting a 4k monitor to even notice the boob physics, needless to say, I was disapointed with myself), The amazing foliage (it's not Witcher 3 levels but its pretty close to modded skyrim), the cities/towns and NPCs in them... I could go on but you get my point-Armors and weapons. I'm much more of an armor guy myself (whats the point of doing it if you dont look good doing it), but both the weapons and armor are really stunning. they base stuff is typical medieval platemail and leather but then you get into some scifi sh!t, I saw a bow that, when drawn, deploys a shield because why not. Some weapons are just light, so whatever your kink, they got you covered-mounts. if you want a plain ol' horse you came to the wrong game, but, if you wanted a giant 2 story tall mecha chocobo or a flying eyeball with wings, then boy your in for a treat. (side note: each mount (for the most part) has their own music and thats just a really nice subtle addition that they didn't need to add)CONS:-Mounts (or lack there of). You have to get a permit to ride a mount, but you have to join a grand company to get the permit, but you have to be alteast 25-30 to join a Grand company... I hope you like cardio. I had 5 mounts by the time I could actually ride one, to be fair, most of them were from events, game time "veteran" rewards, and recruit a friend rewards but still... I WANNA RIDE THE CHOCOBO-1st Person. This game has a 1st person option, and that's cool, but its obvious they intended for people to play in 3rd. There is nothing when in 1st, you don't have a body, theres no head bob, you dont see your weapon or the visual effects/cues from your attacks. Overall just disapointing, especially with the rise of VR and my desire for a SAO-esq future-Spam bots. I know every game has them and that there are MMOs out there that are WAY worse but it is hard to read pub chats when totally obvious "get tons of mooney for free" ads pop up in the chat box. but thats honestly just a minor preference issueWell I hope this "totally" not biased review helps some of you that are on the fence about this game. I know subscritions are a turn off but the quality I've gotten was more than worth it, assuming you're going to play the game more than not at all.

												I've been playing this game since its closed beta phase 2, which is about one and a half year ago now. I can recommend this to anyone who's ready to pay the monthly subscription fee. In terms of entertainment<->money spent ratio, this game wins over many, many others in my library. To get more into detail:- very casual design, although it offers challenging endgame content as well- many alternatives in terms of what to do, you're not bound to farm dungeons if you'd rather craft or gather items or do something else entirely- wonderful music underlining the game and its scenes- nice graphics, even on weaker machines- crossplatform play (PS3/PS4/PC)- frequent new content- many story-driven dialogs and cutscenes, entertaining for those who are interested- easy-to-understand classes and gameplay but challenging to master- pay-to-play but therefore not pay-to-win- incredibly nice gamepad controls, beats keyboard and mouse even, trust me- devoted developers, yes they actually listen to the community   - regular Q&A livestreams + new content showcasing called "Letters from the Producer Live"Please note that I own the steam version since its 1 year anniversary (that means I've been playing it for over a year before that already, so feel free to add many hundreds of hours of gameplay to my current value)

content:
27, 2016
												Ibuki will start by saying she has been playing this gem since closed beta phase 2. Actual hours are close to 3,000 in game.If you are new to this please disregard Balmung unless you want to be hit on by big black Rogs 24/7 while waiting for a queue to pop. Also Gilgamesh is for the elitists so Ibuki advises against this as well as it creates a bad experience for new players to get told how ♥♥♥♥ they are 24/7. Now that that's out of the way, enjoy your opening scene filled with you stuck in the back of a cart/ship on your way to one of Eorzea's city states, which you pick based on your starting class. Along the way, you are introduced to a bunch of nobodies who become sombodies and then nobodies again when all is said and done. If you feel attached to a particular character, get ready to hate them as soon as the voice acting starts (even japanese dub is bad). Luckily this was rectified somewhat in the HW expansion as beginning with the first quest all NPCs save for a few have new VAs' that are actually british instead of the Sam Riegel and Liam O Brian being hammered into your ear for 3/4ths of the story.When starting out at lvl 1 you will only have 1 skill to use in combat, as you level you'll get more and more skills and eventually your class will become very complex to manage, such as the case of Lancer to Dragoons. Once you get a feel for your class (around ilvl 200) and you've wiped to titans landslides or other easily avoidable AOEs and shouted "Lag" in the party chat at least 15 times, you will start to get the hang of prioritizing mechanics over moves. Being able to simultaneously DPS/Heal while a guy shouts THE EDGE IS CALLING TONIGHT and you're getting punched off the edge is truly an experience to behold. If you are less combat focused and just want to fiddle the market with outdated gear so people have an excuse to use gil on something, then look no further then crafting. But unfortunately if you want to make any money off crafting you have to become an Omnicrafter which means getting every crafting class to 50 or 60 (if you like putting razer blades to your neck). The true end game for a crafter is crafting the newest glamour gear and selling them for millions of gil only to realize you have nothing worthwhile to buy and you go back to selling and making more of these things until a new patch comes out that does the same thing. With HW being an Omnicrafter is no longer necessary for the lvl 60 renditions however the new skills that were added in HW for crafters are just dumbed down versions of the other skills, which is bad. Gathering is also another avenue but theres no point in telling you about sitting for 2 hours trying to catch a fish with a green color instead of none.Ibuki recommends this for the constant stream of content and the communication between the devs and the players despite being in different continents across the globe. This has problems atm but at least its not sitting there for almost 2 years with no new content added until the next expansion. As time has shown anything can be fixed in this game as long as Yoshi dedicates development towards it, which he is. My only complaints from 1.0 to ARR are the belts getting removed from the visual model of the character, Mi'qote asses being flattened out and lightning tiered for the sake of development costs, and the fact that when you turn around you instantly snap to ot the animation whereas 1.0 you actually turned around and moved realistically, also the cutscenes were far superior in 1.0.  However everything else was Brendan Fraisered. Oink!

number of helpful: 23 of 29 people (79%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
12, 2016
												I did a video review for this this year:


YouTube™ Video: Should You Pick Up FFXIV? A Review Made In 2016! 

			Views: 49,115		

			my answer would be yes, but look at the points and judge for yourself :) timestamps: 0:34 - 1:23 character customization 1:23 - 2:14 early gameplay 2:14 - 3:40 early game group play 3:40 - 5:14 open...		

let me sum up:+ Atmosphere: absolutely AMAZING. Music is top notch, visuals do pull you in. - Character creator: lacking. It's better than WoW's "choose your head", but it's choosing from 4 presets for majority of your features. - early gameplay: rather boring. The game is very friendly if its your first MMO as it will be rather hand holding, however you accumulate your skills slowly and up until level 30 nothing amazing happens in the main story. I think I got pulled in by the atmosphere, gathering and crafting system and the players around me, but the early gameplay hours did not leave me the best impression, which I think will be the reason most people will turn away. On the upside there's incentives for high level players to queue for low level dungeons (leveling roulette) so you will not have a problem progressing while leveling. + the story: best story I've ever seen in an MMO. You're the focus of the story, but that means that you get to develop a relationship with NPCs and really care for them. As I'm writing this, patch 3.3 was released which wrapped up the Dragon War storyline. I really enjoyed it! This is pretty much the only game where I wait for patches for the story. That being said you absolutely have to do your story to enter the expansion content and to keep up with the end game, so if you're not a story person you might not like this game. + late game: loving the end game. Extreme primals and Savage raids are my favorite thing to do and they're sufficiently challenging. If you're a casual gamer every second patch is a catch up patch, meaning that your item level will never be that far from a raider (casual gamers can hit 240, raiders 241 currently). Tomestones for 230 gear are capped weekly and upgrade materials for 240 gear are also capped weekly, meaning to keep up with the rest of the population you'll need a relatively little time investment weekly. + random knick knacks that developers keep on putting in: talking about The Gold Saucer (an in game casino like place where you gamble a fake currency that is no way tied to your gold (gil) or real life money), Palace of The Dead (a never ending dungeon that currently has 50 floors, that you can enter with friends of any level and gain experience if you're not level 60, end game tomestones if you are level 60 (currency for gear) and you can get an iLvl 235 weapon for any class that you want from there (otherwise known as the wellfare weapon as it's perfect for end game right now and only takes 8 hours of dungeon to get, so if you and your friends did an hour of it a day, you'll get it in a bit over a week)), aquapolis (a dungeon that spawns from treasure maps. Never used to do treasure maps before, now it's an entertaining thing to do) and the likes. I absolutely love this part of the game and engage in it often. + crafting and gathering: as a crafter or a gatherer you'll get as much skills as a fighting class. Your end game could be just crafting and it will feel very rewarding. I love to gather more than I like to craft, but it was one of the things that pulled me into this game, because it didn't feel like a side activity. other things worth mentioning:+ you can have all the classes on one character. Due to how the gearing up process works, you won't be able to have all the classes geared, but fortunately many classes do share gear sets. All tanks share the same gear (except for weapon) so if you have a tank, you might as well have all 3 for varriety in tackling content, if you have a healer, you might as well have all 3. I have 5 out of 13 battle classes at level 60 (DPS casters and healers) and I'm happy with it. I did not feel the need to roll another character. PvP exists. It's not very popular, but it is there. I know that at least some of my guildies engage in it, despite the 10 to 30 minute queues that they encounter. Overall at least check out the free trial. It's the best MMO on the market for me, hands down.

content:
y 30
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn has a spot in my gaming heart. I ventured into Eorzea during its first appearance as patch 1.0. I won't deny how awful the game felt during that time. It felt barren and I truly had no idea what was happening. Square decided to take the game down and guarenteed a promising return - they did so with patch 2.0. The game came back completely revamped with nothing but positive improvements. I returned at the start of patch 2.0 and played for a good six months before I broke off to play..., -sigh- World of Warcraft again. I enjoyed the new changes, the classes had their own unique abilities and the main story kept you interested. I returned once again in 2016 and once more when I purchased the game for my Steam account. This time around I was more unhappy with where my journey in Eorzea ended.Pros:- Engaging story to follow and just the right amount of side quests to keep you busy in other zones and other classes to level.- Easy learning curve - very new player friendly with the active help.- Always something to do and plenty of classes/jobs to level up.- One character is all you need to play everything in this game.- The party finder is one of the best I've utilized in every MMO I've played.- You get your moneys worth when it comes to the amount of content released per game.- Being a part of a Free Company (Guild) actually provides useful benefits with buffs/housing.- Plenty of jobs to level and crafting jobs to keep you going if you ever need to change up from your primary build.- Fantastic UI customization built in. You can move practically everything, disable what you don't want to see and even change the size. No need for UI addons for this game!- Some of the best music you can hear in an MMO. I never get tired of hearing Shiva's theme.Cons:- Patch downloading - I want to really hit this hard on a personal level, because before patch 3.0 there was never an issue getting the game patched up and running. I know people have said their say on the discussion section on how you can get past this, but I should never have to alter my network settings or download a VPN to get a game patched up.- Because I used a VPN to get the patch I continue to receive the error i2501 when I try to input any payment to activate a subscription or even buy items from the Mog Station. I've submitted multiple tickets and had three replies now stating my issue has been submitted to someone higher in the customer service chain. To this day I still cannot activate a subscription.- During dungeons cutscenes occur, and there are times when you just want to get going in a dungeon you will have some new players wanting to view the scenes. I don't hold the new players accountable for wanting to watch these scenes, I just wish they didn't happen before and during the group play. I know in Heavensward they minimized the amount of scenes.- Because of the amount of jobs you can level up, running old content over countless times becomes tedious and extremely repetitive, I'd suggest not trying to level everything up at once to avoid this. I did it my second time through and I got everything to level 30 and became burnt out.- Battles do feel slower in regards to the global cooldown of a default 2.5 seconds. Early in the game it will make fights feel longer than they need to be.- Inventory space needs to be larger. This is a con for now, but it was said when Stormblood arrives we will see an increase for our inventory.- Converting items into materia. I really dislike the approach to this mechanic, because you need to have a spiritbound with the item before you can even think about turning it into a useful piece of materia. Creating a bond with a piece of equipment just feels weird and pointless. If I happen to obtain a piece of gear I don't need, I'd rather just convert it instantly.- The approach to sell your items on the market is tedious. You use two retainer NPCs (or more if you bought more with real money) who will hold up to 12 (I believe it is 12) items in the market for you to sell. I think a general auction house such as something on WoW would suffice. Why make something that just lists your items a pain?There are more pros and cons floating in my mind, but that is just bringing it down to detailed knitpicks. I loved this game a lot, it was just unfortunate how it has ended for me. I wanted to keep playing, but their entire account setup is completely frustrating and more work than it needs to be. However, I will continue to recommend this game as it continues to grow and change. Red Mage job is coming and who wouldn't be excited about that?

content:
r 20, 2014
												A spectacular redemption of the original Final Fantasy XIV, A Realm Reborn turned one of the worst MMOs of all time into one of the very best. FFXIV: ARR combines elements from RIFT, WoW, Guild Wars 2, and a whole host of MMOs to create a fabulous gestalt of MMO mechanics, one that offers more and more the further you go. While TOR is still my favorite MMO due to it's excellent storytelling, FFXIV is definitely my favorite MMO in terms of it's mechanics, though the story here is pretty good too. Set a few years after a fiery apocalypse destroyed the land of Eorzea, the world is just about getting back up on it's feet after the cataclysm. However, the warlike and expansive Garlean Empire has other plans, seeking to subdue the violent and destructive Primals that make their home in Eorzea: by any means necessary. While suffering from a lack of voice acting and an exceptionally slow start, the mysteries and questions of the FFXIV story are compelling enough that you want to see how it all turns out. Overall, while it doesn't have too many ideas of it's own, FFXIV's polish and quality are more than enough to compensate. Looking for the pinnacle of the hotkey based MMO? Look no further.

number of helpful: 96 of 162 people (59%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
20, 2015
												At the time of writing this, I will have put 1300 some odd hours of my life in this video game. Mostly consisting of the trap that ensnares a majority of the people in this game: jumping around your FC house aimlessly until something happens. (Oh wait, there's a revival in old content from 3.0 and before! Give me your poetics bonus, lets go clear Alexander Normal, I need to get my relic. Better get on the train while it lasts! Need a Coil carry/clear, hit up that party finder and tell em bout your bonus!)It plays too safe, too limited and too strict, reducing player agency and planning to "Look up a guide and do it like that". It's not the thinking man's MMO, it's not the even the non-thinking man's MMO, it's the painfully generic experience with no risk/reward scenarios that retirees from World of Warcraft and the people that are new to an MMO love.Player interaction is at best non-existent to barely there, and this is including FC chat and any linkshells you might be in at the time. There's no reward for helping people, no sense of gratification, it's a nameless charity "spin the wheel" of dead content you don't want to do, but you do it for the tomes.(Less so the tomes now, with the new relic. It's spamming A1-4N runs like a hamster in a wheel to get a 10 item level increase for people who don't raid. Maybe i210 will encourage people to raid, or maybe it'll encourage them to reflect upon their misdeeds and hours of grinding. Thank you SE.)You'd think, oh 1300 hours is a long time, you must've gotten your money's worth at this point, right?The answer: No.PvP queues (which I signed up for to cap my weekly tomes than rather deal with the brain dead community post-launch) can take upwards of an hour, and games can last an hour as well. Chalk up 100 matches or so and a big chunk of my time was just waiting. Waiting is something you do in this game, quite frequently. Queues in general, if you were late to the party can be a rather thrilling alt-tab experience, in which you can enjoy the lovely scenery and music alongside shout chats filled with "INV PLS" or "check the party finder" (When hunts were semi-relevant again in 3.0 release, but now that's just dead. It's either memes or B rank daily hunt call outs, pick your poison.)So I took up mining, and botany, and fishing. Crafting, leveling an alt class, and so on and so on, till I was sick of both that and the waiting I did between.Most of the time you play because of an obligation, whatever it maybe, and always hovers very close to peer pressure and addiction at times. Would I recommend this to people who never played an MMO in their life? Yes.Is it an MMO for those that loved XI or really any kind of MMO with social aspects to it's community? No. (Or want satisfying midcore content)Don't play this game with friends unless you don't want to be their friend for very much longer. (Or want to progression raid)EDIT: Look it's patch 3.1 soon to be 3.2. I was never much a fan of new content being trickled out at ridiculously slow pace. Truly this new raid tier will save XIV! Time will only tell if 4.0 will actually be good.

content:
y 29
												I started on PS3 and switched to PC when things got complicated. When it comes to MMOs, I've played Lord of the Rings Online (a LOT of it), WoW, DC Universe Online, Warhammer Online, Guild Wars 1 and 2, Runescape (yep, mid thousands were fun), The Old Republic, and Rift. I'm probably leaving out some trials or free MMOs that I've forgotten about. This is hands down the best.  The content is great (there's only a handful of coop content that aren't great), the devs absolutely love and care about the players (jumping in-game to say thank you to the players, with verification that they ARE the dev team; amazing), the music is great, it has great pacing, fun even when playing solo (I JUST began running around with a regular group of players and I've been playing since 2013), the storyline makes you feel like your involvement is actually purposeful, there's side content that's there just to be really fun/funny (you know things are gonna be great whenever Godbert shows up), you aren't EVER constrained to one thing (I feel like tanking today; you know what? I want to fling spells today), and there's enough references, inspiration, and reverence for Final Fantasy lore to make any long time fan swoon.I whole heartedly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 15
												REGISTERING:I think the only bad thing I have to say about this game so far is REGISTERING. I remember it was the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ experience with FFXI too.If you buy the full game outright you should be okay, it just takes a bit to login to the site and add the code etc.But if you are trying to upgrade from a trial and using steam keyes it can be a pain in the ♥♥♥. For example last night my son downloads the trial and registers an account. He tries logging in and it tells him this account cant be used on a trial on the same day. Wtf right? lol.After some fiddling around I just had him run a copy of my FFXIV folder that i copied to his desktop and it seemed to work with THAT installation. No idea.I also have another issue with another install where it was also registered as a trial. Bought the game and the keys registered fine. However that install does not show a button on the website to add Game Time. Simply no button for it anywhere. Still no reply from SE.GAME EXPERIENCE:Other than that the freakin game is pretty damn fun, and it runs great even on less powerful computers. The only thing NEW players may feel annoyed with at first since it is quite different than most MMOs, is the Class\Job system, and getting use to the map. Also the game is relatively just a slower paced game over all. But I actually like the story and the animations and detail in the characters.CLASS SYSTEM: Let me explain regarding the class\job system (which may be changed in the future according to some speculative sources). Basically you can choose a class in the beginning, which you can take to cap if you want. However most people like to specialize and get a "Job" which is basically a specialized version of your class. However to unlock those you need to meet certain requirements. In most cases it involves having the parent class at lvl 30, and a cross-class Class (yeah i know) at level 15 because your specialized Job will use skills from both classes. Don't ask me I didn't design this ♥♥♥♥ haha. The way they did the Job and Sub job system in XI was far more easier and superior IMO.Anyway you have to essentially level 2 classes to acquire the specialized Job you want. What makes it more of a pain in the ♥♥♥ is the fact that if you want to level say Ninja as your main. You need to first level Pugilist (to level 10 however realistically you will probably need to level it to about 15-17 so you can even travel to Limsa Limosa where the Rogue guilde is located), then travel to Limso Limosa and unlock Rogue. Then there you must level it to 30. Finally when you are done with that, you will need to go unlock Ninja.However here is a cool thing about the way classes work. You can do them all on one toon. You can simply switch between them whenever you want (with a small Global Cooldown timer on skills) and don't need to worry about logging in and out of multiple toons. Really the only time you want to make a new character is if you want a new race or gender. Other than that, you should really try to focus on one toon to get the most out of the game's class switching system.GENERAL GAMEPLAY:The gameplay may take getting use to especially if you are use to mostly F2P games. It is less "actiony" and IMO more chill paced. I personally like it though. It does have a global cool down of 2.5 which can be reduced if I recal to about 2. Really the core of the battle system isn't so much action and quick reflexes, but more planning and coordinating. Some jobs require a bit more quick thinking than others, but over all I think the combat system is pretty solid albiet different from most.The music is great, and honestly I dont expect anything less from a FF game in regards to music.The animations are really well done too, every character and class has their own animations and they feel pretty unique to their race.The map may be challenging to get use to. It isn't the most easy map to use, but it also isn't difficult. If you arre use to games bread crumbing every single thing with blinking lights showing you EXACTLY where to go etc, you will have a hard time adjusting on the first day. You will notice this especially if you are the type of person that goes on autopilot grinding quests. There's a lot of quests you should probably try to read lmao as they tell you to do something specific and when you get to the destination you realize theres no NPC there waiting to accept your item or whatever. But once you get use to it you will wonder why it was so hard to begin with. You will get use to it trust me. Took me a good day to finally get use to what the icons meant and how navigating it worked.The keybind and macro system is very powerful. If you can get acquainted with the macro system, you will save a lot of clicks and can make some pretty awesome scripts to do things for you in game.INTERFACE:The interface is very customizable. Plenty of options to get it how you want.GRAPHICS:Are very well done. Less bright and colorful than you may be use to from games like Tera, Blade and Soul etc. But I would simply describe it as a bit more realistically colored, not an over exaggerated use of HDR\Bloom. The detail in all the things in the world is also quite awesome. The interesting thing is, as good as the game looks, if you have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ computer, it still looks good even on the lowest settings.Attention to detail really shows (as in FFXI) when you can see even the jewelry you are wearing as your gear. When you get to level 15 you will unlock quests for you class that gives you a complete set of gear that looks really good for lowbie armor.CONTROLS:Controls are pretty straight forward and standard. However I do like the fact (if you want to) that you can play just about 100% with just keyboard. Everything is pretty accessible with just the keys. Camera, menus, targetting. This is quite rare IMO and unless you played XI, you wouldn't know. I use to play that game with 100% keyboard. However the thing that changed with this game is that some classes require positions for specific skills to be optimal. So you have to move a bit more and a bit quicker, and fully using keyboard may limit this for (monks, ninjas, rogues). Because of this I started using the mouse to control the camera now as it is easier to move in and out of locations during battle.CAMERA:Camera angles are done quite well and aren't simplified like some games. You can zoom out quite well and zoom in. You can also tilt the angle of the camera up or down lef or right which can be useful even just for screenshots. Since this is a standard skill based game, and not targetting, you won't run into bad angles really during combat either.ROLEPLAY:Also the game lends itself to a lot of possibilities for RP if you are into that. Everything from a ton of emotes, facial expressions, sitting on furiture, day and night experience, weather, housing and interactive emotes with other players. I am not much of an RPer anymore but I did recognize the value and thought I'd bring it up.COMMUNITY:I have seen some people have had bad or rather less than favorable experiences in the community, but personally it's been a good change from previous MMOs. Not that they are no trolls or annoying people, every community has that. But there just feels like there is quite a bit less.As a newbie people have helped quite a bit, or have just been friendly and talkative. I really don't have any complaints on the newbie experience with the commnity. I am on cactaur.OVERALL:I think the game deserves a shot if you are looking for something different than the F2Ps that are out there. Honestly I was playing F2P for years and enjoyed the fact they were free (despite still spending plenty of money on their micro transcations) but I felt they were getting boring because they were all starting to feel the same. This game to me feels more like an RPG should feel like.

content:
, 2015
												So, I've been around the MMO block more than a few times. World of Warcraft, Star Wars The Old Republic, The Secret World, Age of Conan, both D&D online games, Champions Online, D.C. Universe Online, Rift, and so on... but this one is definitely one of the better ones I've played.Lemme put it this way. I've been a WoW player for the better part of eight years now. I recently picked up this game about midway through the WoW 6.1 content and started playing it right before Heavensward came out, then kept on going with my Miqo'te.So how much have I gotten into this game this time around? When WoW came out with 6.2 -I didn't care-. New raid, new zone, new loot, new mounts, etc. I don't give a crap, I'm too busy going through Dravinia.Pros:- A very strong and engaging story with good characters.- The ability to make one character, but swap between character classes post-creation. This is also used to get the upgraded versions of classes (i.e. Lv30 Thaumaturge + Lv15 Archer = Black Mage).- An in depth crafting system that is very addictive to work with.- The ability to have a chocobo partner who acts as both mount and fighting companion.- 22 Individual character classes/jobs based on the classic Final Fantasy job system.- 11 crafting and gathering classes for making equipment, potions, etc.- Five unique playable races with highly customizeable appearances and two main variants for each race. Six if you get the Heavensward expansion.Cons:- Game will require you to grind via dungeons/levequests around the 40-50 stretch to continue the story (you will constantly run into the 'your level is not high enough to continue' issue).- You can't sell things in the Market/Auction House until around level 20, so making money early on is difficult.- You can only send mail to people on your friend's list, so you can't send mail between alts.

content:
4, 2016
												Game has a special place in my dusty old heart, started when somone dear to me left the country and I felt very lonely. It's definitley an MMO with classes, roles, crafting, etc. You're able to switch classes on the fly after completing the initial lvl. 1 quest. That was cool! It means I don't need an armada of characters to try each job. The story is pretty straightforward, very Final Fantasy, dealing with crystals and summons(primals) and that whole deal. It's not terrible and/or not there at all, so I was pretty happy! There is, of course, MMO grind and there will be frustrated or rude players. That pretty much comes with the territory. But the amount of rude/upsetting players is shadowed by all the friends and helpful players I've met.In MMOs I hate the feeling of slug paced levelling ("At last...in three months I finally hit level 30" -Me). I've never maxed any levels before in like...any MMO (ever), but in this game I've managed to max out 3 combat and 2 crafting classes...50-60 is rough but not unenjoyable (This is very much MY opinion not everyone finds grinding cathartic or fun etc.). The pacing of levels is fast but not LIGHTSPEED FULL THROTTLE LEVEL 50 IN 10 HOURS fast thanks to story quests, levequests, sidequests, and dungeons/trials.In the end, you get a free 30 days to try the game if you've never touched it. Which is a good chunk of time to test stuff out. Even if you don't like it in the end, you tried it at least! But I do hope you finish your first dungeon or face your first primal and feel the adventure and the teamwork and the general excitement. It's lame but maybe it'll be there.

number of helpful: 77 of 134 people (57%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
ber 10, 2015
												I liked FF14: ARR up until the expansion. I've played a lot of MMOS (I think at least 30 now) and there are certain things I look for, and really enjoy an MMO having. It doesn't have to, but it gets a big plus in my book if it does. One having interesting and complicated enough mechanics that when you actually finish a boss for the first time, or a dungeon run, it feels like an achievement; that you had to work for it, but it was worth it. The second is having the ability to have different playstyles; the ability to tune your characters closer to how you want to play. The third is an engaging, interesting, and above all USEFUL crafting system.FF14 had 2 of the three; there's no skill trees at all, and not really any way to modify your gear; there's BiS and that's about it. You can do vanity gear over it though, so at least you can look different then every other player the same level as you. Still, the mechanics were awesome, I loved the music and a lot of the themes of the dungeon, and actually LOOKED FORWARD to gathering and crafting, because people LIKED getting HQ gear and useful items later.The world was engaging to look around. The story was... well... decent for an FF game (I don't care for FF games in general myself, I played this because I liked it as an MMO). There was always plenty to do, plenty to collect, plenty to save for, etc.That changed with the expansion. First off, the new maps are a horrid PAIN to get around. They made them HUGE with the intent that "It'll look cool when you fly around" and obviously did not give a damn about people who had to hoof it, trying to unlock flying.Oh yeah, you have to hit random nodes and do random quests on the map (including main quest and side quest stuff) to be able to fly. PER NEW MAP. So by the time you unlock flying, you're probably going to be done with wanting to be ON the map.The mechanics are pretty much mostly just ripped from other previous dungeons. One of the first new ones, Sohm Al, we recognized very easily as a 'weenie T6'. And to me, the music was just really boring...As for the crafting part...Apparently Yoshi P (one of the main developers, if not THE main one) has basically stated he hates the fact that crafters figured out how to make things better then dungeon drops. Oh, sorry that the ENTIRE WEEK one might put into making the HQ accesory and the MILLIONS of gil that you might dump into boosting it up to make it SLIGHTLY better bothers you SO MUCH that you basically made ALL crafting completely worthless.Okay, there's pretty much three reasons to craft in games: To make items a cheaper way then just buying them, to make items you actually want to use, and to make unique items you can't get anywhere else.Since quests just THROW high quality gear at players now, and there's NO POSSIBLE way to get the same TIER as dungeon drops, the only item adventurers would really use is food, and there's not really a market for seliing (level 55 gil for 500 gil on the marketboard!). And the only 'unique' items that are remotely worth making are vanity gear, housing items, and stuff for your mounts. Which makes the HUNDREDS of hours both in gathering and crafting completely not worth it, since almost all the housing items aren't that expensive.There's a lot of other things to mention, but basically I felt they ruined the two main reasons I was playing this in the first place. They MIGHT fix it, but I've already been soured on the idea.

content:
25, 2016
Top notch MMOFreedom to choose Europa, Americas, or Japan serversGraphically brilliant, uses around 80-90% of my 780ti at 2560x1080 (21:9), maximum settings (+custom post processing) and uses it well.Mouse/Keyboard or Console gamepad both available for use, each with their own specialized interface (Very customizable too).Great character creation, 5+1 Races, with two cultural diversities each.8+1 combat classes, 9+4 advanced specializations called jobs. ALL are available to each character.8 crafting classes, 3 gathering. Again ALL available to each character.Heck, be a full time fisherman if you want. Writing which is rich in story, world establishment and humour of all ranges.Gameplay and story start off easy and at a smooth pace, but eventually amounts to huge depth and progression.Seasonal moods are refreshing and explored in full, all year round.No pitiful pay-to-win or limit breaking cash shops. Simply a costume/dye, mount and mini pet store for the most narcissistic among us.AMAZING COMMUNITY (I play with Japanese players, so I can't speak for the rest)The only thing that might let the game down is that voice acting is reserved for critical moments only, but more is being added quite regularly.I recommend all interested in RPGs, Social functions, and MMOs in general to give it a try, even people new to Final Fantasy will feel welcome. Be warned- You may just get sucked in for the long trip, but I certainly enjoyed the ride.
