content:
ber 27, 2014
												Decided to update my review, just because I love this game so much + my last one didn't do it justice. Going to break the main points down, so it's easier to read.GAMEPLAY: Like most MMOs, you have the holy trinity of dps, healer and tanks. In this game they are divided into classes, which can further specialise into jobs. Cross class skills are used, so lets say I'm a White Mage at level 60, I can use cross class to access some skills from other classes/jobs I've leveled. Classes/Jobs are also handled differently. Your character can switch between any of the classes/jobs as they get unlocked, allowing you to completely change your playstyle should you choose to in the future. There's even classes like Fishing, Blacksmithing or Alchemist if you want to work the markets, or help your Free Company build an airship! Gameplay is like most MMOS, except it can get quite challenging as you get to a higher level. IMO this game has some of the hardest content from any MMO out there. There's the typical "Run around and quest" style gameplay, you can do a main story, there's lots of little "sub stories", trials, dungeons, fates in which many people randomly team up to complete a mini objective etc. Gameplay wise the game definately isn't lacking. The actual combat is quite good, players aren't just taught to stand still and smash buttons. There's lots of movement during fights, as you move away from aoes, deal with specific mechanics to handle bosses and move to specific locations to help team memebers. Apart from the obvious leveling gameplay, there's a lot of other things to go and enjoy. There's sightseeing logs, hunting logs, Gold Saucer events + a lot more. STORY: What surprised me the most about this game is just how good the story is. Not just from an MMO perspective, but from a Final Fanasy one. Generally, it's put together really well. Ofcourse there are a few tedious bits, but for the most part it's extremely enjoyable. The story helps guide you to places you should level, introduces you to more of the world and characters in it. Another thing to note is how well some of the characters are built up throughout the story, you really get to know + like them. Again, content wise you're definately not short, especially with Heavensward just released. There's easily more than 50 hours of story content available at the moment, and the best thing is that it's constantly being added to through content updates. The story is split into mini chapter type things, some with overlaping issues, so certain issues don't overstay their welcome and it doesn't get stale. VISUALS + OST: This is a Final Fantasy game. Even people that haven't played Final Fantasy know that a lot of effort is usually put into these 2 areas, and it applies here. Visually, the game is extremely impressive, especially now with DX11 support. The zones and enemies are extremely diverse, filled with a true sense of imagination and thought put into them. The music complements each area well, with a great range of types used. Lots of different types of musical styles are used for certain situations, from J-POP, smooth jazz and heavy metal. Even if some music tracks don't fit your fancy, theres bound to be plenty more that will.ENDGAME:Decided to give this it's own section aswell, as most people are interested in this. There's a ton todo at end game. There's tons of dungeons, raids and extreme primal encounters you can fight for gear, mounts or glory. Some of these get extremely challenging, to the point that you'd need to form training parties to help train yourself + your team to beat an encounter. There's also a pvp arena, which I confess I haven't used, dailies through beat tribe quests or doing any of the logs I've mentioned above. OVERALL QUALITY: IMO The overall quality is just great. There's so much todo content wise, it's just unreal. With so many possible playstyles and things todo it's hard to not reccomened this to any MMO or Final Fantasy fan. I'd honestly reccommend it just for the story alone. This review really doesn't do it justice, so if you've read this and it's interested you I'd really reccomend watching some videos of it on youtube(Just don't spoil the story for yourself!) and checking out the free trial. Just be warned, this game is an absolute timesink that will steal your life.

content:
er 3, 2014
												Where to begin?First off I am a huge Final Fantasy fan, I own and have played through every FF game to date. My alias is Mog and I typically go by Moogle Assasin7. That being said, this is my SECOND favorite FF title to date. Don't get me wrong though, I do have some gripes about this game which is why it's only my second fav.What you need to know about this game is that you have to buy it and it has a subscription (BOTH are required to play). I didn't realize this until my free trial ran out. Very dissapointed that they left that tidbit out of the discription. However, I still play because its awesome.Next is the game itself. Very repetitive... you tend to do a lot of the same stuff over and over. The trick is to mix up your game play and switch up your focus. There is a massive amount of story and there is always something to do. Voice acting is great. Plus the devs are constantly adding new content, which helps keep you engaged. Community is great, I have yet to have a problem with a single person. It's easy to drop in and out. This is nothing like FFXI, you CAN actually progress through the story line and you'll do it almost completely solo.I use a midgrade laptop that runs on windows 8.1 and it handles fine. (usually around 11fps) I know that isn't alot but this game doesn't require much. Biggest drain on fps is the hunts.Bottom line 9/10 for massive amout of content, easy to learn, hard to master, great story but repetitive. Totally worth the 15 bucks a month. Highly recommend.

content:
22, 2014
												As far as MMORPGs go, FFXIV is not at the same level as it's main competitors. Yet. The world is still lacking in scope, the endgame needs more variation, and lots of features like player housing hasn't been implemented yet.But I still give it my wholehearted recommendation. The graphics are great, the content that IS there is really fun, the production values are as good as any MMORPG I've ever played, and I can't stop playing it. If you're the type of player who rushes through content, you may find yourself hitting a wall at some point, but if you dial it back to somewhere between "hardcore" and "casual", this game is a true gem. Heck, even if you DO breeze through it all, it is a game that grows with every patch, every content update, and every (eventual) expansion pack.The monthly fee might seem discouraging, but not since Final Fantasy XI (also an MMORPG) have I ever got so much playtime and content for my money. If you love Final Fantasy and MMORPGs, you owe it to yourself to at least give it a try.

ry 16
												I have always been a fan of MMOs, from my early days of Star Wars Galaxies, City of Heroes/Villans, to Free to Play MMOs like Blade & Soul and Tera. For the longest time of my life i have been a stickler of pay to play MMOs in the current gaming age and I will tell you, as a guy who has played MMOs since he was about 12, THIS GAME IS WORTH THE SUBSCRIPTION! It has an engrossing story, worthy of a single player FF game, beautiful music, grand landscapes and plenty of things to do both solo and with friends and party members. Rarely will you meet anyone who can be considered a jackass until end game (which is currently level 60 with Heavensward) and the next expansion Stormblood is dropping in June. The combat can feel a little slow right now but SE says they are revamping it with Stormblood so we'll have to wait and see what it becomes. But, if you are looking to scratch that classic MMO itch, this game has 200+ hours worth of gameplay IN THE BASE GAME ALONE! NOT COUNTING HEAVENSWARD!!! If you are an MMO fan like I am, do yourself justice and give this game at least a try. There is a reason people hold this game in the same regard as WoW, it is the best MMORPG to release after WoW did, and that's saying something

content:
3, 2014
												The MMO genre has seen several failed attempts in recent years, and only a few have managed to really shine. Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn manages to rise to the ranks of great MMOs like WoW Burning Crusade. Where do I start? Character customization is filled with hundreds of potential combinations. You could easily spend a good hour or so mixing and matching to find a character that suits your taste. You even get to give your character both a first and last name. You have your standard three main roles and classes that fit into them, but the brilliant part is that you can become all of them on a single character. Never more will you have to juggle resources and time between characters just to fill multiple roles, as you can simply switch whenever the need arises. Combat uses the standard auto-attack and skill system, but has plenty of actions that require you to pay attention and move around. Several enemies use AoE attacks and your character can gain damage bonuses depending on his attacking position. The graphics are stunning for MMO standards and add to the beautiful realm of Eorzea. The story is very strong within the game, but it doesn't fall victim to the problem of Tortanic where it was too single player focused. There is plenty to do between main quests, side quests, FATES, dungeons, and primal raids. And the crafting system even manages to be exciting through the unique crafting process. Trust me, I've gotten hyped about being able to make a boiled egg when it almost failed. While the subscription fee can be discouraging, this game provides quality that more than justifies it.

content:
22, 2014
												The graphics on this game are amazing. It also scales well across old and new technology.I am a die-hard WoW fan, and will probably always play it on-and-off until it ends, but this game might be the first major MMO to catch my attention. It all just works. The first few levels are a bit disorientating, but after level 5 it starts to make sense. The community is also young (as the game is new) but very polite and helpful.There's a decent variety of classes to start off with, and those who hate alts will love that they can switch classes just by changing weapons after a certain point in the game. (Level 15?) WIth some hybrid classes only being available after you level two individual classes to 30/15 respectively. There's almost a guarentee of many many more classes coming over from the previous FFXI title. Ideally it would flesh out every primary class with two specialization choices-- like how Arcanist must choose between Summoner or Scholar. Classes famous from XI include: Samurai, Black Knight, Corsair, Theif, Red Mage, and Blue Mage.So far quests are varied and interesting, the enviroments are vibrant, and the world feels alive. I have not experienced any lag client or server side. If you like classic Final Fantasy, you'll love this game. It's a very solid title and worth a shot.

28, 2014
												I picked this up to give it a shot, having heard that the newer version was far improved over the original 1.0 release, and man am I happy I did. The game is gorgeous, entertaining, and does a fantastic job of pulling you into the narrative, and making you care about the npc characters. The ability to level all the classes on one character is a blessing and a curse, but overall I like the way it feels.Biggest downsides for me are the lack of chat bubbles, and the need to grind xp to finish the main story/cap your character once you surpass level 35. There's also a fair bit of gold spamming, and having to type out a ticket to report it every time is very tedious, especially compared to WoW's one button report spam feature.Overall, very happy with my purchase, and the ability to pay for subscription via the steam wallet. It's well worth $30 to give this a try and see if it's right for you!

7, 2014
												Yes. It is finally here. Final Fantasy 14, the next part in the ever-so-popular series isfinally out for the gamers of the world to enjoy. As for me, i was a bit sceptical about it at first, as i don't really like MMO's. But as a huge fan of FF games, decided to give it a shot. And believe me, i was not wrong. I was hooked right at the moment i entered the main menu: The guys from Square Enix managed to make even the menu look beautiful and soothing, accompanied with all-too-known musical theme. The graphics are amazing, even on the lower settings, and the landscapes are gorgeous and well-planned. The game itself has many clever designs, such as different view on crafting, dynamic battles, party and dungeon finders, daily quests, the all-new multi-class system.... Etc. Etc. And the game always manages to give you something new, more different things to keep you from getting bored. If you still have your doubts about giving your money monthly to play the game, then i will say you that: If you want a solid MMO experience with plenty of traditional FF goodness and recognisible characters - then think no further, just go and pay for it. You won't be dissappointed.

content:
, 2015
												I am not one usually to leave a review as I find other people have already spoken my opinions but I have been infuriated by the amount of crap I went through to try and play this game. Initial set up was easy - bought through steam, get game code. FFXIV makes you set up an account with Square Enix which is fairly normal for an online game. It takes the usual information like email address, screen name then your name and birthdate. Then your address, and a personal security question. Captcha's on every screen by the way, hard ones too. I do my usual thing of putting in crap because you don't need my damn address or birthdate. Then after that I log in, filling another captcha in as I go.This was around 2 years ago, I play the game and use up the free month before moving on and not playing again. However, recently I decided to start playing again as my friends have picked it up. Forgotten password, so go through that system of password recovery but it doesn't work. I recieve no email with reset details. So I try again, figuring I spelled something wrong. Nope, nothing. More captcha's each time too. Now, they do say it can take some time for the email to come through, and after "considerable" time waiting, to try again. 4 days later the email comes through but has an expiry time on it. If you don't click on the contained link within an hour of recieving it, it no longer works and you have to try again. And so I try again, this time it comes through 6 hours later when I am at work, I was lucky enough to be on a break and click the link. But it won't just reset my password, oh no. It wants my bloody birthdate, security answer and address. Ridiculous hard captchas on EVERY DAMN PAGE. Failing to crack my own answers I make a new account, a new email address to send information to and write everything down this time. Before stopping, putting my pen down and setting fire to the paper. The damn game has a registration key that links with the damn account. So I need to buy the game again. No thank you, enjoy your day.

content:
ber 19, 2016
												A lot has changed since I played so I'll change my review to reflect what I experienced in Heavensward and what I assume hasn't changed about the game. Dungeons: They're incredibly linear and shallow. Boss battles can be mechanically satisfying but the majority of your time is spent grinding mobs with a lot of health. There's really nothing fun or rewarding about them. You'll find yourself spamming queues for them in order to level up after the story stops leveling for you. All of these issues wouldn't matter too much if the combat this game has to offer was fun. There is nothing enjoyable about cooldown dependant combat. Especially if your class has buff micro-management. Raids and trials: Essentially giant sponges that have a long list of mechanics to memorize. You'll find your party wiping tons of times. Drops are rolled on so good luck getting what you wanted. There is nothing fun about completing the same battle over and over again. Why not add longetivity elsewhere? They're another aspect of the game negatively affected by the limitations of the combat system as well. Fates and hunts: Look, I know you want to give people a reason to revisit locations but collecting items and grinding mobs is not a good way to do it. Yet another aspect hindered by the combat system. PVP: It doesn't have much to offer, desperately needs more maps and more of an incentive to do them. You'll have to convert your friends to your grand company as well. Relic weapons: Probably the most boring, time demanding aspect of the game. Trust me, it's not worth the time and effort. Crafting: Literally useless for armor and weapons. Really just a tool for running the economy. Gathering: I'll admit, I like fishing. It's good when you just want to relax and take a break from what should be redundant. But the others, all you do is run around and press one button. Just WTF...Weekly capped gear: This is my biggest complaint about the game. There's gear that gets released with every update and you have to collect tomes by repeating already completed content in order to get them. By the time you have the set the next one is out so you feel like you wasted all of your time doing something boring and repetitive.IL: Item level, it's important as it dictates a lot about what you're able to do in this game. Forget skill, it's all about having the best gear in the game. That's why the game pulls in a lot of people with a superiority complex. Instead of getting better at the game through experience with the combat system, you get better by remembering patterns and getting a just as studied group to do raids all day (Or get the somewhat inferior capped gear)... Queues: Yep, you don't need any friends, play with random people from other servers.... Mostly easy stuff anyways. Story: Probably the only reason to play, ♥♥♥♥ endgame. So, do you want to do the same boring content over and over again for months just get better gear or do you want to play a game where every victory is rewarding and every challenge is engaging and satisfying?

content:
2016
Product received for free
												Note that this is for the base game, not the game plus expansion.Pros: Loads of content, loads of stuff to do.  Easy to get into multiplayer content, incentives for veterans to help rookies out, storyline quests progress your levels quite efficiently.  Interesting crafting mechanic, no-fuss travel, lush scenery and classic Final Fantasy aesthetics.  Loads of punny quest titles and memes hidden throughout.  A marriage mechanic that does not restrict (or even ask questions about) gender combinations.  Multi-rider mounts so you can haul your friends around.  Tons of quests and collections, a completionist's dream.Cons: Extremely technical, precise, minmax-y and a lot of poor communication, both between the game and the player and between player and player.  Terribad voice acting, overly flowery and verbose script, a plot that is hamfistedly dramatic and full of predictable and frustrating tropes, ugly "basic" gear practically until max level with few to no alternate options.  Gear-gated content and rng-based gear acquisition (this is a con, to me, take that as you will.).  Story quests force you to solo content, even in a game where no class is built to safely run solo.  Passive-aggressive elitism in the community.I ran out of game time, and I won't be renewing it.  This game is not for gamers who play games to have fun.   This is an MMORPG that is designed for people who feel good about themselves by getting very good at, or completing, extremely difficult or complicated content.   I'm not what one calls a "hardcore gamer" and thus the restrictive, overly specific Holy Trinity of RPGs gameplay left me feeling drained more than refreshed.  After failing a solo story quest duty five times in a row, and finding that I was doing everything right, I just simply should've gotten hit less, I decided I wasn't the kind of player Square-Enix had in mind when developing this game.I'm told Heavensward is much better story and much nicer mechanics, but if you can't even make it to the Heavensward  expansion's content, which begins only after you've completed your entire A Realm Reborn story quest, it's not worth even the cost of the base game.  I'm not going to muddle through a difficult, unsatisfying and frustrating game just in the hopes that I can pay more money to see if the expansion is more to my liking.I game to have fun, not to hate myself.

number of helpful: 53 of 103 people (51%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
er 6, 2014
												This is certainly a decent MMO, one of the better ones currently available, however, I find I can't recommend it.I really wanted to love this game, and the crafting was really great...at least until you got into higher level stuff.  It was with great sorrow that I realized that the higher tiers of crafting had some bizarre, invisible-except-for-certain-times-of-day mechanic putting my happy gathering spree to an immediate, screeching halt.  I understand the need to make things rare in order to maintain the economy, but seriously?  Faced with the choice of standing, waiting for hours for a single node to spawn or buying it from the market, buying it from the market seems a much better choice, at least, until you see the prices, and realise that it would take you just as many hours of harvesting regular things to sell to afford one.  I suppose this is 'balance' but it certainly wasn't fun, and crushed my hopes as a crafter.The game will also 'force' you to participate in queue-for-group dungeon content to advance your main story quest, and I found unless you queued as tank or healer, you'd be waiting sometimes hours for a group (which may or may not even stay together to finish the dungeon!) just to advance your main, storyline quest.  I eventually made it to the end, but after that I was left with just a sense of overall disillusionment.  Add that to the pointlessness of the crafting at higher tiers, and well...As I said, it is one of the better MMOs out there, but I don't feel it has anything for the 'long haul' - unless you fancy queueing for groups and sitting afk at node spawn points for months on end, which ultimately killed it for me.  Perhaps if you have unlimited playtime to do the time-sink routine it'd be worth a play.

content:
er 22, 2016
												FINAL FANTASY® XIV: A Realm Reborn™(My hours in-game are not representative as I have played the game off steam a lot longer)If I had to describe the game in one sentence: "One of the best MMORPG's out there, beautiful, challenging, complete!""In the beginning there was Final Fantasy XIV, and it was not good. For most games, the story would’ve ended there. But Square Enix, perhaps feeling that its prized franchise's name was in danger of becoming too literal, undertook a mammoth effort to keep Final Fantasy’s legacy from being marred by such a disaster. Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is the resulting do-over, and it’s a huge success on PC, PlayStation 3, and PlayStation 4. Beautiful, fun, and only a bit uneven in the late game, this dramatic reinvention easily establishes itself as one of the most sincere and effective apologies in gaming history." - IGN"The juggernaut Final Fantasy XI grew into was a tough act to follow, but no one predicted such a spectacular failure. Square Enix took note and responsibility and made a resolution to learn from its past mistakes, releasing Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn as a "rebirth" of sorts for the massively multiplayer online role-playing game that could. It has used its own personal Phoenix Down to come back fully revitalized, and the gorgeous new MMORPG is now a bustling world filled with curious players ready to get lost in it." - GAMESPOT"Final Fantasy XIV Online, massively multiplayer online role-playing game — an MMO barely alive. Square Enix rebuilt it. They had the technology. They had the capability to build the world's first relaunched FF title. A Realm Reborn is that game. Better than it was before. Better, stronger, faster." - KOTAKU"Final Fantasy XIV Online was a unique experience.""Supreme. The best MMORPG""Can't stop playing!" - FansIf my opinion has any value, FFXIV Online is a great game from many aspects. I do not like getting into gameplay details. That is part of the fun in discovering a new game. It is game that will continue to grow and I recommend it without any doubt!Take it easy!!

content:
ry 5
												I don't have an extreme amount of hours but I feel like I have a decent amount to write a review for it. I have been hunting for a good MMO for a very long time. I came across this game before and to be honest it was a little different than most MMO's that I have played and I was a little confused with how everything worked so the first month I just got scared off and went to hunting again. Months later I said you know what I'll give it another shot, I actually took some time to get through the game and I currently have a level 50 Monk and 45 Ninja. This MMO is absolutely phenomenal if you just give it a chance. Almost every MMO I have tried in the past year+ I have just left after a couple days but this game I cannot get away from. There are so many things to do in this game and the Community is honestly the best I've had in an MMO. You don't get punished or talked down to for doing bad or messing something up 99% of the time, people understand you are new and would rather teach you through it so you know for next time and guide you on what to do and what not to do while playing in a Dungeon, or just playing your class in general. For a pay to play title it is very much worth the money to get. If you don't believe me just read the reviews with the players that have over 5000+ hours. But this is coming from someone fairly new to the game so I have a solid say as I am not end game yet, but from what I have heard the end game gets even MORE addicting! Which I am excited about.Pros:- This game is BEAUTIFUL for it's age, honestly it's absolutely amazing- The Community is great from what I have experienced so far, last community in a game I found so great was City of Heroes- The STORY, I won't mention anything in the Story itself but, The beginning there is no voice overs but as you go along there's actual Voice Dialogue and it's GOOD- SO Many Classes, and you can swap classes ON THE FLY, one character can be all classes at once, no need to make a new character for each class- Cross Class Skills - High level players can play with lower levels in the low level dungeons at any given time! So you can jump in and help with anyone new you play with- The Classes are actually COMPLEX, you don't just sit there and button mash your best skills, you have rotations and you play the class how it is MEANT to be played unlike most games- CONTROLLER SUPPORT, ALSO THIS GAME IS CROSS PLATFORM WITH PS4- The music is awesome and helps the game feel like a Final Fantasy Game- Some Dungeons bosses actually have moves you gotta learn to dodge and mechanics you gotta learn in order to complete it successfully without wiping, making it more fun than just tank and spank. Not EVERY boss has mechanics though- The game gradually teaches you how to play your role with class specific quests, and a novice training hall for your role- Fat ChocoboCons:- WE NEED MORE TANKS AND HEALERS- The quests can get a tad bit repetitive but trust me you'll get through them- Not as much of a casual sit back and play game, you need all attention if you wanna do good in the end game content- Early on the game feels really slow and trust me I felt it, but when you gain more skills and get to farther content you won't feel as bad- Glamouring your items (aka: reskinning your armour to make your own look requires you to be level 50)- Inventory is too small in my opinion- RMT SpamMixed:- Side Quests are almost necessary your first time playing through, if you don't do it you will be underlevelled for some of content and will have to grind out Mobs/Fates/Etc- Crafting can be complex to some plays, you either really enjoy it or you tend to push away as far as possible fromNote that there are a lot more I can list for both Pro's and Con's but I honestly can't think of anymore on the top of my head. This game is Amazing in my opinion and is my favourite MMO at this point. I will update if I can think of anything else though!Give it a shot guys I highly recommend it.Note: I have not even accessed Heavensward yet so this is solely based on A Realm Reborn!

content:
5, 2016
FFXIV: A crafter's review.Note: My time-played is actually about half of my actual time-played, as I tend to launch the game through the base launcher instead of Steam. Steam says I don't have any time played this week which is... Laughably inaccurate. FFXIV isn't like other MMOs. Some reviews will focus on its amazing ability to keep a Final-Fantasy quality of story despite being an MMO. Some will rave about the spectacular Armory and Class system. Me? I'm a crafter. And hoo boy, does this game deliver.FFXIV doesn't limit you to one class in combat, and that thankfully extends to crafting as well. If you want to dabble in alchemy and weaving? You can do that. Decide you want to make some pretty jewelery? You can do that too with no penalties to your other classes. This game not only allows you to level every crafting class you please, it also offers some useful shortcuts for levelling in the form of levequests and, later on, collectibles. These systems reward you for striving towards quality in your crafts, instead of mindlessly grinding. And speaking of quality? The crafting system itself is amazing. FFXIV does not have a one-click crafting system like most other MMOs. Each class has abilities and rotations, similar to what you would see in a combat class. Some would argue (and I would agree) that the crafting in this game requires more strategy than the combat. So if you love to relax and make things for other people, or make some hefty profits playing the markets, this game might just be for you. To illustrate: I have exactly two combat-oriented classes at 60, and they really only count as one for this purpose as they both level with the same exp bar (Summoner and Scholar). On the other hand, I have every gathering profession (botany, mining, and fishing) maxed, and every crafting class nearly at cap. I just really, really enjoy the crafting system. It's hands-down better than any other MMO I've played. If you're ever on Balmung, feel free to hit up Lilligan Freshwater!

Several hours i got tired and decided to go to sleep, so i go the the inn, request a room, and hop ni the bed to log off. Yes, your read that right, your charcter can go to sleep in a bed to log off. ABSOLUTE BEST method to log off in an MMO i've ever seen, which is why i always do it, even made an outfit specifically for going to sleep before logging off.

content:
er 22, 2016
												FINAL FANTASY® XIV: A Realm Reborn™(My hours in-game are not representative as I have played the game off steam a lot longer)If I had to describe the game in one sentence: "One of the best MMORPG's out there, beautiful, challenging, complete!""In the beginning there was Final Fantasy XIV, and it was not good. For most games, the story would’ve ended there. But Square Enix, perhaps feeling that its prized franchise's name was in danger of becoming too literal, undertook a mammoth effort to keep Final Fantasy’s legacy from being marred by such a disaster. Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is the resulting do-over, and it’s a huge success on PC, PlayStation 3, and PlayStation 4. Beautiful, fun, and only a bit uneven in the late game, this dramatic reinvention easily establishes itself as one of the most sincere and effective apologies in gaming history." - IGN"The juggernaut Final Fantasy XI grew into was a tough act to follow, but no one predicted such a spectacular failure. Square Enix took note and responsibility and made a resolution to learn from its past mistakes, releasing Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn as a "rebirth" of sorts for the massively multiplayer online role-playing game that could. It has used its own personal Phoenix Down to come back fully revitalized, and the gorgeous new MMORPG is now a bustling world filled with curious players ready to get lost in it." - GAMESPOT"Final Fantasy XIV Online, massively multiplayer online role-playing game — an MMO barely alive. Square Enix rebuilt it. They had the technology. They had the capability to build the world's first relaunched FF title. A Realm Reborn is that game. Better than it was before. Better, stronger, faster." - KOTAKU"Final Fantasy XIV Online was a unique experience.""Supreme. The best MMORPG""Can't stop playing!" - FansIf my opinion has any value, FFXIV Online is a great game from many aspects. I do not like getting into gameplay details. That is part of the fun in discovering a new game. It is game that will continue to grow and I recommend it without any doubt!Take it easy!!

												I've played quite a few MMORPG's, and Final Fantasy XIV is one of the best I have ever playedDuring the content draught in World of Warcraft during the Warlords of Draenor expansion, I decided to give this game a shot and it was totally worth it! Though, this game is different from other MMO's as in there is a 2 second Global Cooldown, which may take some getting used to if you've played lots of other MMO's, another thing that is different is that their is a huge emphasis on story. In order to unlock dungeons/raids/etc. you HAVE to do the Main Story Quests. For example, once you get to level 50, you aren't able to just immediantly hop into the Heavensward expansion, you have to do the rest of the quests from the vanilla game, including quests that were added in patches. It may seem like it kinda sucks, but it really isn't bad and I personally enjoyed it, though I will admit that this isn't for everybody.(Note: I only have 8 hours of gameplay because I originally played the non-steam version of the game, but then bought it on Steam so that I could track gametime.)

y 6
												This MMO is a lot of fun, and the setting, storyline, and graphics are great. The group finder is a nice addition and makes finding groups for dungeons and raids very simple. The class/job system is very unique, and you can level all classes and jobs up on one character. This can be very useful since there are a lot of cross-class skills that you can use as well, though I split them across two characters, mostly for RP reasons. I enjoy the crafting system the most, with its own skills that you utilize while crafting, trying to increase the quality of the item while not failing to create said item. I'd recommend giving it a try, at least. Just keep in mind that you cannot link a retail-bought game to your Steam account, and vice-versa; this has caused a lot of confusion and isn't well-stated.

content:
er 28, 2015
												Oh how long it has taken for me to actually recommend this game.I would be embarrased if this thing would show my playtime with PS3 too. :PWould probably be going around 10k. '-' I think I am being too humble with my playtime guesses.So I started playing this game almost right after 'A Realm Reborn' had come out and it has been nice to see this game improve so much and even nicer to see that it has improved from the flop of an original Final Fantasy XIV.I will go through cons first, because they were easier and shorter to list:- Leveling can be quite annoying and slow (if you aren't into grinding a lot)- Combat can feel like you are spamming the same abilities all the time. Exception to this are usually highend raids.- If you aren't into crafting things or gathering materials, you will probably have a hard time earning gil (money)- Even though the class system is really nice, it feels like some of the classes are better than others in the sense of outgoing damage.- Damage dealers (DPS) usually have to wait really long (around 10-30 minutes usually) to get in to a dungeon or a raid unless you have a premade team. (this is not the games fault to be honest, just too many people as DPS)- Quests are usually boring. Exception to this are "unique quests" that have cutscenes or something different than the usual 'fetch, gather, kill' quests.That's all I can think of.Pros will probably be much longer, because I have so many good things to say:- NOT A PAY-TO-WIN GAME. <3 Pay-to-play tho- Graphics are really beautiful- Class system is really nice. You can change from healer to tank to damage dealer anytime you want to.- Really beautiful world... like one would expect from a Square Enix game.- Races are really diverse. You can be a kitty, dragonish person, tiny midget baby, an elf as tall as a building, a wall-like orc or just a meh human.- Dungeons are really pretty and primals (standalone bosses) look really interesting. There's a boss that looks like a stone... made out of stone.- I forgot to mention music early on, so let's just add it here. Music is really beautiful. Opening scenes have the best songs imo.- Big updates about every 2-3 months, little updates like some quests about every month.- You can magically make your ugly costumes beautiful... or your beautiful costumes ugly. You do you.- You can gamble. Tho it's not as addictive as FFXIII-2's slotmachines. :P- Specified Limit Breaks for every damage dealing class look awesome. If you are a healer left alone with your team dead and your team has full lvl 3 limit break, you can bring everybody back to life with full health. Not broken.- You can be lazy and do level 30 dungeon with level 60 character solo to get loot for my other classes. B)I am too lazy to write more pros, but maybe someday I will finish this list.Anyway, if you are thinking of buying this game... BUY IT.If you are thinking of moving from a console to Steam version like I did... DO IT. Much easier to get playtime or other cosmetic stuff.

content:
y 13
												I do not have much experiences with this kind of MMO, nor with MMO in general, as the only two MMO Games I played so far are Vindictus and Wakfu. The Gameplay in itself is not that exiting from the perspective of somebod who prefers either mor heavily action based games or Games that focus more on strategy. As a Mage you get a bunch of Skills that mostly do nothing more than some Damage and set a global cooldown, as a healer you also get a few skills that heal as well as a skill that changes your stance between healer and DPS stance. Crafting is quite unique as far as I can tell as it involves you using skills to improve your chances in getting a high quality product. The weakest point of this game is the Leveling system. You get a main quest line that developes your main role (the first one you picked) alongside itself, so that you always have the appropriate level for the next Main quest. However after a certain Level you open up all other classes for your character to choose from, all starting att level 1. If you did not need one side class to progress your main class above level 30 and some key skills from certain other classes for your main class, this would not be a problem, but the number of sidequests that are available as well as the EXP they give is quite low, so that leveling comes down to grinding overworld events that most of the time are minutes appart from each other. Thats not talking about the leveling of gatherer classes which is litterally grinding stuff you do not need and can't even sell because all the other gatherers have already oversaturated the market. Also most of the quests are rather boring, as they mostly consist of "Kill x local mobs", "Talk to somebody far away" or "Give person x this item". I can remember one Main storyline quest where I had to talk to the same guy 5 times as he ran away and respawned about a minute of walking time away each time in an area where mobs that aggressive mobs where quite common. So why do I recommend this game?Well, at first, once you reach lvl 15 with any class you open up Dungeons with this class. Those are just really fun and well designed. Really, there is not much else I can say about it. The player roles are handled well and each class and roll feels useful in every dungeon I played so far. No mandatory tutorial. There is one, but I never saw it. That's something more games need to do. The difficulty curve is crafted exceptionally well (at least up to level 30) so that you pic up all the skills necessary as you progress through the game. And finally the Community. As a new player you are marked with a sapling next to your name. Also the game actively encourages skilled players to help newcomers. Where in most other games  most people dislike playing with a noob, in FF XIV you get the feeling that most do like teaching new Players the techniques of the game. There is a newby network where new players can ask questons to skilled players and I have always got accurate answers right away. The playerbase is friendly and encouraging. Nobody rages when your mistake in a dungeon has your group repeat a boss fight. Thats what Multiplayer games should be like. Therefore, I give my full recommendation to anybody who likes MMO and is looking for one with a great communityTL;DR:PROS:- one Character, All the classes- Crafting- cross class skills- great difficulty curve- good dungeon design- nice story for an MMO- AMAZING COMMUNITY!CONS:- early game fights are rather boring- a lot of boring or annoying quest- secondary classes need level grinding

ry 6
												Of all the MMORPGs out there, Final Fantasy XIV has one of the most in-depth, incredible stories. This is the closest to its roots Final Fantasy has felt in many years, and I highly recommend it. Between character customization and the main story quests, there is plenty of content that non-MMO players can play with little to no need for other players interference. And for those who like the social aspect, there are Free Company's (guilds), lots of dungeons, and an amazing community of players from around the world looking to have fun and make friends. All in all, this is an amazing game, and I recommend it to anyone looking for a golden years Final Fantasy experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 16, 2016
												As someone who hasn't really given MMOs a fair shot as a genre due to not having a huge interest in it from the get-go and being a bit skeptical of pay subscription models, I am very glad that I was talked into picking this up by a friend. It is by far one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played, and having only picked up the game last week (at time of writing), the 27.8 hours that I already have logged in should be considered as a good indicator of just how enjoyable this game is, and how easy it is to be entralled in the universe that is Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn. Due to my inexperience with the genre, perhaps I lack the keen eye to be able to spot what makes an MMO truly great. But as a newcomer to the genre, and perhaps yourself too being on the fence on whether to try this MMO out, hopefully my words are relatable and equally as helpful as those who are veteran MMO players: Pros: - Stunning visuals;- Class Fluidity (being able to change classes on the fly; not having to worry about being pidgeon-holed into a class forever);- Many classes and subclasses to choose from; variety ranging from combat, magic, trades, and artisan roles;- Engaging storyline; - Free 30-Days game time for newcomers;- Very healthy population for a game that is already 3 years old;- New content, patches and expansions still being released by developers (new expansion coming in 2017 for e.g.)- Good guild support (in the game they are known as 'Free Companies');- Party System to play with friends;- Support for both Mouse and Keyboard, and Gamepad play; - Player-run economies (nice bit of micro-economics between players if they wish to use their classes to develop products/ items and sell to others in order to make a bit of money. Also makes for good banter between friends); - Nice balance of PvE and PvP content - you can quite easily enjoy both or pick one or the other if that's what you prefer.Cons: - Voice acting is a little lacking but otherwise great; there will be times often enough where you are just reading lines of text which can be a bit boring and/or skippingly tedious;- Game is arguably and substantially more enjoyable with friends than it is without.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2016
												Final Fantasy XIV is a good game. Visually it looks amazing and the gameplay is really fun. However there are a couple things that take it away from being at the top spots for MMO's i've played. Firstly the world size, although there are plenty of zones to explore they are all instanced. This means to go between each zone requires a loading screen which doesn't seem that bad but there also 2 areas in each major city meaning you have to load every time between them. Also unlike other MMO's the zones feel rather restricting. By that I mean that there's a set area you can walk in and there's a lot of predetermined areas you can't walk over where its just an invisible wall all the way around the object instead of letting you freely explore over it. This is minor really but it makes the world feel smaller.Secondly questing. Before you can move on in the game at all you must complete the Main Story Quests with over 180 between level 1 and 50. Once at 50 you have to play through exactly 100 more quests before you can even enter or use anything heavenward related. The quests still continue after that currently going post 60. This quest system isn't bad but after getting to 50 you have to spend way to much time going through pointless quests unless your interested in the storyline.Now that aside it is a really fun game. It has a fun class system which allows you to have 1 of every class on one character allowing you to switch between them when your not busy. Each of them requiring its own leveling. This system means that your not tied to one class and allows ou to play what's needed at the time. The boss fights are really fun with the Sync system meaning even people higher level than the boss will be synced with gear and level to help you so you get a more rea experience as to what it was like to do it when it was first released. Lastly just look at this game it looks stunning and that's all that has to be said on that.I would recommend this game.

content:
ry 5
												I don't have an extreme amount of hours but I feel like I have a decent amount to write a review for it. I have been hunting for a good MMO for a very long time. I came across this game before and to be honest it was a little different than most MMO's that I have played and I was a little confused with how everything worked so the first month I just got scared off and went to hunting again. Months later I said you know what I'll give it another shot, I actually took some time to get through the game and I currently have a level 50 Monk and 45 Ninja. This MMO is absolutely phenomenal if you just give it a chance. Almost every MMO I have tried in the past year+ I have just left after a couple days but this game I cannot get away from. There are so many things to do in this game and the Community is honestly the best I've had in an MMO. You don't get punished or talked down to for doing bad or messing something up 99% of the time, people understand you are new and would rather teach you through it so you know for next time and guide you on what to do and what not to do while playing in a Dungeon, or just playing your class in general. For a pay to play title it is very much worth the money to get. If you don't believe me just read the reviews with the players that have over 5000+ hours. But this is coming from someone fairly new to the game so I have a solid say as I am not end game yet, but from what I have heard the end game gets even MORE addicting! Which I am excited about.Pros:- This game is BEAUTIFUL for it's age, honestly it's absolutely amazing- The Community is great from what I have experienced so far, last community in a game I found so great was City of Heroes- The STORY, I won't mention anything in the Story itself but, The beginning there is no voice overs but as you go along there's actual Voice Dialogue and it's GOOD- SO Many Classes, and you can swap classes ON THE FLY, one character can be all classes at once, no need to make a new character for each class- Cross Class Skills - High level players can play with lower levels in the low level dungeons at any given time! So you can jump in and help with anyone new you play with- The Classes are actually COMPLEX, you don't just sit there and button mash your best skills, you have rotations and you play the class how it is MEANT to be played unlike most games- CONTROLLER SUPPORT, ALSO THIS GAME IS CROSS PLATFORM WITH PS4- The music is awesome and helps the game feel like a Final Fantasy Game- Some Dungeons bosses actually have moves you gotta learn to dodge and mechanics you gotta learn in order to complete it successfully without wiping, making it more fun than just tank and spank. Not EVERY boss has mechanics though- The game gradually teaches you how to play your role with class specific quests, and a novice training hall for your role- Fat ChocoboCons:- WE NEED MORE TANKS AND HEALERS- The quests can get a tad bit repetitive but trust me you'll get through them- Not as much of a casual sit back and play game, you need all attention if you wanna do good in the end game content- Early on the game feels really slow and trust me I felt it, but when you gain more skills and get to farther content you won't feel as bad- Glamouring your items (aka: reskinning your armour to make your own look requires you to be level 50)- Inventory is too small in my opinion- RMT SpamMixed:- Side Quests are almost necessary your first time playing through, if you don't do it you will be underlevelled for some of content and will have to grind out Mobs/Fates/Etc- Crafting can be complex to some plays, you either really enjoy it or you tend to push away as far as possible fromNote that there are a lot more I can list for both Pro's and Con's but I honestly can't think of anymore on the top of my head. This game is Amazing in my opinion and is my favourite MMO at this point. I will update if I can think of anything else though!Give it a shot guys I highly recommend it.Note: I have not even accessed Heavensward yet so this is solely based on A Realm Reborn!

content:
1, 2015
												Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn is a new version of the original game, just called Final Fantasy 14 Online, which came to be considered a complete failure. The title, available for PS3 and PC, did not disappoint in his recovery and has met the expectations of fans.  Realm Reborn is a very appropriate name for the game, as he was redone from scratch and this is already felt in its first minutes. Not just the game system, but also its history, characters and operation. Even those who were at advanced levels in the previous version here returning from scratch, entirely renovated.And so resumes the story of Eorzea, where goes the adventure. Entitled to reset characters and a new mythology, the player gradually gets involved in the action and drama lived by this world. Arriving with his hero in a city, out of nowhere, it needs to give their all to be recognized as someone of value.The character creation system is well done and complete. Even in the PS3, with commands totally focused on the joystick, it is possible to find and not get lost in the confusing menus. The game does not disappoint in this initial step and is quite complete in everything from races options the initial classes, through appearance setting.The introduction also fulfills its role well, with a story narrated in the third person and scenes breathtaking, setting the stage for what the player must face over the next few hours - and they are many. As a true MMORPG, Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn has a lot of content.As in any game genre, the evolution of the characters is due to the missions to be accomplished and advanced levels. Here the experience levels are back (remember they are gone in Final Fantasy 13?), Then the progression is natural. At each level, new skills and more news are unlocked, but there are some surprises.The first is the possibility of moving level with each class available in the game and others that can be enabled. Unlike other online RPGs, it is not necessary to create several characters to test other classes of heroes. Here you can simply decide that tired of being warrior and changing careers, becoming mage or archer. Of course, this will reset the level that chosen profession, but the former remains.This kind of change only adds personality of A Realm Reborn, striving to be a MMORPG different from the others, even though some follow successful trends - such as own missions. Fortunately the class system works very well, recalling the classic Final Fantasy Tactics at times - after all, many professions require various levels in others and so on, just as you learned in PlayStation 1.In fact, much in the Realm Reborn seems to have been inspired by previous games in the series. Elements ranging from the class system up to some spells, elements, materials and so on. Overall, the game risks trying to please enough who is long-time fan, although it can be availed by those who favor recently.We will not lie, the gameplay of Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn fit like a glove to the game. Everything is very well fitted both on the PC, as the PS3. Play on either platform is a rewarding experience, which is even more impressive for console users.It is worth mentioning that everything works well in DualShock 3 control, and even the PC version is fully compatible with an Xbox 360 control plugged into the computer. Commands are natural, menus can be easily accessed and attacks are activated easily, quickly and accurately, as a struggle requires.This type of adaptation is played master of Square Enix, since the game can be availed on both platforms with just one account. Unfortunately you have to buy it twice, once on the PC and one on the PS3, to play with them, but later the first month tuition - $ 15 every 30 days - goes for both platforms simultaneously. A nice plus.In addition, all the characters, friends list and historical are saved in both the PC and the PS3, the online server of the producer. This happens because the game is exclusively online, of course, but there is an advantage in this.A Realm Reborn has decent graphics to be called a legitimate representative of the Final Fantasy saga. With the right effects jaw-dropping, neat monsters and spells with many special elements, the game does not make ugly, despite the PS3 version lose a little - just a little - the title on the PC.Another point that stands out are the very cities. Some, at first, are very small, but then it changes exponentially. The player soon stumbles upon megacities, stuffed characters, either other players or the computer, but what matters here is the visual. A quick Internet search reveals, for those who do not have the game, as he is really beautiful in their environment, something that is difficult in a MMO, in many cases.

ry 3, 2016
												I have never liked mmorpg's in general though i have tried a few like WoW, Guild Wars 2, and some F2P titles. I thought the pacing and grinding was awful, i could never get past lvl 30 because by then I was too bored. This game however is something else. I'm a lvl 54 paladin by now. Here's why: there's a very captivating storyline, the gameplay mechanics are awesome (although the global cooldown might be a bit slow for some), the pacing is brilliant; you level quickly due to the main scenario quests and a thing called dungeon roulette (the game throws you in a random dungeon for an exp reward).Perhaps the most important thing (for me at least) since I never got to the endgame of an MMO before: the community is extremely helpful for new players, be it the guild you're in or the randomly selected partymembers with which you have to clear a dungeon. People were always ready to help out. There's also a lot of nostalgia-bombing for fans of Final Fantasy, but you absolutely don't have to have played the games beforehand.Overall I recommend this game for newer MMORPG players as well as older players.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 16
												Introduction:By far this is one of the better and possibly the best MMO out there and the best I've ever played. Theres so much that you can do in this game that you will spend days on (*Which is a good thing for an MMO Scenario) and it does most everything with a new refreshing style and with a lot of fluency. You won't regret making this purchase if you have an open mind and are willing to put some effort into it. Here are a list of personal pros and cons.Pros:+Easy for Casual/New-To-MMO Gamers to Pick Up (There's even a impleted "Novice Network" for Q&A)+VERY Friendly Community (I got invited into an FC (Guild) in literally 10 minutes after I started, as opposed to my previous MMO which took weeks to get a guild)+One Character Can Literally Do Everything+Simple Learning Curve to Classes/Jobs (Start off slow, and get faster as you go)+Active Community for All Content (No Ghost Towns)+Long,Interesting (and Funny) Story+Strong Role-Playing Community+Intensive Crafting Systems+Breath-Taking Graphics+Consistent Patches (As of this review, 3.5 is being implemented)+The Subscription Model (You get "Veteran Rewards" for each month you are subscribed)+Well Optimized (You are not required to sell that arm and leg to run this game)+Superb UI+Multi-Lingual Support (You can switch languages on a whim, no need to install a 'different' version)+Lots of PvE Content+Beautiful Music+Square Enix (They're great and helpful people!)+Gambling/Chocobo Races and Generally Fun Minigames +Easy to Follow Quests+Lots of Tutorials (Even ones for Roles)+Tons of Gear (Even Cosmetics for you Fashionistas out there)Neutral (Along with my personal opinion):+/- No Addons: Some people may find this as a put-off, but there are no add-ons whatssoever for this game, in fact its pretty much taboo to use them. (Personal Opinion: To me, this is a good thing because I think add-ons like DPS Meters etc., while they give you numbers and a basis to work off of, they also contribute to a hostile community, not saying everyone who uses them does but there is always those people who attack new players for not doing 'good') +/- +/- Grinding: Everyone's Love/Hate Passion(Personal Opinion: While personally I believe this is a good thing because it keeps you working towards something, it can also be very determential and "burning" to players+/- Map Size(Personal Opinion: Yes,i its decent sized at best, but with the constant updates, there will be more)+/- Global Cooldown - 2.5 Seconds Compared to 1 second to Accomade Controller Users(Personal Opinion: While A lot of people may have hate for this, I think its a good thing for slower reacting players AND they dont leave out the controller community)Cons:-Gil Bots/Spammers (They happen,but they arent as bad as some MMOs)-The Player Market (There are unfortunately a lot of trolls or people who just crash the market by selling items lower than vendor price OR,the polar opposite, price something very high because of monopolization. That being said it isn't a total loss)-Economy (Kinda Steep for what you earn,but Gil comes in Decently, Still a Con)-Occassional Bugs or Issues-Minor Issues involving Clarity (It doesnt happen often but when it does, you need Google.)Overall: This game is a great refresher compared to most MMOs out there. It does many things SO right that just makes it great if you can look past the Cons. The way Square Enix excutes a lot of things in FFXIV:ARR is done very well. If you are looking for a new MMO to fancy you or if you are new to MMOs in general, I can whole-heartedly say that i HIGHLY RECOMMEND this gameSquare Enix, You have really outdone youselves. I give this game a 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2016
												"Now! This is it! Now is the time to choose! Die and be free of pain, or live and fight your sorrow! Now is the time to shape your stories! Your fate is in your hands!" - AuronMMOs have innovated greatly and has always been the staple of open world traditional fantasy gaming since their conception more than a dozen years ago. All MMOs suffer the catastrophic sympton of the level treadmill and Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn is no exception. What separates a great MMO to a good one is a subjective one, and while FF14 doesn't bring anything new to the table, it does what it does extremely well.While not the most impressive MMORPG I've ever played, it certainly does grant a plethora amount of content to do. At first, I was afraid that FF14 was simply riding on its brand loyalty and kept my expectations low in case it was just another lackluster and half-hearted mess, but what I found instead, to my surprise, is a high quality MMO with superb art direction and average narrative. You are not limited to a single class or a single craft and are able to freely change between them at your leisure. While you are not granted as much freedom as you are in WoW, FF14 is still a worthy contender that deserves your attention.I have played dozens upon dozens of MMORPGs over the years, starting from EverQuest II, Maplestory and WoW, to Japanese and Korean MMOs which are not available on this side of the world. Most of them are plagued with toxicity in the community or unfaithful publishers and developers. Fortunately, FF14 seems to have kept these pitfalls to a minimum and for the most part, are quite pleasant. Of course, nobody can really control how the community evolves and it all depends on the server you chose to reside in.One of the most glaring issues I have found in FF14 so far is the lack of character customization options, which I think is mostly due to the fact that this game is still being supported on old-gen consoles. Many MMORPGs, even pre-2013, are able to support more options and basic sliders. Hopefully this will be improved in the near future. Another issue which personally I don't mind, but some players might, is the lack of evident PvP options and activities. Final Fantasy was always about collaboration and PvE content so I was not too disappointed by this.Overall, Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn is a solid MMORPG with very little flaws and should be praised for its high production quality. There are no free or paid MMO which is similar in vein, and should you be an MMORPG fan, at least give it a try.4/5Technical Tips for everyone:If you are planning to get this game, be aware of which version you buy. If you buy FF14 on steam, you must buy everything else on steam. If you buy it off the official Square Enix site, you must also buy everything else on there. The customer support will not help you if you manage to muck up one or the other.There are also numerous issues with the patcher itself as well. If I factored the patcher's quality into the score, it would be more like 3/5 or lower because of its glaring issues that needs immediate attention now. If you are getting errors of [30413], [25008], or within the 5.26 - 5.27 patch dates, you must use a VPS to solve it. Once you are past these patches, you may download the game via your normal speed again. I have a decent internet of 30/5 down/up, and it took me about two days to download the entire game due to this issue.

content:
5, 2016
FFXIV: A crafter's review.Note: My time-played is actually about half of my actual time-played, as I tend to launch the game through the base launcher instead of Steam. Steam says I don't have any time played this week which is... Laughably inaccurate. FFXIV isn't like other MMOs. Some reviews will focus on its amazing ability to keep a Final-Fantasy quality of story despite being an MMO. Some will rave about the spectacular Armory and Class system. Me? I'm a crafter. And hoo boy, does this game deliver.FFXIV doesn't limit you to one class in combat, and that thankfully extends to crafting as well. If you want to dabble in alchemy and weaving? You can do that. Decide you want to make some pretty jewelery? You can do that too with no penalties to your other classes. This game not only allows you to level every crafting class you please, it also offers some useful shortcuts for levelling in the form of levequests and, later on, collectibles. These systems reward you for striving towards quality in your crafts, instead of mindlessly grinding. And speaking of quality? The crafting system itself is amazing. FFXIV does not have a one-click crafting system like most other MMOs. Each class has abilities and rotations, similar to what you would see in a combat class. Some would argue (and I would agree) that the crafting in this game requires more strategy than the combat. So if you love to relax and make things for other people, or make some hefty profits playing the markets, this game might just be for you. To illustrate: I have exactly two combat-oriented classes at 60, and they really only count as one for this purpose as they both level with the same exp bar (Summoner and Scholar). On the other hand, I have every gathering profession (botany, mining, and fishing) maxed, and every crafting class nearly at cap. I just really, really enjoy the crafting system. It's hands-down better than any other MMO I've played. If you're ever on Balmung, feel free to hit up Lilligan Freshwater!

er 4, 2015
												I love this game! All the Final Fantasy characters and monsters! You don't need a new character to play a different class/job! The music is amazing! The story quests are easy to track, and put you at the center as the Hero of Light. Everyone is fighting for the same casue, no good vs bad, so you don't have to worry about being in the wrong place and getting smashed by another player. There is pvp arena's for those who like to. Plenty of things to do, like hunts, treasure maps, the Hildibrand story line, Chocobo racing. Speeking of Chocobo's, you get one early on for a mount, and it doubles as a companion to fight with you. The Duty finder is helpful to get into instances when your friends or Free Company members are not around. It also looks to other servers to find players, as well as being a cross-platform with the PlayStation version. Thats right, controllers and KB/M playing side by sideYour are rewarded for your total subscription time, no need to pay every month if you don't want to, you still get the rewards when you have meet the amount of days payed (exp. your first 30 days payed earns a reward, you can not play for a year, and when you pay again, you get the 60 days reward. After a few, it starts to take more time between rewards).Fighting in this game requires you to move to not be hit by mobs attacks. Even as a caster, you must pay attention to what is coming your way, and sometimes it is just a matter of knowing where to stand to get spells off before you have to move again.Everything in this game looks great, the characters and equipment, mobs and bosses, zones and backdrops, and of course, the cutscenes! Oh and the spells and ability!! There is even a Limit Break system while in instances. A shared guage that builds up to 3 levels, and the different class groups (exp. casters, healer, tank, dps) have a different limit break. A level 3 healer limit break will raise all dead party members, casters cast meteor. Time it right and save the day!Crafting, almost forgot crafting! You don't just click a button and wait for a bar to fill. You have skills to use as a crafter. Skill rotation helps determine output quality. Plus quests for your craft, and the gear just for crafting. Some of the crafting gear is also styled around what you are crafting.Gathering jobs are  miner, botanist, and fisherFree companies have houses that provide a place to grow crops for cooking or feed for your chocobo, training dummys to practice your rotation, and a few vendors for repairing equipment, buying regents, or just selling junk.All of these things (and so much more) tie together wonderfully, and give (me at least) a sense of place in the grand scheme of things.This, compared to one other mmo I played a lot of, is a huge difference. I just didn't feel the other game gave me any drive to "do great things" other than to complete a quest, or run a instance for the fun of it. I never felt like I was part of the Big Picture. Kind of hard to put into words, and maybe I just did not play with the "right" players, and I never made it to end game raids.Over all, FFXIV is Best MMO I have ever played, and still crave to play! I Hope you find this review helpful. :)(If my review has helped you decide, and/or you just like it, maybe you could toss some change to my steam wallet. HAHAHA)

ber 10, 2016
												I'm generally not into MMO's but this one is something else. It manages to blend the pacing and fun of a singleplayer RPG in an MMO like world. It's also exceptionally long  (I've spent more than 200 hours and more just on the main quest). While this may seem like a lot, the plot is actually very compelling and has probably the best writing the franchise has ever seen (voice acting is exceptional as well). FF 14 also manages to be a huge love letter to fans with lots of easter eggs and references to previous FF games. You also get to battle awesome iconic bosses including summons.Finally, and this is a personal plus, the game is super controller friendly. I've actually played the whole way through with a gamepad on my laptop and it feels very comfortable. This again reinforces the idea that this was an MMO designed as a singleplayer traditional FF game. There's a free trial so give it a go. You won't regret it.

er 14, 2016
												Story driven holy trinity MMO with a decent amount of content. Graphics are a bit simple, but look good overall. 9 starting classes, can later become one of 10 jobs. Jobs are fairly balanced, though some feel slightly stronger than others. Crafting system is rather unique, requires immense effort to truly make useful. Gathering system is boring.Early levels can feel very slow because of the initial lack of skills and the long global cooldown. Starts to get better after level 15.Story content must be completed to unlock the majority of content. The story between the first "arc" and the Heavensward expansion is a 100 quests of mostly filler, prepare yourself.Most content is very casual-friendly, only a handful of endgame raids really challenge players.Open world activities are a bit limited, most interesting things happen in instanced areas (dungeons, raids etc.).PvP is almost barren, worth it only for vanity armor.Lots of enjoyable side quests.Lots of references and fanservice to fans of the Final Fantasy series.I like it.

content:
12, 2015
												Honestly my favorite modern MMO. I've put countless hours into it and still find it endlessly enjoyable. The classes are all fun and unique, the crafting is active and interesting, and thanks to the job system you can experience everything the game has to offer with a single character.I took a break after finishing end game and getting all best in slot gear for my main class, but when I came back I found out that there was almost double the endgame content as when I left. This game is ever changing and ever expanding, new content is being added quite regularly, and it's not just new raids or dungeons. Whole new story quests, expanding on the lore, are added extremely often.I'm going to sum up my feelings in a list of good and bad from my perspective,******************************************************************************What's the good:The combat: It's slower then most other MMOs but that is a benefit, giving you more time to make a choice on what to do next and how it will be effective. It flows naturally and feels satisfying with just the right amount of power. Later in the game a boss fight stops being just a harder monster you need to work through, but instead becomes a kind of dance, each member of your party having their own role on the stage.The Quests: Yes, they are a lot of fetch quests and breadcrumbs, it's nothing special in the MMO world... But it somehow is. With all the dialog, lore, and the streamlined loot system, the quests in this game somehow transcend the "Go here and do this" standard. The first major thing you might notice? The quest givers know damned well what you're there for, the world has a long history of adventurers and questors, everyone knows you're there to help them with anything and damned if they are not going to take advantage of it. This makes for quite a fun experience as you do the most basic tasks for someone too lazy to pick up vegetables that are literally 5 feet away, and they acknowledge it. If you play and get to level 50, I HIGHLY recommend the "Hildibrand" Quest series started in Ul'dah, it will have you laughing till the end.The Dungeons: The dungeons in this game are basic, but awesome. Each able to be run in about 20-30 minutes and comprising of 3-4 bosses and trash. But they have a ton of atmosphere and charm, each one clearly was carefully crafted to be both visually appealing and challenging. And don't be fooled when you see the labels of "Hard mode" when you get to end game, Hard mode dungeons are not in fact just more difficult versions like in other MMOs, the game designers in fact go back and remake a dungeon from scratch, using the same location but a different path, with different trash and different bosses. Every Hard Mode is a whole new dungeon with a whole new story to it, causally taking place after the events you caused in the normal mode.Community: Other then a few bad eggs and elitists the community is extremely helpful and kind, you should never lack any help if you need it just by asking around. The game actually incentivizes high levels to help low levels with the Syncing system where a high level in specific situations can scale his/her level down to match a dungeon/quest/fate.*****************************************************************************What is Bad:Global Clock: All actions by players and mobs are on a global clock. This gives the game a somewhat turn based feel to it where everything is in time and synced together. Why is this bad? Because for more then a few classes in order to get the most out of your abilities you need to time them PERFECTLY based on this clock, and the fact that you can't see or interact with it means that you'll be guessing based on the countdown on your abilities. Best example of this being a problem is on the summoner Job, where timing your dots right makes the difference of 100% of your damage or 80% of your damage if you get it wrong.Insanely difficult dice roll quests: At end game, there is a series of quests to get your "best" weapon. This is... the most bull ♥♥♥♥ you will ever have to face in a game. You have to win 12 random dice rolls, and failing one means having to try again... Did I mention that each dice roll happens AFTER you finish one of the many random events around the world? That you have to wait up to 15 minutes for? Even with higher drop chance it is still Bull. (My best time for completing this quest.. 6 days, friend took more then 2 weeks) Lucky that this is optional.Character creation limitations: What's that? Wanna play with a friend who already plays the game? What's that? They are on the Levi Server? Well FK YOU! Servers every now and then (some more then others, to the point of being closed more often then open) will close their gate to new players, this is done to keep the servers from being over loaded, but this has the nasty side effect of keeping players from playing together on the servers they want, specially the more populated ones where you have more people to interact with and more options for guilds/fcs. Why is this done? Well that brings me to my last problem.Gold Spammers: Yup, the ever present MMO issue is here but 1000x worse. These pesky parasites will spam all chats, all areas, all the time. They even personally PM you with their virus ridden web links, promising massive amounts of gil for your hard earned money. This is done through the in game player search, where they just have to go alphabetically to find every single one of us and spam us one at a time. Of course they get banned, only to instantly make a new random name account and get right back into the game. they come in the thousands and they want all of your money, and in my opinion is the sole reason that servers are rotated the way they are. It's annoying, it's frustrating, and no mater how many of them you block there are always 5 more to take their place. Every now and then Square does a mass Hardware ban and that quiets them for a week or so wile they buy new computers/servers but it's only a temporary fix to a permanent problem.**********************************************************All in all, in my opinion, the good outweighs the bad. This game is an experience, an amazing experience. I've never had more fun with an MMO in my life and I'm not sure I ever will. No one would have thought that after the disaster that was the original FFXIV that this would be what comes out of it. I ask any of you reading, at LEAST give the 2 week free trial a chance. You have nothing to loose but a whole world to gain.
