content:
er 18, 2014
												Final Fantasy 14: ARR is probally one of the best P2P mmo's I've played in recent years, even moreso in my opinon than WoW etc.I've put a fair few hours into this game and played to max level at the time I left (lvl50). This game offers so much content and so many ways of playing that it is worth the £7 sub fee per month. Admitidly I did buy this game during a sale ( I picked it up for around £6) and it was worth every penny. However I can only base my review on my experience that I gained and of course you get what you want out of the game.Things I loved:-Each class levels up seperatly meaning that reaching max level with one class doesn't mean the end of the game.-Being able to switch class just by changing weapon/crafting item means seemless fluidity.-Being in a large Free Company (guild) is very enjoyable and many players are very friendly.-Even if you are not a huge Final Fantasy fan this is still a great MMO.-A nice loot greed/roll system that is done by class rather than all rolling on loot to stop people grabbing gear.-Daily quests/trails/challenges.-Fat chocobos.Things I didn't like so much:-Difficulty curve can be quite high and the ingame macro system isn't explained as well as it could be.-High level dungeon grinding for high level gear can be tedious especially as some gear can only be gained once per week.-All games have idiots and griefters on them, this is no exception.-£7 can be alot a month if you don't have alot of time to play.-Language barried can be a problem especially in dungeons.-People farming the later story missions skipping the cutscenes ruining it for first timers.Overall I can highly rate this game from a MMO point of view and while it does have it's downsides I put many happy hours into the game and met alot of nice people. Even if you are not a final fantasy fan, this game is a very nice MMO that is easy to pick up and enjoy!

content:
3, 2016
												I strongly recommend this as an immersive, beautiful, extensively narrative-driven experience, to the point even the crafters and gatherers get their own storylines! While the combat is simplified, it's neither too simple nor too frustrating, and the native controller support is an absolute joy. More depth and complexity can be found in the crafting and gathering systems, although the game is still quite easy to understand.The world, while only consisting of a few maps, is gorgeous, memorable, and full of detail, both in characters and environment.The music is also fantastic, expressing a broad array of emotions, from the tender to the grand. The boss music as well is varied and intense and uses a variety of styles and instrumentation.Achievement hunters might find the game a bit of a grind, as some of the achievements are literally just grindwalls, especially the ones relating to the game's minigame hub, but the fact that most game systems have achievements attached to them, and the sheer array of activities that can be done, mean achievement-hunting is fairly involved and interesting from an intellectual point of view.

content:
er 4, 2015
												I love this game! All the Final Fantasy characters and monsters! You don't need a new character to play a different class/job! The music is amazing! The story quests are easy to track, and put you at the center as the Hero of Light. Everyone is fighting for the same casue, no good vs bad, so you don't have to worry about being in the wrong place and getting smashed by another player. There is pvp arena's for those who like to. Plenty of things to do, like hunts, treasure maps, the Hildibrand story line, Chocobo racing. Speeking of Chocobo's, you get one early on for a mount, and it doubles as a companion to fight with you. The Duty finder is helpful to get into instances when your friends or Free Company members are not around. It also looks to other servers to find players, as well as being a cross-platform with the PlayStation version. Thats right, controllers and KB/M playing side by sideYour are rewarded for your total subscription time, no need to pay every month if you don't want to, you still get the rewards when you have meet the amount of days payed (exp. your first 30 days payed earns a reward, you can not play for a year, and when you pay again, you get the 60 days reward. After a few, it starts to take more time between rewards).Fighting in this game requires you to move to not be hit by mobs attacks. Even as a caster, you must pay attention to what is coming your way, and sometimes it is just a matter of knowing where to stand to get spells off before you have to move again.Everything in this game looks great, the characters and equipment, mobs and bosses, zones and backdrops, and of course, the cutscenes! Oh and the spells and ability!! There is even a Limit Break system while in instances. A shared guage that builds up to 3 levels, and the different class groups (exp. casters, healer, tank, dps) have a different limit break. A level 3 healer limit break will raise all dead party members, casters cast meteor. Time it right and save the day!Crafting, almost forgot crafting! You don't just click a button and wait for a bar to fill. You have skills to use as a crafter. Skill rotation helps determine output quality. Plus quests for your craft, and the gear just for crafting. Some of the crafting gear is also styled around what you are crafting.Gathering jobs are  miner, botanist, and fisherFree companies have houses that provide a place to grow crops for cooking or feed for your chocobo, training dummys to practice your rotation, and a few vendors for repairing equipment, buying regents, or just selling junk.All of these things (and so much more) tie together wonderfully, and give (me at least) a sense of place in the grand scheme of things.This, compared to one other mmo I played a lot of, is a huge difference. I just didn't feel the other game gave me any drive to "do great things" other than to complete a quest, or run a instance for the fun of it. I never felt like I was part of the Big Picture. Kind of hard to put into words, and maybe I just did not play with the "right" players, and I never made it to end game raids.Over all, FFXIV is Best MMO I have ever played, and still crave to play! I Hope you find this review helpful. :)(If my review has helped you decide, and/or you just like it, maybe you could toss some change to my steam wallet. HAHAHA)

												I played around 20-30 mmos, ranging from f2p to p2p titles like for example aion, lotro, eso, guild wars 1 and guild wars 2, age of conan, the secret world and ofc the many many f2p titles out there like maestia, shaiya etc. you name it. most of these games i did not play long, maybe for a couple of hours, because i was kinda biased through guild wars 1 which was until now my all time favorite mmorpg. ff14 is challenging this, because it is just ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. i can't even begin to describe this game. im even having fun farming resources and crafting stuff, because it is completly different to other titles out there. im dead serious i hate farming and crafting, i find it really boring, but in this game? nope im having so much fun. and the best part for me is, that i can really learn EVERYTHING with one character. i like this freedom. in gw1 you could essentially use all 1250 skills avaiable and try out so many different combinations, granted that's not the same as in this game, you have much less skills, but still it reminds me of this freedom to go and just try stuff and experiment. i missed that much. this game is giving me exactly that. so if you like freedom in a mmo concerning your character then go ahead and try it out. it's just 10 bucks and you will find out in 1 month if you like it or not ;)

content:
9
												This game... is addictive.I have not played much endgame, I'm sure it's fantastic, this is a run-of-the-mill MMORPG however. You played Tera, Aion, Rift, WoW, Guld Wars 2, etc, you'll see the familiar elements, the grinds, the farming, etc. So I'll list some pros/cons below:Pros:So much to do (explained below)Graphics"Engaging" cinematics, for real, this game has the most cinematics for a MMORPG I've seen yet (and I played SW:KoTOR)Cons:Semi-clunky (combat, movement, etc)Same old grind, if you want an MMORPG without some type of farm/grind, keep looking and good luck.So much to do:FIrst, the class system is fantastic. Anyone can be any class, crafting, and gathering profession. You wanna be a cook? Go for it, wanna be a warrior and a mage? You can (just not at the same time obviously).This, for me, was one of the things I was most warry about, but ended up loving. Finally, I can play an MMORPG game where I can do whatever I want with no consequences. All it takes is a switch of gear (your main-hand weapon determines you current class/profession). Of course it has a well-done gear swap system as well (can save gear sets, etc), and furthermore there's a "reccomended gear button to auto-equip you for your current class/profession, fantastic.The sheer multitude of classes, professions, and 3 gathering professions is amazing... you will NEVER search for something to do. Along with little quests, dungeons, scenarios, a "game room" type area you will not want.Now... if your goal is to reach endgame and do that content.... you may find the above frustrating and in your way. If you want to immerse yourself in the lore, enjoy the world and characters and various things to do, then you will be satisfied as I was. I've been playing for 71 hours, still haven't reached max level (even for the base game), but I've been levelling 3 classes, 5 professions, all 3 of the gathering professions).On that note, the gathering system and crafting system is the best I have seen, very in-depth. Fishing not only helps other professions, for example, but you also have a fishing log, showing you various areas you've fished at, fish found there, etc. If you like filling out logs and collecting ♥♥♥♥, this game has you covered.The crafting system also has abilities (like combat), to improve and craft you items. You don't simply hit a button and wait for a timer to craft! However, if that's what you want then yes, there is a "quick-craft" button that does that :)About the CLUNKY aspect. The overall feel is clunky not in a bad way, but compared to other games (WoW, Wild Star, etc) it falls more in line with GW2 for movement and combat, but slightly less fluid. There is a weight to movement and actions, the weight is not bad, but it's like the difference between playing Gears of War and Halo or Team Fortress 2 and CoD. Every button in FF14 has a purpose, every movement a reason, and you can feel it.Overall, this is one the most addictive MMORPG's I've played in a while... and I've played a good amount. This is the FIRST one besides WoW that I actually cared about the lore, and the first game where I've actually said "Wow... this crafting system is actually nice." Hell, I even enjoying fishing, fishing! If you've ever played WoW and levelled fishing to 700+ you'll understand what a feat it is for me to actually say I enjoy fishing in a game (that isn't specifically designed solely for fishing).Anyway, review too long and bulky, my work here is done.

content:
ry 9, 2015
												I thought I would never really enjoy a MMORPG again, but this game managed to change that.I played a lot of MMOs for a lot of time in the 90s and 2000s. But in the last few years, whenever I tried a new MMO, I usually thought to myself: "there are some really cool ideas here, but meh... I can't invest the time to really feel interested in actually playing it". In other words, I could appreciate MMORPGs, but couldn't really get myself to play them again.But I can play and enjoy FFXIV easily. It's hard to pin-point why: the game isn't very innovative, most of its mechanics have been used in multiple western and/or eastern MMORPGs before it. But it blends them well, and everything feels very polished and sleeky. And the Final Fantasy style gameworld, full of fan-service for fans of the series, lends itself well for a relaxing experience with gorgeous scenary. To help with that, the community seems to be more pleasing and much less toxic than most other MMOs, too.

content:
er 31, 2014
												My original review was SO LONG that it became a novel… That soon became a trilogy… That was eventually released on blu-ray DVD.…That’s how much I love this gametl;drThe game comes with a free month, which is more than enough time to give it a try. Despite the lackluster fighting IMO (read below), it doesn't detract from the overall gameplay. FFXIV is an absolutely gorgeous and vast world, and one of the best subscription MMO's I've played. I would recommend this game to any of my friends.---COMMUNITY:FREE-to-play MMOs are like highschool. You’re often surrounded by people who could care less about you or the community, and only a select few people who do care. One of the biggest reasons I play any subscription based MMO is for the community.SUBSCRIPTION based MMOs are like university. You’re at a hub where like-minded people gather, who have paid for their entrance, and in doing so will most likely try their best to thrive; the only way to do so is to become apart of the community.My first day on the server I was invited to a free company (a lesser form of a guild), and I was chatting up my FC mates like no tomorrow. We shared stories, got to know each other a little bit, and some of the max level players came out to help me quest for fun (they even gave me a free pet). We also went to the FC house and chilled in a hot tub, at which point we began to /dance naked without equipment. Needless to say, I felt like the community was incredible.Granted, everyone will have a different experience and some might not be as lucky as I was (although I still vouch for the community since my brother and friend were in thriving FC’s as well). GRAPHICS:I bought the game cause my friend said I could make a hot female character with an even hotter merchant retainer... He didn't lie. But seriously, the graphics are stunning. So often did I catch myself stopping to take in the scenery before I continued on with a quest. And even more often did I catch myself marveling my own character (and others) during cutscenes. From equipment and weapons, to the vast cities and it's inhabitants, I could spend hours just roaming around taking it all in; and that's saying something.ATMOSPHERE:I'll be honest, I'm very biased here, so I'll say it straight; I'm a huge FINAL FANTASY fanboy. From the lore to the cameo's, and all the familiarity that is FINAL FANTASY, I LOVED this game. But I'll try and be objective. IMO, this game isn't afraid to be cute and light, and neither is it afraid to be dark. This is reflective of the writing and plot, to the characters you meet and enemies you fight. Unlike most single player RPGs that become far too cute, or completely dark with no hope for salvation, or "try to hard comedic" with jokes that bash you're head in, this game is a combination of every world, and in nice moderation. I felt after my time spent in the game, I got to see its dark aspects, but never forgot how cute it was. Especially with the immense varying between areas. I adored how one city made me feel fresh and relaxed, while others made me feel rigid and attentive. The same goes for the characters you meet along the way. Even the monsters have great diversity. Although I'll stop there, because the sheer nostalgia of seeing a huge ♥♥♥ Malboro or Ifrit will turn this review into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.GAMEPLAY:Alright this is the bad part, and might be a deal breaker for you. There was nothing wrong with the gameplay. In fact, I actually prefer FFXIV’s approach to the job system where all you need is 1 character to enjoy all the classes (this also removes the bs of having to start another alt if you messed up a skill tree or something). What I felt was this game was very REACTIVE as opposed to PROACTIVE. I was constantly waiting to react during fights, either waiting for my cast bar to finish and react with another skill, or reacting to a boss attack field by moving out of the way. Many MMOs have you proactively moving to avoid damage rather than reacting to a boss attack field. And those same MMOs don’t have a cast time for every single skill, thus creating a rhythmic flow to attack skill rotation (PROACTIVE) rather than waiting on dreary cast bars (REACTIVE). In general this made my gameplay feel lackluster at times. But this never detracted from overall gameplay. Mind you, mastering cast bar skill rotation (and skill rotation in general) is an art form all its own.CONCLUSION:I would highly recommend this game. Even the gameplay which I just bashed isn’t a deal breaker (for me at least). There is nothing wrong with a reactive style of play. Keep in mind this review is just my opinions. FINAL (fantasy) verdict:8.5/10

content:
er 18, 2014
												Final Fantasy 14: ARR is probally one of the best P2P mmo's I've played in recent years, even moreso in my opinon than WoW etc.I've put a fair few hours into this game and played to max level at the time I left (lvl50). This game offers so much content and so many ways of playing that it is worth the £7 sub fee per month. Admitidly I did buy this game during a sale ( I picked it up for around £6) and it was worth every penny. However I can only base my review on my experience that I gained and of course you get what you want out of the game.Things I loved:-Each class levels up seperatly meaning that reaching max level with one class doesn't mean the end of the game.-Being able to switch class just by changing weapon/crafting item means seemless fluidity.-Being in a large Free Company (guild) is very enjoyable and many players are very friendly.-Even if you are not a huge Final Fantasy fan this is still a great MMO.-A nice loot greed/roll system that is done by class rather than all rolling on loot to stop people grabbing gear.-Daily quests/trails/challenges.-Fat chocobos.Things I didn't like so much:-Difficulty curve can be quite high and the ingame macro system isn't explained as well as it could be.-High level dungeon grinding for high level gear can be tedious especially as some gear can only be gained once per week.-All games have idiots and griefters on them, this is no exception.-£7 can be alot a month if you don't have alot of time to play.-Language barried can be a problem especially in dungeons.-People farming the later story missions skipping the cutscenes ruining it for first timers.Overall I can highly rate this game from a MMO point of view and while it does have it's downsides I put many happy hours into the game and met alot of nice people. Even if you are not a final fantasy fan, this game is a very nice MMO that is easy to pick up and enjoy!

content:
7, 2015
I will update this review probably once I reach 1000+ hours. My hours are 160 at the time of this review.So you probably want a review from someone who doesn't play MMOs, or at least, didn't. I played Runescape back in 2007 with some friends. That was the only MMO I've ever played. FFXIV was still easy to learn, and I just didn't feel a stranger at all. It's impossible to not enjoy this game unless you just hate MMO's, or are impatient.I bought this like a month ago and I just reached level 50 dragoon. It's all so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing. The story is incredible, the music is stunning, the art is amazing, graphics are ridiculously beautiful. The classes (fighting classes, crafting classes, and gathering classes) are all uniquely rewarding. With that said, you can literally play as ANY class in the entire game with a single character. Wanna be a gladiator? Equip a sword. Miner? Equip a pickaxe. Wanna just ♥♥♥♥in cook? Equip a skillet. The community is wonderful. I'm no veteran hence my hours played, but I'm in a great Free Company (like a clan in other games) with great players that make me feel at home.However, this is definitely not a game for everyone. It could be quite intimidating to the average casual gamer who doesn't understand the basic principles of most MMO games. This game requires quite a bit of your time and patience. So, I would absolutely recommend looking up gameplay videos to understand the combat system if you're really questioning this purchase.I guess the only downside is I wasted my entire summer on a single video game. In the real life that sucks, but in Eorzea, it has been so wonderful.

content:
er 28, 2015
												I thought it was about time to write a review for this, since I've put quite some time into it.Final Fantasy 14 is really freaking amazing. There is always so much content for you to be doing.FF14 was my second paid MMO, first being a... RUNE game... Yeah you know the one. Anyway, this game just seems so much more superior than the other MMOs I have played. Both free and paid.When I first started playing this, I was clueless on so much. The game throws a lot at you in the beginning but it's also not difficult to catch on. I started in Ul'Dah, and for those who have played the game might know how easy it is for a newbie to get lost there in the beginning!The game has multiple classes you can play as. You can start as a Gladiator, Lancer, Arcanist... Anything available, really! And to make it better, once you reach level 10 (I think...), you are told that you can now change class whenever you wish. That's right, you read that correctly. So if you started as a Gladiator and then was having second thoughts, you can go ahead and change your class to whatever you want. Anything!There are also multiple crafting classes and gathering classes. Again, you can become these whenever you please. Crafters will make things like armours, weapons, foods and potions. And believe me, your gatherers and crafters are fantastic money makers.Now onto the content. Final Fantasy 14 is FLOOOOOODED with content. You really won't get bored. (Seriously, look at my time played ._.). The story is amazing, and I won't talk much about it to avoid spoilers. But IT'S GOOD. There is plenty of side quests for you to enjoy too. Some of them are quite funny, like the Hildibrand sidequest. Ontop of the quests, there are loads of dungeons, raids, primal fights and even PVP.You definately will not get bored playing this game. You'll always find yourself being able to do something. You might wanna go kill things to level up, run a dungeon, go and explore the world or sit down by a lake and do some fishing.The choice is yours, Adventurer ;)

content:
er 18, 2014
												Final Fantasy 14: ARR is probally one of the best P2P mmo's I've played in recent years, even moreso in my opinon than WoW etc.I've put a fair few hours into this game and played to max level at the time I left (lvl50). This game offers so much content and so many ways of playing that it is worth the £7 sub fee per month. Admitidly I did buy this game during a sale ( I picked it up for around £6) and it was worth every penny. However I can only base my review on my experience that I gained and of course you get what you want out of the game.Things I loved:-Each class levels up seperatly meaning that reaching max level with one class doesn't mean the end of the game.-Being able to switch class just by changing weapon/crafting item means seemless fluidity.-Being in a large Free Company (guild) is very enjoyable and many players are very friendly.-Even if you are not a huge Final Fantasy fan this is still a great MMO.-A nice loot greed/roll system that is done by class rather than all rolling on loot to stop people grabbing gear.-Daily quests/trails/challenges.-Fat chocobos.Things I didn't like so much:-Difficulty curve can be quite high and the ingame macro system isn't explained as well as it could be.-High level dungeon grinding for high level gear can be tedious especially as some gear can only be gained once per week.-All games have idiots and griefters on them, this is no exception.-£7 can be alot a month if you don't have alot of time to play.-Language barried can be a problem especially in dungeons.-People farming the later story missions skipping the cutscenes ruining it for first timers.Overall I can highly rate this game from a MMO point of view and while it does have it's downsides I put many happy hours into the game and met alot of nice people. Even if you are not a final fantasy fan, this game is a very nice MMO that is easy to pick up and enjoy!

content:
7, 2016
												Sorry for this long review, if you dont wont to read, then all the other ine sentence reviews should convince you to get this game. this is pretty much just details on the game itself and my thoughts on them. i dont think i get really specific so if you wanna know more just go to the wiki or the play guide http://store.steampowered.com  Pros (in my opinion, obviously) Most Classic RPG experiance in an MMO that ive had in a while. its its pretty rare these days where you start off as an actual  normal adventurer and get quests from an adventurers guild. these days most mmos are just replica of "you are a chosen one! now go fight evil" sorta thing. The combat system is about the same as the standard good old formula, has som pretty animations for combat as well. The Gear and weapons have a nice aesthetic feeling to them and they get the look of the gear right as well, going from begginners gear to higher level gear, it actually matches what it looks like in comparison to the level. no flashy beginners gear. to bad that there is no costume slots so you can use the image of old gear, but most of them look great to begin with. A great part of the class mechanics is that once you reach lvl15 on your first class, you can choose to pick up any other class and conintue with that, of course starting from level one again. but if you dont want to do this you can always start a new character, since they give a generous amount of character slots per world (at least after the ifrst month of paid sub). The Story is quite typical of a final fantasy game, chocka block full of characters and plot. since i play most games while listening to something,  i usually dont pay much attention to what the npc's say and just follow quest obj, but this has probably been one of only 10 or so games that i dont do that. Animations, Graphics and Design of Final Fantasy 14 are quite good, if you look around you realise that every npc, wheteher they be friend or enemy, has a ton of idle animations and animations while being interacted with. for me who uses a pretty low end pc (basically what the minimum it states, maybe a bit lower) its still looks quite beautiful. The Environment and world itself is quite expansive,though it is section off into different regions. For example Thanalan (name of whole region) -> split into North, South East, e.t.c There is thankfully no game breaking pay to win gear. though there is gear that you can by with real money, its aesthetic stuff like mounts and costumes. basically all you can by with real money is -> The game itself + paid DLC ( which so far is only heavensward), the sub needed to play and aesthetic stuff like premium dyes, mounts, nostalgic costumes and little pets that will follow you around.Also if you happen to be a japanophile like me you can hav Jap audio with english sub. just saying, but theres nothing wrong with the english voice actors, they're acutally pretty good. Cons i wished that they would add more voices to the cutscenes and general talking to npcs, because so far only important mission cutscenes have voice.maybe no sub fee or a lower one, its pretty heavy on my wallet since i play alot. hahahasometimes around really big updates the launcher freaks out and does a bunch of erros and you'll end up redownloading it or searching the internet for an answer.

content:
ry 9, 2015
												I thought I would never really enjoy a MMORPG again, but this game managed to change that.I played a lot of MMOs for a lot of time in the 90s and 2000s. But in the last few years, whenever I tried a new MMO, I usually thought to myself: "there are some really cool ideas here, but meh... I can't invest the time to really feel interested in actually playing it". In other words, I could appreciate MMORPGs, but couldn't really get myself to play them again.But I can play and enjoy FFXIV easily. It's hard to pin-point why: the game isn't very innovative, most of its mechanics have been used in multiple western and/or eastern MMORPGs before it. But it blends them well, and everything feels very polished and sleeky. And the Final Fantasy style gameworld, full of fan-service for fans of the series, lends itself well for a relaxing experience with gorgeous scenary. To help with that, the community seems to be more pleasing and much less toxic than most other MMOs, too.

												If you love Final Fantasy games and are unsure about picking it up because its a MMO and it'll take away from the experience. Then allow me to reassure you, Even though its an MMO, FFXIV has done it amazingly well with their Story. Taking part with the MMO basics of Dungeons, Raids and Guilds, as well as putting their own twist on it with Aeons/Primals, If you don't get hooked on the fights, The music will get you to come back to them, Each having an amazing soundtrack as it fires you up to fight onward, Coming from someone who enjoys Final Fantasy games in a whole and has put hours upon hours into them, Going to A Realm Reborn was a great refreshing feeling.So far my best experience is the Trial fights with all the different Primals they have in store for you, Not only in A Realm Reborn, but in the Heavensward Expansion as well. Each having a great impact and leaving you wanting to go at them again and again.One other thing to mention is that Final Fantasy 14 allows you to change classes at will, so theres no need to make another character to play a different class, You may begin a new class at anytime by talking to their respected Guilds and taking on their Quests.Long story short, The games great, Ive had countless hours of fun, Trials kept me wanting to come back and VS tough opponents, Dungeons had great mechanics and a great level curve, The music is amazing to listen to, Although it is Pay to Play, You can start a free trial to see if you would like it or not, But Would recommend.

ber 12, 2016
												This game is possibly one of the best MMOs i've ever played. dont be fooled by my 1.5 hours on record. i personally bought the disc edition of this game so my main account is outside of the steam client. i can guarantee you i have well over 1500 hours into this game.Although some of the updates of late have been controversial, there is no shortage of fantastic content in this game and it is easy to see that square enix spared no expense. from start to end game, there is rarely a dull moment since every single zone, dungeon, and raid, is completely unique and jammed full of amazing character and design.the music in this game is second to none. honestly, it is the type of music that CREATES nostalgia within you. while the main themes of the game are completely new and inovative, the game incorporates many of the prior games' iconic music tracks such as final fantasy 7 golden saucer, ff7 costa del sol, and many remixes of battle themes from throughout the series. you will find yourself humming along to the theme of a boss fight you have never been in and then realize "Hey! this is from ff4!". but truthfuly, there is nothing like coming back to your starting city and being welcomed by the grand theme of Ul' Dah, or the Liberating bagpipes of Limsa Lominsa. even the perky, yet calm harp and flute of Gridania. i would buy the game just for the music.The graphics in this game are some of the best graphics you will find in an mmo. there are others that boast amazing graphics that surpass this, but the style is quite amazing.the crafting system is the best i have ever experienced and is extremely rewarding. the economy is also, alive and thriving. i can guarantee that you will get many many hours of entertainment out of this game.

content:
3, 2016
												I strongly recommend this as an immersive, beautiful, extensively narrative-driven experience, to the point even the crafters and gatherers get their own storylines! While the combat is simplified, it's neither too simple nor too frustrating, and the native controller support is an absolute joy. More depth and complexity can be found in the crafting and gathering systems, although the game is still quite easy to understand.The world, while only consisting of a few maps, is gorgeous, memorable, and full of detail, both in characters and environment.The music is also fantastic, expressing a broad array of emotions, from the tender to the grand. The boss music as well is varied and intense and uses a variety of styles and instrumentation.Achievement hunters might find the game a bit of a grind, as some of the achievements are literally just grindwalls, especially the ones relating to the game's minigame hub, but the fact that most game systems have achievements attached to them, and the sheer array of activities that can be done, mean achievement-hunting is fairly involved and interesting from an intellectual point of view.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 3, 2016
												I have never liked mmorpg's in general though i have tried a few like WoW, Guild Wars 2, and some F2P titles. I thought the pacing and grinding was awful, i could never get past lvl 30 because by then I was too bored. This game however is something else. I'm a lvl 54 paladin by now. Here's why: there's a very captivating storyline, the gameplay mechanics are awesome (although the global cooldown might be a bit slow for some), the pacing is brilliant; you level quickly due to the main scenario quests and a thing called dungeon roulette (the game throws you in a random dungeon for an exp reward).Perhaps the most important thing (for me at least) since I never got to the endgame of an MMO before: the community is extremely helpful for new players, be it the guild you're in or the randomly selected partymembers with which you have to clear a dungeon. People were always ready to help out. There's also a lot of nostalgia-bombing for fans of Final Fantasy, but you absolutely don't have to have played the games beforehand.Overall I recommend this game for newer MMORPG players as well as older players.

content:
9
												This game... is addictive.I have not played much endgame, I'm sure it's fantastic, this is a run-of-the-mill MMORPG however. You played Tera, Aion, Rift, WoW, Guld Wars 2, etc, you'll see the familiar elements, the grinds, the farming, etc. So I'll list some pros/cons below:Pros:So much to do (explained below)Graphics"Engaging" cinematics, for real, this game has the most cinematics for a MMORPG I've seen yet (and I played SW:KoTOR)Cons:Semi-clunky (combat, movement, etc)Same old grind, if you want an MMORPG without some type of farm/grind, keep looking and good luck.So much to do:FIrst, the class system is fantastic. Anyone can be any class, crafting, and gathering profession. You wanna be a cook? Go for it, wanna be a warrior and a mage? You can (just not at the same time obviously).This, for me, was one of the things I was most warry about, but ended up loving. Finally, I can play an MMORPG game where I can do whatever I want with no consequences. All it takes is a switch of gear (your main-hand weapon determines you current class/profession). Of course it has a well-done gear swap system as well (can save gear sets, etc), and furthermore there's a "reccomended gear button to auto-equip you for your current class/profession, fantastic.The sheer multitude of classes, professions, and 3 gathering professions is amazing... you will NEVER search for something to do. Along with little quests, dungeons, scenarios, a "game room" type area you will not want.Now... if your goal is to reach endgame and do that content.... you may find the above frustrating and in your way. If you want to immerse yourself in the lore, enjoy the world and characters and various things to do, then you will be satisfied as I was. I've been playing for 71 hours, still haven't reached max level (even for the base game), but I've been levelling 3 classes, 5 professions, all 3 of the gathering professions).On that note, the gathering system and crafting system is the best I have seen, very in-depth. Fishing not only helps other professions, for example, but you also have a fishing log, showing you various areas you've fished at, fish found there, etc. If you like filling out logs and collecting ♥♥♥♥, this game has you covered.The crafting system also has abilities (like combat), to improve and craft you items. You don't simply hit a button and wait for a timer to craft! However, if that's what you want then yes, there is a "quick-craft" button that does that :)About the CLUNKY aspect. The overall feel is clunky not in a bad way, but compared to other games (WoW, Wild Star, etc) it falls more in line with GW2 for movement and combat, but slightly less fluid. There is a weight to movement and actions, the weight is not bad, but it's like the difference between playing Gears of War and Halo or Team Fortress 2 and CoD. Every button in FF14 has a purpose, every movement a reason, and you can feel it.Overall, this is one the most addictive MMORPG's I've played in a while... and I've played a good amount. This is the FIRST one besides WoW that I actually cared about the lore, and the first game where I've actually said "Wow... this crafting system is actually nice." Hell, I even enjoying fishing, fishing! If you've ever played WoW and levelled fishing to 700+ you'll understand what a feat it is for me to actually say I enjoy fishing in a game (that isn't specifically designed solely for fishing).Anyway, review too long and bulky, my work here is done.

content:
4, 2015
												A very solid MMORPG. Sticks to many of the traditional aspects that made the genre popular while putting its own spin on things, as well as keeping the Final Fantasy vibe alive and well.  Final Fantasy fans who are not very familiar with MMORPGs will find this to be a good entry point into the genre. MMO fans should get enjoyment out of it even if they are not big into the Final Fantasy series, although they may not appreciate it as much as somebody who is very familiar with the Final Fantasy series.  Even if you aren't a fan of playing MMOs, you can still get a good experience just by playing through the main storyline.  Since the first month of game time comes free, that gives you more than enough time to play through the story if that's all you desire to do. It's definitely worth picking up and trying. It's a fun game and my MMO of choice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 11, 2015
												At this point, writing a review is a bit like asking Gordon Ramsay if he likes to cook. I have nearly 300 hours in this game as of writing, and I've enjoyed every single one of them. Also I manage perfectly well to balance my study with this game. If anything it actually IMPROVED my performance, it drives me to work harder during the day so I have more free time during the evenings to play.The good:+ Summarized: This game takes everything from other MMOs that works, strips out what doesn't work, and innovates on features in its own way.+ The dev team is very much aware that the original FFXIV had a horrible start, and their mantra is "earn and deserve the players' trust". They deliberately chose to keep the game subscription-based because it offers them and the players more stability.+ The cross-server Duty Finder lets you queue up for every form of cooperative content from wherever you are in the world.+ Big bonuses for people who repeat old content in the Duty Finder (sadly only once per day), to encourage keeping storyline content populated so you won't get stuck just because you can't find anyone to play with.+ Classes are varied and the handful I've tried are fun to play. At level 30, every class evolves into one or two Jobs that are even more specialized.+ You can train every class on a single character. In fact most Jobs have a secondary class requirement that also needs to be trained.+ There are two levels of subscription, Entry and Standard. Entry is cheaper than Standard, but doesn't allow recurring payments and restricts you to 1 character per server, 8 in total. But since you can just train every class on a single character anyway, this won't actually lock you out of anything.+ The world is beautiful and feels alive.+ The lore and story are of true Final Fantasy levels, and better than I've seen in any other MMO.+ The game tries to do that "chosen one in a world of chosen ones" that story-heavy MMOs are all guilty of, but actually executes it very well. In-storyline, your character becomes something of a living legend after a while, and everyone acknowledges that you faced off with terrible monsters and lived to tell the tale. When someone does question your skills in the storyline, it's usually because they actually are a fool.+ Boss battles are extremely memorable, and all have interesting mechanics.+ The music. Oh God, the music. The regular zone music is already plenty good and immersive, but the composer went completely wild with the dungeon and boss themes. Expect epic choires, punk rock and heavy metal. One boss in particular has 5 different phases, and every phase has its own song.'The middle:~ Truly understanding the mechanics of your class/job and the role you fulfill in party dynamic takes quite some time and willingness to learn. If someone gives you good advice, listen to it. I learned the most by making mistakes, and getting tips on what I should have done differently from people who were there with me. This process still continues today, and I only get better by it.The bad:- Levelling alternate classes gets quite grindy. You get massive XP boosts when you level classes that are below the level of your highest class, but even with that you'll need to invest a lot of time past level 30. Your primary class should be fine doing only Main Story Quests most of the time, at least until you reach Heavensward.- You start with a lot of inventory space and even an armoury chest to store your equipment in, but you will inevitably run into the limits of this with how many crafting materials there are in the game, and how many different sets of equipment you need if you play multiple classes. Rather than a bank the game features retainer NPCs which can do something to alleviate the burden, but I think the game would really benefit of a Guild Wars (2) type of crafting material specific storage.- There is a shortage of Tanks and Healers in the Duty Finder queues. But this isn't really the game's fault, and multi-classing makes it easy to just ask a friend to jump in for a role if you really can't find anyone.- Not all parts of the story are equally good, and some characters are very annoying.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												I LOVE this game so far! Quitting WoW after 10 years and was looking for an MMO with depth. I've dabbled in Aion and Rift periodically, but thought I'd try FF 14. The negatives coming from World of Warcraft are the numerous loading screens and the steep learning curve. BUT!!! Honestly, the game is good enough that I don't mind much. The GCD is rather long initially, but combat speeds up as you receive more abilities. The ability to change classes on the fly is fantastic. This can be a drawback as it is easy to get sidetracked if you try to level everything at the same time. The graphics and attention to detail are stunning (especially if you like anime/Japanese-style art). FFXIV is heavily story-driven. Sadly, the cut-scenes aren't always voice acted, but many of them are interesting or entertaining for someone new to the franchise. I popped onto WoW to help my husband last night and it felt shallow and uninspired compared to FFXIV.If you are coming from Warcraft, bring your map/navigating skills. It took me a bit to get used to the maps/navigating compared to other MMOs. Also, do not skip the help topics...it will save you a LOT of trouble.

content:
er 24, 2014
												Having played (and still am playing) World of Warcraft I've been over the MMO market to find one as fun as WoW. Warhammer Online didnt work for me, The Old Republic had nothing in the way of content (also its Star Wars, don't heavily like the series), Maple Story was ok in small doses, and Tera, while pretty, has one ♥♥♥♥ community.So while I knew of the original FFXI I never played it and got the basics from hearsay, and the original launch of FFXIV left me glad I had no interest, cut to the present and SE decided to pull it, rework the game, and with Naoki Yoshida's wonderful direction remade and released a truly fantastic MMO that reminded me of the first time I played WoW.Eorzea literally grabbed me like Azeroth first did and I was everywhere, I had my first timer bungles yes, but the game is fair in its guidance and shows you where to go. Dungeons are only 4 people instead of a traditional 5 but that also seems to help on content as with 5 you could have one person carry everything with 4 everyone must pull their own weight. Dungeons offer a fine line of challenge, reward, and ease, you do a hard mode dungeon, wipe on a boss several times but push it more and eventually kill it and get loot and no one is mad but glad? Always wonderful. While young, the games raiding is solid if needs just a bit more tweaking, not I have not done Coil so I cant speak on those as I know they are quite challenging but it all works well and wonderful.Overall I got my monthly payment of enjoyment, and with the developers constantly working on new content for everyone to do it doesnt get stale, also PLAYER HOUSING!

content:
er 28, 2015
												I thought it was about time to write a review for this, since I've put quite some time into it.Final Fantasy 14 is really freaking amazing. There is always so much content for you to be doing.FF14 was my second paid MMO, first being a... RUNE game... Yeah you know the one. Anyway, this game just seems so much more superior than the other MMOs I have played. Both free and paid.When I first started playing this, I was clueless on so much. The game throws a lot at you in the beginning but it's also not difficult to catch on. I started in Ul'Dah, and for those who have played the game might know how easy it is for a newbie to get lost there in the beginning!The game has multiple classes you can play as. You can start as a Gladiator, Lancer, Arcanist... Anything available, really! And to make it better, once you reach level 10 (I think...), you are told that you can now change class whenever you wish. That's right, you read that correctly. So if you started as a Gladiator and then was having second thoughts, you can go ahead and change your class to whatever you want. Anything!There are also multiple crafting classes and gathering classes. Again, you can become these whenever you please. Crafters will make things like armours, weapons, foods and potions. And believe me, your gatherers and crafters are fantastic money makers.Now onto the content. Final Fantasy 14 is FLOOOOOODED with content. You really won't get bored. (Seriously, look at my time played ._.). The story is amazing, and I won't talk much about it to avoid spoilers. But IT'S GOOD. There is plenty of side quests for you to enjoy too. Some of them are quite funny, like the Hildibrand sidequest. Ontop of the quests, there are loads of dungeons, raids, primal fights and even PVP.You definately will not get bored playing this game. You'll always find yourself being able to do something. You might wanna go kill things to level up, run a dungeon, go and explore the world or sit down by a lake and do some fishing.The choice is yours, Adventurer ;)

content:
7, 2015
I will update this review probably once I reach 1000+ hours. My hours are 160 at the time of this review.So you probably want a review from someone who doesn't play MMOs, or at least, didn't. I played Runescape back in 2007 with some friends. That was the only MMO I've ever played. FFXIV was still easy to learn, and I just didn't feel a stranger at all. It's impossible to not enjoy this game unless you just hate MMO's, or are impatient.I bought this like a month ago and I just reached level 50 dragoon. It's all so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing. The story is incredible, the music is stunning, the art is amazing, graphics are ridiculously beautiful. The classes (fighting classes, crafting classes, and gathering classes) are all uniquely rewarding. With that said, you can literally play as ANY class in the entire game with a single character. Wanna be a gladiator? Equip a sword. Miner? Equip a pickaxe. Wanna just ♥♥♥♥in cook? Equip a skillet. The community is wonderful. I'm no veteran hence my hours played, but I'm in a great Free Company (like a clan in other games) with great players that make me feel at home.However, this is definitely not a game for everyone. It could be quite intimidating to the average casual gamer who doesn't understand the basic principles of most MMO games. This game requires quite a bit of your time and patience. So, I would absolutely recommend looking up gameplay videos to understand the combat system if you're really questioning this purchase.I guess the only downside is I wasted my entire summer on a single video game. In the real life that sucks, but in Eorzea, it has been so wonderful.

												IMPORTANT: If you buy the steam version of ARR every new expansion must be bought from steam, because steam and windows keys are different, BUT, if you buy the steam version on the Mogstation website (where you can manage your ff14 account) you get the option to buy time using your steam wallet (it takes you to the steamwebsite and it shows how much is going to cost using your currency)Review:Well...i never thought i was gonna be hooked with an MMO because of the story.....seriously, best godmman plot in an MMO, even some side stories unlock at the end of the basic story have incredible character development.Also, if i ever got bored playing a class, all i had to do is change my weapon and im done, which in my opinion is the best idea ever, since the worst thing an mmo can have is repetition, so being able to change classes whenever i want is the best, hell they even have a unique story for every basic class and its respective Job upgrade.

content:
er 31, 2016
												This is a game that I was unsure whether or not I would be able to get into it at first.  However, once I starting playing and created my character, I was in for a treat.  Many people and news outlets have said how terrible 1.0 was and that a completely new team at Square Enix was formed to create this game.  This game was even created from the ground up since there was no way to fix the original due to outdated code and other factors.  This game was very worthy of my time and still is.  The combat is very fluid, the different zones that you visit are all unique and have some factors that make it stand out  the various dungeons and trials that you do with other players are all very fun, this game is cross platform between PC, PS3, and PS4 players meaning that regardless of platfrom, you are all playing with each other, the endgame gives you something to do with more harder dungeons, trials, and raids,  and the story in this game is probably one of the most interesting stories that is part of a Final Fantasy game.If you are still unsure whether or not you should invest some time in this game, there is a 15 day free trial that you can try out.

er 31, 2016
												This is a game that I was unsure whether or not I would be able to get into it at first.  However, once I starting playing and created my character, I was in for a treat.  Many people and news outlets have said how terrible 1.0 was and that a completely new team at Square Enix was formed to create this game.  This game was even created from the ground up since there was no way to fix the original due to outdated code and other factors.  This game was very worthy of my time and still is.  The combat is very fluid, the different zones that you visit are all unique and have some factors that make it stand out  the various dungeons and trials that you do with other players are all very fun, this game is cross platform between PC, PS3, and PS4 players meaning that regardless of platfrom, you are all playing with each other, the endgame gives you something to do with more harder dungeons, trials, and raids,  and the story in this game is probably one of the most interesting stories that is part of a Final Fantasy game.If you are still unsure whether or not you should invest some time in this game, there is a 15 day free trial that you can try out.

content:
ry 28
												This game is literally the best MMO I ever played. I bought it while on sale during christmas days and not a day has passed since where I haven't played. The character creation has not as many options as others,but still enough to customize a decent character. The monthly fee for playing (13€) us worth paying. There's a lot to do and discover: One character can have all classes and jobs,there's no need for an endless character list. Also the character is perfectly integrated in cutscenes and the english translation of the story is well-made aswell as the translation for other stuff (e. g. open world events [FATEs]). Also the game has a beautiful world graphic wise,it just feels good to walk/mount through.Every area has it's own style.Gameplaywise it's the basic MMO thing: you use your skills and your chara does autoattacks,but every class is made interesting with it's own features. For example Conjurer (cleric): They have a skill wich switches their healingstat with their magdmg stat and increases magdmg by 10%/reduces healing by 20%,wich makes them great to play solo,unlike in other MMOs. Also the NPC-Mentors of all classes are vbery memorable and characteristic,the dialogues all are worth reading.Conclusion:This game is worth it. Once you start playing it,you will be able to feel how much love and detail was put into the game (except that long hair still glitches through some clothing),in music,dialogues,the landscapes and also the story.And you will learn how to love and hate characters and bosses at the same time.

content:
er 28, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is, without a doubt, the best MMO I have had the joy of playing. Of course, I grew up on Free to Plays that bombarded you with microtransactions everywhere you turned, and perhaps it's simply the feel of a clean  'I know exactly what I'm paying for' MMO that makes me love it so much.The dungeon runs are smooth, and every single party I've been in has worked extremely well together. The only quip here I might have is how long some queues take, but if you're in a Free Company, chances are you'll have at least one person there to wait with you- which speeds things up considerably, might I add. Even when I was in a dungeon queue for over an hour, all I had to do was switch gear sets and work on my Blacksmithing. So really, I view the wait times as forcing me to get off my lazy ♥♥♥ and work on some more 'mundane' classes.The idea of being able to play literally every class with /one/ character was, I'll admit, a little overwhelming at first. I didn't understand it all that well, but one of my companymates helped me out and showed me the ropes of juggling more than one class at a time. It's not that difficult once you're used to it.I can't say much for the soundtrack, as I listen to music of my own while playing, but I can say something about the graphics. They're absolutely stunning. Some of the best I've seen for an MMO, honestly. Even little things, down to how clothes and hair blow when the wind picks up, and how your clothes will actually change texture if it's raining to actually make them look wet.The community is actually surprisingly low-key, friendly, and helpful. I've only been playing for a few days and I've already made over 20 friends who've helped me understand quite a bit about the game. The only downside is I get a lot of whispers from spammers. They're easy enough to blacklist, which is another very well-implemented system, so it's not a big problem either.Overall, I just really enjoy XIV. Maybe I haven't been playing long enough to say my piece, but it's a stellar MMO and if you're a fan of either FF or MMOs you should definitely check it out. Make sure you have enough for the monthly fees, because it'll have you wasting all your money.

content:
y 12, 2015
												For some reason Steam doesn't show me playing when I launch the game, but I do have many hours into the game. Wanted to add that before my review.It's just really good. I don't really know what to say. Whether this be your first MMO or not, it's a completely solid experience. I was out of the MMO scene for a while, pretty much stopped playing them towards the end of WoW's Wrath of the Lich King expansion. Played plenty of others, was originally really hyped for Guild Wars 2 but felt it was entirely disappointing and the genre fell out of favor with me for a while. Never was the biggest Final Fantasy fan either, of those that I've played IX is my favorite, but I had some friends get into XIV when A Realm Reborn launched and decided to try it out. I absolutely adore this game. The content is good, the progression is well done, and all the jobs feel interesting and fun and what's better is that you can do every job on one character. It has the right amount of difficulty and accesibility. You don't have to do long attunement chores to get content unlocked. Instead, you unlock content through short quests, whether it be part of the main story or side quests, and it gives you a reason to be there by giving you lore behind the dungeons.There's also plenty of end game content, and the story continues even after you hit max level. You have hard modes of dungeons you've done previously, but it's not just new mechanics as they feel like whole new dungeons. Halatali Hard has you going a different route with whole new bosses as an example. You have two 24 man raids, Crystal Tower and Syrcus Tower, and the hardest content in the game is 8 man (Coil of Bahamut). You have the post-50 primals such as Ramuh or Shiva and hard modes of the pre-50 primals like Titan HM or Titan EX. It's a game with plenty of fun and interesting encounters, and with a new expansion coming out sometime in the spring you'll have even more to look forward to including new jobs, a new race, and more story. Not to mention other post-50 content like Hildibrand which is an awesome quest-line.If you're wanting to try it out but not sure, there is a trial and I recommend sticking with it until you get to Ifrit at around level 20. The story that leads you to Ifrit and as well as the fight itself is what made me really want to see more of the game. That isn't to say there's not some low points in the story, especially pre-50, but there's some great moments and it only gets better once you hit max level on your first job.XIV provides plenty for both the hardcore raider with hitting the Coil of Bahamut, or the more causual minded MMO player who just wants to chill with friends. Was game of the year last year for me, and will probably be again this year. At least a 9/10 in the MMO genre, and currently the best subscription based MMO on the market.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2015
												I played WoW for 6ish years on and off, and when I was gifted a subscription by my sister, who gave high praise of it, I I thought it couldn't play that differently. WoW set a very rigid image of how an MMO was set up to milk time whenever possible from the user to give the illusion of accomplishment. However, I began to notice very quickly that where WoW wasted your time, FFXIV ditched those gameplay mechanics and replaced it with something more sensable.First, I'll give you a brief look at classes, money, and travel. Travel first because its simple. Remember all those long flight times, and even with flying mounts it didn't compensate for having to traverse the continuous, no-loading-screen continents. In FFXIV you teleport to the zone and that's it, no fuss, maybe a little walking if your destination is in the back of zone.This ties directly into money, so that's next. In FFXIV quests actually give you some substantial amounts of money for getting everything you need from gear to materials for professions. However, repair costs ramp rather quickly, as do teleportation expenses, so part of managing your character becomes maintaining enough income to sustain everything you need. Daily quests and dungeon queues are actually important if you don't maintain any crafting/gathering skills, unlike WoW where they're a chore simply to improve a reputation with a side faction.Classes are completely different as well. Unlike WoW where you get locked into focusing on a class unless you want to start up a whole new character, and restricted to 2 professions, FFXIV puts no barriers in your way. One character can level to 50 on every tank, dps, healer, crafting and gathering profession, and there are economic and gameplay insentives for expanding your knowledge of the game with this. Every class/profession has 2-3 cross-class skills that can enchance the abilities of another, not just combat but also in professions. The more professions you level, the easier it becomes to be independant of their version of the Auction House, as well as make boatloads of money.Last, I guess I can put some facts down about differences in guilds and endgame. In WoW, you had to find a dedicated guild and organize parties yourself to complete 10 or 25 raids, which essentially the home to all the best-in-slot gear. They eventually added in a token system where hard 5 mans and the 10 mans would grant accumulative currency for buying equivalent or near-BiS items. However, you'd find yourself tediously working through a raid clear all week, and very rarely a boss would drop something useful to you (and you actually win the roll), making it akin to the lottery everytime you actually got something you needed. In FFXIV, they bipassed this by making the token gear the BiS in most or all cases. If your gear dropped in 4man dungeons you were always the only class that would be able to need on it, and even in the 8 or 24mans there would rarely be another class-mate (HEH).  Also, there's nothing particularly unique a dps brings to the table than another, same with tanks and healers. Some do things better than others, but the developers saw class balance as an important thing to accomplish, UNLIKE WOW. Holy ♥♥♥♥, just remembering how useless they would make certain classes from patch to patch is infuriating as I'm writing this. That doesn't happen in FFXIV, in fact, you can randomly queue for the endgame raids everyday, multiple times a day if you want. Farming those tokens is easy, and queues are generally short. The only weekly restriction is on the current endgame dungeon's loot, which is 1 drop a week.TL;DR: FFXIV doesn't waste your time, and seems more interested in enjoyable gameplay than epenis upgrades to flaunt over your fellow players that are more busy IRL.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 1, 2015
												Pros: - Intersting story that isn't hard to follow and has decently played out cutscenes.- Collision/Impact style based tab target, Not the usual tab target where you can clip through people/npc/enemies, It actually makes you dodge attacks and not just stand there bored pressing 1 , 2 , 3 repeatedly untill the mob dies like generic tab target games.- Brings back the old type of class systems where you can do everything on the one character, An aspect I personally love because it means you dont have to play through the same story over... and over... and over... to play the different types of classes available or master different professions - you only need the one character.- Game lets me be a Ninja Catgirl.Cons: - Pay to play.- Its still tab target.- No open world pvp/Very little pvp content.- Servers are pretty limited, Europe/Japan/NA.All in all its a good game, Probably not worth the full price unless you plan to dedicate your life to it, On special i'd definitely reccomend it, The amount of content you can do on your one character is staggering and i'd imagine it would take multiple months to get to that level so you wont be bored quickly.Take a week off work, Ignore your friends and social obligations and dive into the world of Eorzea, At the very least you'll leave with a miqo'te fetish.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
y 19, 2015
												Don't let my small game time dissuade you taking my review seriously, I have been playing since 1.0 and most of my logged hours are with the beta client which was patched to the retail client.Anyway not really a review, but this is hands-down the best subscription MMORPG currently on the market. It may feel strange to those who aren't familiar with the Final Fantasy franchise, but to those who are (or are familiar with the original version of FFXIV) this game is now a huge success, and it's not hard to see why.By adopting common traits found in modern MMORPGs, yet dousing it in Final Fantasy flavour, A Realm Reborn feels like an MMORPG while still feeling like a Final Fantasy game. Square Enix are committed to continually updating the game as well, with loaded content patches being released every three months since launch. I hope they continue this trend.Just be wary, you may not enjoy or appreciate the first 30 or so levels, but when you upgrade your class to a fully fledged job and can change jobs whenever you want (providing you are out of combat) and more importantly, when you experience the incredible amount of content that the endgame provides, you will realise that FFXIV is finally reaching the potential we all had hoped for.I can't wait for the first expansion this Spring.Goodbye real life.

content:
21, 2016
												Ignoring my playtime (I actually rebought the game on Steam, I'm sure I'd have upwards of a few hundred hours otherwise) this is one of the only MMOs I've been able to get into. It reminds me of the WoW glory days but it seems to have learnt from WoW's mistakes. HOWEVER, keep in mind it's practically a WoW clone in some regards. This is a very 'traditional' mmo. An excellent one, but it still isn't exactly gamebreaking innovative anywhere. You still have the old school action hotbar combat with tab targetting, you still work off an ability rotation, the holy trinity class system is here, etc.If you don't LIKE those systems, then this game probably isn't for you. If you're looking for an alternative to the giant that is WoW then this is an excellent choice. Personally as someone who LOVED Guild Wars 2 but was immensely bored by the lack of end game (And ♥♥♥♥ Anet's expansion and how they handled pricing) FFXIV was an extremely welcome sight. This game has some of my favorite raids and a seriously massive amount of end game content with lots more being added every few months. Even if you aren't a super hardcore MMO player I find the game excellent to revisit every few months just to check out the new content.

content:

												WARNING PLEASE READ:Save your soul if you tend to play this game and also make sure to put your girlfrind aside, your dog aside, your kids aside, your job aside and also the life you don't have aside as well.There are so many things about this game I love and I'm not even max level yet. This game is by far one of the best mmorpg games I've played for a PvE experence. The grind is a fun grind where you can sit back and have fun. Also this game is so well optimized where I could run it on my old GT 630 (I have a 970 now) on lowest settings and it would look like it was on high, plus there was hardly any lag (Besides the main square at limsa lominsa everything goes to hell) But the only downside is the amount you have to pay. It costs 155.88 US$ for 1 year of a subscription and that is a lot to pay for one game, not only that but the addons such as hevensword and to buy the game itself and if you want a good ceremony of eternal bonding deal and also more retainers the money just keeps adding up.Overall its a 7.5/10]=-=[Pros]=-=[Smoothe, stunning gameplaycinematic cutscenes are long and gratifyingwonderful community (Depending on the server you are on I am in Brynhildr)enticing end game gear that is worth working up tosemiregular updates with a good amount of content in each realeaseA fun grind instead of boring.Amazing charatcer creation (Usually takes me an hour making my charater)you can be a neko.]=-=[Cons]=-=[Payment is a ♥♥♥♥♥Pray to your one and only RNGodThe Market Board is VERY franticSomewhat limited invortory space.~Player of the game~And finally a duengeon rant:If you are a DPS queueing for a duengeon you better watch a movie and go pick corn out of your local corn feild, peal the corn, dry the cernals out and after a while then cook the corn cernals into popcorn then you want to make your own caramel dressing to put over that popcorn to cure your salty soul and soon after when you finally sit down to enjoy your movie you can finally relax of the hard working labor you just did to make your popcorn and eat it. Once you get back to your computer or playstation you will finally be ready to enter your duengeon. (This has been an over dramatic decription of how long it takes and how I feel when I have to solo duengeons as a DPS)

content:
7, 2015
												I'm not an MMO player, but I love FInal Fantasy. And that's what drew me to play this game after hearing that the story and music were the best in the FF series in a decade. Having beaten the story up to the end of Heavensward, I can confirm that is true. Although the gameplay is classic MMO, the atmosphere, music and story all bring back memories of the Final Fantasy series. The story will have multiple twists and turns and will keep you wanting to know what happens next. The Heavensward expansion is especially good with this imo. To note though, because it is an MMO, there ARE portions of the main story questline that are filled with filler quests and fetch quests. They definitely felt dull, and feel like Square just put them in to increase the amount of "content" in the main story when they didn't need to. Again, the Heavensward expansion did not have that. The main culprit is the post-ARR, patch 2.1-2.4 content.The game has some of best FF music in awhile, enough to make me seriously want the soundtrack. There are a lot of memorable area/city music and battle/boss themes. The world and areas are another strength. There are many varied locations in the world, and some beautiful scenes. The lore is extensive, and I can't wait till they open up even more of the world. There is so much left unexplored in the world and story (that will most likely be explored in future content).In terms of end game content, the constant updates gives you enough things to do throughout even if it is possible to "binge" through all of it fairly quickly. Raids are fun and challenging.In terms of an MMO game, there isn't too much innovation, but FFXIV:ARR executes everything really well and hence its status as the foremost MMO rival to WoW.

content:
y 19, 2015
												Don't let my small game time dissuade you taking my review seriously, I have been playing since 1.0 and most of my logged hours are with the beta client which was patched to the retail client.Anyway not really a review, but this is hands-down the best subscription MMORPG currently on the market. It may feel strange to those who aren't familiar with the Final Fantasy franchise, but to those who are (or are familiar with the original version of FFXIV) this game is now a huge success, and it's not hard to see why.By adopting common traits found in modern MMORPGs, yet dousing it in Final Fantasy flavour, A Realm Reborn feels like an MMORPG while still feeling like a Final Fantasy game. Square Enix are committed to continually updating the game as well, with loaded content patches being released every three months since launch. I hope they continue this trend.Just be wary, you may not enjoy or appreciate the first 30 or so levels, but when you upgrade your class to a fully fledged job and can change jobs whenever you want (providing you are out of combat) and more importantly, when you experience the incredible amount of content that the endgame provides, you will realise that FFXIV is finally reaching the potential we all had hoped for.I can't wait for the first expansion this Spring.Goodbye real life.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2015
												I played WoW for 6ish years on and off, and when I was gifted a subscription by my sister, who gave high praise of it, I I thought it couldn't play that differently. WoW set a very rigid image of how an MMO was set up to milk time whenever possible from the user to give the illusion of accomplishment. However, I began to notice very quickly that where WoW wasted your time, FFXIV ditched those gameplay mechanics and replaced it with something more sensable.First, I'll give you a brief look at classes, money, and travel. Travel first because its simple. Remember all those long flight times, and even with flying mounts it didn't compensate for having to traverse the continuous, no-loading-screen continents. In FFXIV you teleport to the zone and that's it, no fuss, maybe a little walking if your destination is in the back of zone.This ties directly into money, so that's next. In FFXIV quests actually give you some substantial amounts of money for getting everything you need from gear to materials for professions. However, repair costs ramp rather quickly, as do teleportation expenses, so part of managing your character becomes maintaining enough income to sustain everything you need. Daily quests and dungeon queues are actually important if you don't maintain any crafting/gathering skills, unlike WoW where they're a chore simply to improve a reputation with a side faction.Classes are completely different as well. Unlike WoW where you get locked into focusing on a class unless you want to start up a whole new character, and restricted to 2 professions, FFXIV puts no barriers in your way. One character can level to 50 on every tank, dps, healer, crafting and gathering profession, and there are economic and gameplay insentives for expanding your knowledge of the game with this. Every class/profession has 2-3 cross-class skills that can enchance the abilities of another, not just combat but also in professions. The more professions you level, the easier it becomes to be independant of their version of the Auction House, as well as make boatloads of money.Last, I guess I can put some facts down about differences in guilds and endgame. In WoW, you had to find a dedicated guild and organize parties yourself to complete 10 or 25 raids, which essentially the home to all the best-in-slot gear. They eventually added in a token system where hard 5 mans and the 10 mans would grant accumulative currency for buying equivalent or near-BiS items. However, you'd find yourself tediously working through a raid clear all week, and very rarely a boss would drop something useful to you (and you actually win the roll), making it akin to the lottery everytime you actually got something you needed. In FFXIV, they bipassed this by making the token gear the BiS in most or all cases. If your gear dropped in 4man dungeons you were always the only class that would be able to need on it, and even in the 8 or 24mans there would rarely be another class-mate (HEH).  Also, there's nothing particularly unique a dps brings to the table than another, same with tanks and healers. Some do things better than others, but the developers saw class balance as an important thing to accomplish, UNLIKE WOW. Holy ♥♥♥♥, just remembering how useless they would make certain classes from patch to patch is infuriating as I'm writing this. That doesn't happen in FFXIV, in fact, you can randomly queue for the endgame raids everyday, multiple times a day if you want. Farming those tokens is easy, and queues are generally short. The only weekly restriction is on the current endgame dungeon's loot, which is 1 drop a week.TL;DR: FFXIV doesn't waste your time, and seems more interested in enjoyable gameplay than epenis upgrades to flaunt over your fellow players that are more busy IRL.

content:
, 2015
												This game is an overall amazing and stunning MMO to play and my favorite yet. It is very rare to find an MMO that just completely nails so many amazing features at once. This game has a very nice social aspect to it with a wide variety of emotes, housing, mini games, guilds and more that just allow the very large player base to interact like few other MMOs. This game creates a wonderful atmosphere with it's visually stunning graphic style and quality. It also features one of the hardest sets of raid content I have ever experienced. The game has a large variety of raids and dungeons at varying difficulties that allow for both casual and hard core raiders to enjoy themselves. The easier raids are just slightly more mechanically driven than WoW's Raid Finder while the highest tier of raids take more skill than almost any MMO I have played. This game almost has it all for an amazing target based MMO with amazing developers that literally took a dying game and turned it into my favorite MMO to date. I highly recommend this game to any MMO fan.
