content:
y 1, 2015
												I can't believe I haven't reviewed this yet, but my play time should speak for itself. Do not confuse this game with the atrocity that was XIV 1.0. Square Enix literally dropped a Bahamut meteor on that game to crash the servers and reimagine it as the beautiful experience it is today. Graphics are top-notch, at least if you have a decent enough rig to play it on high quality. The community overall is incredible, though your experience will vary by server, play times, and free company allegiance (FFXIV's version of guilds). Inter-played cooperation is mandatory for endgame content, and the game sets you up very nicely to learn your chosen role well by level 50. And then if you decide you don't like that role... all you have to do is switch weapons to a different class and try again.Hallelujah, no more multiple characters to play multiple classes; I'm looking at you, WoW. Final Fantasy's job system makes it totally feasible to level every class to cap without having to jam up a server with 10 different characters, and you might be surprised by the number of people that do exactly that. Even the crafting system is much more interactive than others I've tried, and it's the crafters and gatherers that drive the game's economy. The sense of community is all-inclusive with plenty of experienced players willing to lend a hand to upstarts, though of course don't expect everyone to be this way. Like any game, this one has its elitists but the funny part is that some of those still haven't beaten the last raid.The best pieces of advice I can give you are these:1) If you buy the game, give it until around level 30 to start getting truly fun. That's where you unlock your job (as opposed to your class), earning you extra abilities, and it's where the dungeons start to get really fun.2) Once you hit level 50, there is a HUGE learning curve jump when you get to extreme mode primals and the Coils of Bahamut. That's not to say these things are impassable, but you will have to buckle down and learn the mechanics rather than expecting a clear on your first try.3) If you get lost, use the /sh shout function in chat. Talk to someone! I can almost guarantee there will be someone around to lend a helping hand.4) Listen when people give you advice. 90% of the time, they say it because they want to help improve their server's experience, not because they think you're a n00b that sux.5) If you're new to the game and chose the Brynhildr server, hit up Taliel Sicilian. ;)

ry 1, 2015
												Pros: - Intersting story that isn't hard to follow and has decently played out cutscenes.- Collision/Impact style based tab target, Not the usual tab target where you can clip through people/npc/enemies, It actually makes you dodge attacks and not just stand there bored pressing 1 , 2 , 3 repeatedly untill the mob dies like generic tab target games.- Brings back the old type of class systems where you can do everything on the one character, An aspect I personally love because it means you dont have to play through the same story over... and over... and over... to play the different types of classes available or master different professions - you only need the one character.- Game lets me be a Ninja Catgirl.Cons: - Pay to play.- Its still tab target.- No open world pvp/Very little pvp content.- Servers are pretty limited, Europe/Japan/NA.All in all its a good game, Probably not worth the full price unless you plan to dedicate your life to it, On special i'd definitely reccomend it, The amount of content you can do on your one character is staggering and i'd imagine it would take multiple months to get to that level so you wont be bored quickly.Take a week off work, Ignore your friends and social obligations and dive into the world of Eorzea, At the very least you'll leave with a miqo'te fetish.

content:
er 28, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is, without a doubt, the best MMO I have had the joy of playing. Of course, I grew up on Free to Plays that bombarded you with microtransactions everywhere you turned, and perhaps it's simply the feel of a clean  'I know exactly what I'm paying for' MMO that makes me love it so much.The dungeon runs are smooth, and every single party I've been in has worked extremely well together. The only quip here I might have is how long some queues take, but if you're in a Free Company, chances are you'll have at least one person there to wait with you- which speeds things up considerably, might I add. Even when I was in a dungeon queue for over an hour, all I had to do was switch gear sets and work on my Blacksmithing. So really, I view the wait times as forcing me to get off my lazy ♥♥♥ and work on some more 'mundane' classes.The idea of being able to play literally every class with /one/ character was, I'll admit, a little overwhelming at first. I didn't understand it all that well, but one of my companymates helped me out and showed me the ropes of juggling more than one class at a time. It's not that difficult once you're used to it.I can't say much for the soundtrack, as I listen to music of my own while playing, but I can say something about the graphics. They're absolutely stunning. Some of the best I've seen for an MMO, honestly. Even little things, down to how clothes and hair blow when the wind picks up, and how your clothes will actually change texture if it's raining to actually make them look wet.The community is actually surprisingly low-key, friendly, and helpful. I've only been playing for a few days and I've already made over 20 friends who've helped me understand quite a bit about the game. The only downside is I get a lot of whispers from spammers. They're easy enough to blacklist, which is another very well-implemented system, so it's not a big problem either.Overall, I just really enjoy XIV. Maybe I haven't been playing long enough to say my piece, but it's a stellar MMO and if you're a fan of either FF or MMOs you should definitely check it out. Make sure you have enough for the monthly fees, because it'll have you wasting all your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
y 12, 2015
												For some reason Steam doesn't show me playing when I launch the game, but I do have many hours into the game. Wanted to add that before my review.It's just really good. I don't really know what to say. Whether this be your first MMO or not, it's a completely solid experience. I was out of the MMO scene for a while, pretty much stopped playing them towards the end of WoW's Wrath of the Lich King expansion. Played plenty of others, was originally really hyped for Guild Wars 2 but felt it was entirely disappointing and the genre fell out of favor with me for a while. Never was the biggest Final Fantasy fan either, of those that I've played IX is my favorite, but I had some friends get into XIV when A Realm Reborn launched and decided to try it out. I absolutely adore this game. The content is good, the progression is well done, and all the jobs feel interesting and fun and what's better is that you can do every job on one character. It has the right amount of difficulty and accesibility. You don't have to do long attunement chores to get content unlocked. Instead, you unlock content through short quests, whether it be part of the main story or side quests, and it gives you a reason to be there by giving you lore behind the dungeons.There's also plenty of end game content, and the story continues even after you hit max level. You have hard modes of dungeons you've done previously, but it's not just new mechanics as they feel like whole new dungeons. Halatali Hard has you going a different route with whole new bosses as an example. You have two 24 man raids, Crystal Tower and Syrcus Tower, and the hardest content in the game is 8 man (Coil of Bahamut). You have the post-50 primals such as Ramuh or Shiva and hard modes of the pre-50 primals like Titan HM or Titan EX. It's a game with plenty of fun and interesting encounters, and with a new expansion coming out sometime in the spring you'll have even more to look forward to including new jobs, a new race, and more story. Not to mention other post-50 content like Hildibrand which is an awesome quest-line.If you're wanting to try it out but not sure, there is a trial and I recommend sticking with it until you get to Ifrit at around level 20. The story that leads you to Ifrit and as well as the fight itself is what made me really want to see more of the game. That isn't to say there's not some low points in the story, especially pre-50, but there's some great moments and it only gets better once you hit max level on your first job.XIV provides plenty for both the hardcore raider with hitting the Coil of Bahamut, or the more causual minded MMO player who just wants to chill with friends. Was game of the year last year for me, and will probably be again this year. At least a 9/10 in the MMO genre, and currently the best subscription based MMO on the market.

												It's funny that almost everyone I've met has been eager to help and once in two dungeons there has always been 1-3 people that wanted to chat with me during the whole runs. I currently have over 140 hours in to the game and there has been only 1 person acting bad towards me and that was in potd when I was playing with a friend in matched party and I wanted to clear this one room and one of the randoms started to curse and act negative towards me. Few minutes later he left us alone there, which made us need to restart that run again because there was no way to take the enemies down with the classes we had. I'm currently around the end of Astral questline, have bought heavensward which I actually bought after 1 week in to the game. I like the game alot, the easy class swap method is great and interesting. There are it's own faults in it though. The Waking Sands area's story quests were a bit irritating to complete and many other places, because they had so many repetive "go talk to thess guys in these cities and come back here 50 times" quests. The duty finder sometimes takes around 9-13 minutes to find enough people even though the game informs you that it should usually take 5minutes at max to find all people. There are also few un-important instances in the game, for example Waking Sands's and Raising Stone's office where Minfina is is pretty useless. Haven't touched pvp yet so can't say anything about it yet. It was a shame that the base game didn't have a to handed swordsman class which is the main reason I bought heavensward actually. But overall it's a pretty good game and I'll gladly get the stormblood expansion when It comes out.

content:
ry 14
												People complaining about how this game has a subscription service.People call this game pay to win, its pay to play. There's a difference.Pay to win is the ability to pay for items or in-game currency to gain an advantage over players.Pay to play is a subscription service to keep the game running and keep updates rolling out. If the company didn't make any profit off of this, they would most likely abandon it. As you can see, hundreds of thousands of people don't play this, but it still has an active community.If you complain about this game not being free, complain about World of Warcraft as well, one of the most popular, if not THE most popular mmo out there.I would recommend the game to people who do like WoW, but dislike the 2002 graphics.Play with friends, or find a free company. Community is great.Gameplay : The game has a similar if not identical gameplay system to World of Warcraft. There is a high variety in classes you can choose from, that fits your playstyle.The game has good tutorials that you can use that can be accessed at anytime for reference.If you can't find out how to do something, join a guild, or ask a friend and ask.Or google it.Google exists.Grinding mobs isn't really a thing. Just do leveling roulette and do a dungeon for your level.Classes: Make a character, pick a class, switch whenever.You can change from a gladiator to a conjurer to a pugilist at anytime. Of course you can't do it in combat or in a dungeon, but you can still try out everything.Gear : Main quest should supply you with the gear you need. If not, buy it off the market. If you're poor, run dungeons and get gear from there.Staff and Support : You can enter a support ticket for any bugs or questions that are not found in the FAQ. The FAQ also acts as a tutorial when you can't find out something. Otherwise google it.Google exists.They usually respond within a couple hours or a day, from my experience.Story : So much story. So much. This game is not enjoyable if you don't pay attention to the story. You will end up not knowing what you are even doing. Basically saying, don't rush the game.Bad ♥♥♥♥ : Boring without friends.Story can get boring.Everything can get boring.The game thrives on community and pretty features.You can expect to find me in the Primal data center in Malboro under the name Naomi Sato.Oh you get a 30 day trial which you can basically level up to the max level in a good amount of time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
6, 2015
												This is a beautiful, immersive and meticulously detailed game, the amazing gameplay of which will reel in franchise fans and newcomers alike. While Final Fantasy XIV is unlike its single player predecessors, the lore recognizeable by the long time FF fans creates a story with depth and character interactions generally forgotton by MMO creators. As such, the attention to detail regarding idiosyncracies of certain characters is conveyed through their speech, and this attention to detail extends to the environment as well. Small things that one would barely notice can be found in the game, such as the pattern of shadow created by light shining through a grate, as well as that shadow adjusting alongside the in game time of day; the stitching on armors and clothing, right down to the shadows created by them on the player; and many more details that add to the game's wonderful environment.Within this environment is gameplay that is executed uniquely, and superbly. Skills operate in a style familiar to MMO players, with a relatively short global cooldown, and individual skill cooldowns which vary depending on the strength and usefulness of the skill. Combat utilizes a TP, similar to a stamina system, while magic utilizes the classic MP. Some magic skills of which rely on a casting time, which occurs at the same time as the global cooldown, making casting fluent yet balanced. Skills can be clicked, hotkeyed, setup through user macros, and so forth. The combat truly appeals to every style of play, as well as every player through its broad range of classic Final Fantasy jobs that players can quest as.The questing is reminiscent of other MMOs, and yet the game approaches these concepts in ways that makes them less of a grind than they could be. Rather than the traditional, "Kill 50 of this monster," or ,"Gather 30 of this material," the quests bring these numbers down to 5s and 3s, which allows the player to take the time to actually understand WHY they are doing what they are doing.Furthermore, many players will actually be ABLE to do what they want to be doing, for the game has been optimized wonderfully. Areas are divided by loading zones, but the transition between these is so fluent and quick that it took me this long to even remember they were there. With easy to use presets such as "High end PC" or "Low end laptop," adjusting settings is user friendly. If you would like to adjust things yourself, there is of course an option for custom settings.Yet what truly sold me on the game, what I believe to be the greatest of its qualities, is the job change system. Many MMOs have you make one character, choose one class or destiny for them, and that's that. You're either forced to pay for some sort of reset, make a new character, completely start over or combinations of the above. NOT in Final Fantasy XIV. By simply equipping a new weapon, your stats, gear, abilities, everything switches to the role that weapon relates to, and you can head back to lower level areas to train yourself anew. This is done WITHOUT losing any of your previous progress. In fact certain jobs can use abilities learned from other classes, and often need to in order to reach their full potential. The best part is that no mistakes can be made with this system. There is no "woops, you didn't train your warrior class so your strength is too low," there is some minor ability point allocation, but this is done easily and can easily be reversed. A single character can serve you for every adventure, and as such, the character creation allows you to bring that perfect character to life.One truly could spend a few hours just in the character creator, detailing everything from the muscularity of your character, to their eye color, to the color of the tips of their hair vs the rest of their hair, etcetera, etcetera. There are four basic races each with two deviations in appeance to begin with, and the next perk that comes along is that you don't have to worry about "which race has the best looking armor." Armor is purely based on class, scales based on size, and doesn't vary from race to race, only between genders. There exists a range of emotions to emulate via these characters in game, if roleplay at all interests you, and the community has considerably less..."game challenged" players than other MMOs.Worth every cent of the subscription fee, Final Fantasy XIV is a game whose developers LISTEN to their community (see the 2.1 Patch) and who truly care about their game. The friendly community, and the freedom and beauty offered by the environment will leave you wondering why you didn't play this game all along.

content:
y 30, 2016
												They really improved this game- and I love that I can choose to play the same character on PC or PS4 depending on which I'd rather be on at the moment (unrelated to the PC version, but the controls work very well on PS4).It has a bit of a slow pace, and of course it's an MMO so there's grinding involved- but the game looks good, is easy to use and unlike FFXI you can solo your way through anything even if you're not a great player, while also making it easy and rewarding to group up both for dungeons and world events.It has pretty much every feature you'd expect for a modern MMO, an involving story, variety to do, and it has likely the best online community of the AAA group.You won't feel any adrenaline playing this game, but if you're looking for something relaxing it's perfect. Need a break from enemies? There's entire classes devoted to gathering and crafting you can switch to on the fly (one character can have every single class, almost like specs in another game with no respec cost). There's many mini games, even an entire zone dedicated solely to mini games (the Gold Saucer behaves much like the one in FFVII).Gathering professions are considerably more involving than other games; and even fishing's enjoyable (though, a bit limited- take in small doses).The game looks and sounds nice, but some of the voice acting is... questionable. Also, there's still a sub fee.That said- for a mainstream MMO it's one of the best, and I'm hard pressed to think of one that has the same general appeal for the f2p. Sides, a month of gameplay for an hour's work at minimum wage, or two starbucks coffees, has never seemed unreasonable to me.

content:
ry 15
												TL;DR - I am confident this is the best MMO out there, especially for a Final Fantasy fan.By far my favourite MMO of all the many ones I've played in the past. What put me off in MMOs has been worked on in this game, such as an engaging, worthwhile story, a decent sense of progression, and the greatest thing of all, being able to be all classes on one character. It has content for both casual and hardcore players, plenty of mini games and collectables, such as mounts and pets (minions, which have their own RTS mini-game now). Crafting/gathering classes are actually extremely fun for the first time in an MMO for me, so give those a shot for sure. The game can be grindy at times, but it isn't ball-achingly dull like most games. I've been subsribed for almost a year, I've taken a year break, but now I am back into it and I plan on staying for years to come. For the first time in any MMO, I've truly felt the urge to keep coming back.If you plan on playing this game, I highly suggest trying to get yourself on Gilgamesh (at certain times in the day, off-peak hours when the server isn't full and people delete characters), under the Aether data center (NA). From what I've heard, it's the place to be, and the server to get stuff done later on in the game. I moved here from an EU server and have had no lag issues whatsoever, only ones to blame on my internet.PS: Expect super over the top boss fights that the FF series is known for. A lot of them are visually stunning, it's almost distracting how amazing some of the visuals are in this game.

Delightful?The game is exceptionally good for MMORPGs, and as well as having good story and mechanics it has a mature and generally friendly community who partake in serious role-play that some servers are dedicated to. Offers a huge amount of things players can do (Such as crafting, fishing and similar tasks) and encourages players to engage in Jolly co-operation with dungeons and things of the sort. Worth the money, but it requires about £8.99 / 12.99 € in subscription fees every month so while you will only get players willing to pay a decent amount of cash to play this, a lot of players are unable to play because of this. The game works very well in cohesion with steam, despite most in-game purchases and subscription payment going on at their own website they still accept steam wallet as payment. It looks beautiful and is a somewhat relaxing game to play imo, I would highly suggest giving it a try since they do offer a Free Trial[www.ffxiv-freetrial.com]. Allows you to download the demo on steam.

content:
21, 2014
												As an avid MMO player, I came into Final Fantasy XIV with mixed expectations.  I had friends who had played before ARR and I had friends who had played after the release.   While one set said the game had been terrible and they were never touching it again, those who played after ARR's release said that the game was well worth the monthly sub.   Deciding to see for myself; I, my significant other, and our friends decided to buy the game and check it out.   It suffices to say, I was not disappointed.FFXIV: ARR takes points from all current MMO's, polishes them, and then puts them on a pedestal for all their players to view and enjoy.   I've played GW2, WoW, RIFT, Terra, and SW:TOR, but nothing comes close to the pure satisfaction of embracing a truly well made Final Fantasy MMORPG.   FFXIV: ARR has recovered from all of it's mistakes in the past, to bring out a wonderful game that sticks true to it's Final Fantasy roots and will leave you begging for more.From the game soundtrack to the storyline, FFXIV: ARR has shown itself as a competitor to take place among the "legends" of the MMO industry.  The Dungeons are paced wonderfully, and show challenge when you need it, the quests are fulfilling and give you a sense of purpose within the game and objectives like FATE's and Guildhests give players exactly what they need; smooth enjoyable fun.From furthering yourself in crafting items and gear, to fighting monsters and bosses, each task takes an enjoyable amount of time.  Having only put in about 75 hours, I've found myself enthralled by  the depth of each action, and the amount of polish that has gone into the game to make it the work of art that it is now. + Great Storyline.+ Battle system is enjoyable.+ Wonderful music.+ Enjoyable community.+ Smooth gameplay.10/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
10, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV: A realm reborn is a really fun MMO. Being a WoW player from late vanilla and jumped to GW2 but got bored from it after a couple of weeks later when it was released and then jumped to Final Fantasy XIV: A realm reborn when it came to steam.I can say that i have more fun playing this MMO then when i playing GW2 and what WoW is becoming today.To be honest i never played a Final Fantasy from the main series before but did played some DS spinoff games and came to this game and the main series as a stranger but i always wanted to try out a FF game from the main series. From have completed the main story in this MMo i think i can make a review of this game.The first thing you should know is that if you were expecting a different MMO then World of Warcraft you gonna be disapointed but if you liked WoW from what it is you can feel a bit comfort here. You got your Kill X creatures and Collect Y things and also some talk to NPC quests but the game does not take the amount you need kill or collect as crazy as most MMo's. At later levels you mostly need to kill like 6-10 while at early levels not even more then 3. Also this game has just like WoW the Holy trinity (Tank,DPS and Healer) where also you can also play dungeons with people from other servers. But unlike WoW the normal instances are 4 man and the bigger instances 8 man but you also got a 24 man raid.One of the key differences from WoW is that you can change to every class in the game on 1 character meaning that you dont have to make alts. I personally like this a lot and you can also be every gathering and crafting class aswell. if you level more classes you can even share some of the skills they have with other classes but not all of them, Kinda replaces the game from having no talent tree or talent skills.The game does have a story and you progress through it by completing story quests. The game kinda forces you to follow the story quests because most of the game features are only unlocked by doing these quest making the first levels from 1 - 30 on your first class a long tutorial but after that games opens more up and the game does not really feel that slow. The game does feel a bit slow on every class first levels but as you go on the class becomes a lot more intresting.The game also have guilds but here they are called Free Company's in this game but as you go through the story you also need to choose a Nations Grand Company wich you discover more from as you go on with the game.Lastly if you are more of a PVP person you gonna also gonna be a bit disapointed because right now the only PVP is a 4vs4 Arena battle like in WoW and there is no way to duel people in the world and Open pvp is also not in the game.So that kinda concludes my review on this game. if i tell about everything then this review goes out of hand. Overall i really like this MMO and wishes it to even improve more in the future. And i cant wait to do all the end game content now that i completed the main story but to be honest the story does go even further after you completed the real main story of the game. If you are unsure if you can run this game you can download a benchmark from the official site of the game where you can also Create a character beforehand so you dont have to that when you buyed the game and the benchmark is free.

If there was one thing I could go back and change, it would be a different starting class for my own character.

												The graphics are beautiful, the combat is tight and the pve content is all in all extremely enjoyable. If you're new to the Final Fantasy world or an old fan boy like myself, you would truly enjoy everything this game has to offer. The only drawback I have with this game is the pvp. It needs fine tuning and the battles are completely unbalanced. You have to go in with a cookie cutter group. Pugs are usually cannon fodder in pvp.My favorite aspect of this game is the job system. You have several base classes in which you will later combine to create an advanced class. Some classes can cross abilities. For example: My Black Mage can use some of my Archers abilities or buffs. The cross platform is fantastic as well since I can play with friends who prefer to play on their PS3's. This game has plenty to offer for every type of gamer.

content:
26, 2014
												This game is not just a fantastic MMO. It is a fantastic Final Fantasy game. It captures the essence of the franchise very well. The music is superb and the graphics are top notch. And the game is BEYOND addicting. At the time of writing this review I have 35 hours in on it and have barely even scratched the surface of the game, and that is being generous. I can't imagine how long it would take to do everything. Thousands of hours. It streamlines the whole finding a party or group thing which was usually my least favorite thing about an MMO. Because I don't like the hassle of trying to get a group together. But FF14 automates this and it becomes as simple as popping into a Call of Duty match. It makes dungeon crawling feel like pick-up matches that require very little set-up. And that is THE quality about the game that makes it near perfect for me. I highly encouage anybody who is a fan of similar games to pick this up. By far the best MMO I've ever played. Which for reference the otheres I've played are Everquest, Everquest 2, and Guild Wars 2.

content:
, 2014
												Owned it for just over 2 weeks, and got up to level 20 with my main character.The style really does make it feel like a Final Fantasy game. From the music the moment the game loads, to the style of clothing, to classic creatures such as chocobos and moogles.What also helps make the game different compared to some other MMORPGs is that your class changes simply from switching out your main weapon. This is for combat and non-combat classes. All gear has a level limit which is determined by the class, but some may also be stricted to specific classes, preventing your level 1 Marauder running around in level 50 Lancer gear, or even the other way around.I still need to decide if I will be continuing this after my initial subscription expires, but currently it is optimistic :)

content:
4, 2014
												This game, like other MMOs, is deeply addictive. While I don't like games that involve too much grinding, Final Fantasy XIV has some fun mobs and dungeon-like events called FATEs that make leveling up your character fun rather than a chore.The graphics are beautiful, and exploring the game is a joy, especially once you play long enough to get a chocobo!With emotes, it's possible to role-play within the game if you want, but it's not necessary. There's a little less player interaction in chat that I'd like, but FFXIV forces you to play with other people via it's four- and eight-person story-based dungeons. It's a crapshoot as to whether you'll get paired up with good folks, but it definitely keeps you on your toes.All and all, I dig it. I'm about halfway through the story right now, and I like it an awful lot.

content:
30, 2014
												I remember playing FFXI for hours on end, day after day until SE announced FFXIV. Then, after waiting for the new game to come out, I couldn't wait to delve into the game. Boy, was I disappointed. So were a lot of people. Thankfully, SE listened and completely redesigned FFXIV into FFXIV: ARR. This is what I was hoping for the first time around. It plays enough like FFXI to give you warm fuzzies remembering bygone days, while being different enough to stand on its own in the FF series. I don't write recommendations for games often unless I really enjoy playing them. This is one game I can see myself playing for 200+ hours with ease without  growing tired of the game.

content:
7, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV is a beautiful game. The world design is wonderful, bringing life to new areas with each update. Dungeons are fun, interesting, and easy to get into. While there is a primary storyline, which you need to follow to unlock different aspects of the game, a lot of the side quest are unique and very filling. When I say filling, I simply mean that there is a lot of "stuff" to do. From slaughtering cacturns, to exploring new areas; each quest comes along with an interesting narrative.When I first started to play, I joined up with two pals from beta. They were significantly higher level than me, but were able to help me by lowering level to match my own. It really made the game more fun, and we got a few good laughs out of the dungeons. They had me join up in their Free Company, and now I've got lots of people to just hang out with and dungeon run with.Sure the cost isn't exactly cheap, but it is easily worth the monthly fee. Besides that, the only real issue is that even on the lowest graphics, it can still slow down a computer to a crawl.

content:
er 18, 2016
												Don't purchase this game from Steam as they will give you a "key" that will not allow you to login to the game or register the game successfully. Even after logging into the account management section for Square Enix, I still could not use the key that STEAM provided. I attempted to use it at the login screen that prompts use of the key, as well as the actual account management site AND Mogstation. So just when you sit down and have some free time to play, you actually have to contact Square Enix, sending and email, since their chat support is offline on Weekends, only to find that you have to wait for a response for more than a day or two. So at this point, when you do get a reply, its likely that you go back to work, bummed that you did not get a chance to play the game that you purchased, because STEAM and SQUARE ENIX can't get their crap together and communicate effectively and the ♥♥♥♥♥ gets passed along, down the hill to the customer, even after they are both multi-million dollar companies. That is laziness and stupidity in its finest. Rant over. P.S. Yes I have played FFIX on both PC and PS4, but took a break and decided to come back. What a waste of time, lol. Now for the review. It's a fun MMORPG, polished and continually improving. The map system still sucks, hopefully that will one day improve. Auto-Travel to quests would be nice, who knows, maybe they have that now. I don't know, I have not gotten back in the game yet. It still has cat-girls, so it is not all that bad, lol. The raids can be confusing, because of the crazy stuff going on in your team hot bars, so you just hope the DPS does not pull to much Aggro from the Tanks and the Healers do their part and everyone avoids dying horribly, you know the usual. That being said, don't expect more from this game than any other MMORPG, they are all clones, with different character models, animations and so on. There are some neat aspects that I believe they are learning from MMORPGS where you have to dodge, like Wildstar and Tera, but with a better story and player base. Get it. It's another pretty way to waste your time and meet others who are also wasting their time. Enjoy.

												There is a sharp divide in the player base. And it's the same divide you see over most of the internet and its associated communities: Half the players are awful bigots, white nationalists, and just generally gross people who sexually harass you, scream awful things in the shoutbox, or otherwise hound and harass you - these ones tend to be ex-WoW players, who joined once the game received high review praise.The rest, however, are lovely, kind people, who are pleasant to be around and always helpful.You will be pestered fairly frequently by goldfarmers trying to sell you in-game currency.The game is really good. The crafting system is a great. Battle system is solid. Party mechanics work well.You can literally try any class out with your character, just by equipping the necessary stuff.What stands out to me are little things, though - a rather robust character creation system, and the ability to dye most of the armour/equipment as you see fit.I just love things like that.Superfluous outfits are available too. And at lv.50, you obtain the ability to "glamour" your gear, to wear whatever you like without sacrificing stats.They have a system of marriage, with no restrictions on gender.Is this the first game with marriage equality? Because I can't think of any others.And that is just an awesome touch.So much love, Square-Enix.<3

content:
y 31, 2015
												After what i feel is a decent amount of hours played i feel i can write a review for this game..Lets start with its good points right? so here goes:-FF XIV is a top shelf MMORPG, yes your have to purchase the base game and yes it has a subscription fee 'sigh'... but after much deliberation and playing pretty much every other MMORPG.  My friend and I came to the conclusion that in F2P games the most important content and utilities where microtransaction BS! and you just cannot progress.. not to mention the most vile and hatred filled gamers your ever likely to come across.. So we gave this one a bash and in all honesty for what your paying its a bargain ! and no im not a fan boy.. im speaking the truth.... theres no locked content, everything is available as long as your able to progress that far and level up high enough to reach the locations.The graphics in this game are indeed Direct X9.0, but not by any means outdated ! i play many new games such as S.O.M / Farcry 4 etc... and this game is just as graphically pleasing if not a little easier on the eye as it all blends and texturises realy well. I run a Nvidia Geforce GT 740 2GB ddr5 card and get 40-50 fps all day long on the highest settings.The music is well composed and fits in well with the FF Franchise to those who are familiar, however just sometimes it can grate on you when your not expecting it or suddenly gets louder...Voice acting is some what scarce and when is around poorly dubbed but again something anyone familiar with FF will just over look this easily !As for content the game is full of it ! Theres never a dull moment, with 18 Classes to not only choose from but swap to at any given moment you can never get bored... ive litterally gone from fighting to keep my A** alive to suddenly sat on a stool fishing for sardines !! all in space of a few seconds. get bored of fishing easy ?? no problem grab a pickaxe and follow me ! we can go smash some crountry side open and mine for ore and composites !! whats that you say ?? cant find your pickaxe ?? not to worry my friend, lets go train to become a carpenter. We'll have you equipped in no time :D and how about after that we head to the Culinary Guild and cook us up a nice dinner of rabbit pie with white pearl chocolates for afterwards. Like a bit of slash and gash voilence ? become a Gladiator and Tank your way through whiles the Arcanist's and the Thurmatages watch your back with ranged magic and summons ...And of course need not to be mentioned really (ITS AN MMO ITS IN THE DESCRIPTION) you can do this with your friends 95% of the way through... of course i say 95% because during some Guild missions and Campaigns missions im afraid your going to have to go it alone !!! But the people of Eorzea are a nice Folk and are willing to help out anyone who just speaks up !! Help is out there people.. your never alone here :D FF XIV is Cross-Platform compatible with the PC/PS3/PS4 platforms and you play along side them..Bad Points to this game:- Again i say "Subscriptions fees" but there not all that bad .. theres no locked content once you've paid and everything is at some point readily available..Fast Travel can cost a fortune so be wary of how you travel !Can seem Tedious at times, but once you discover everything there is to do youll never fit it all into a day :DOverall i Can definetly recommend this game to anyone looking for an MMORPG but feel there all missing something ?? WELL WHAT DO YOU EXPECT FOR FREE HUH ??? pay a little and gain alot more !9.3/10 theres always room for improvement right ?? Come join us today and find out for yourself just how addictive and fun this game really is ..... because you just cant take someones else word for it :D

content:
7, 2014
												This game is beyong anything I could have ever imagined.Gameplay wise, the game is smooth, easy going, and rather slow paced. The start of the game may seem a bit grindy, but the more you progress, the more features you unlock. Every quest you complete seems rewarding.The environment one of the most beautiful I have seen in any MMO, being easily comparable to games like Tera Rising. The graphics are absolutely phenominal and the attention to detail makes the game really immersive.The community as far as what I have experienced contains some of the nicest people I have ever met in an online game. People are inclusive and ready to help new players out.The only issues I have had with this game are a global cooldown of 2.5 seconds, although you  get used to it quite fast, and the lack of voiceacting in cutscenes. Voiceacting could have deserved a little more focus, especially seeing as when you actually get to experience it, it is absolutely great, funny and immersive. That's literally the only issues I have had though, and if you are able to ignore these minor things, you are going to have a one-of-a-kind experience.I will update my experience with this game the more I progress through it.

content:
er 30, 2014
												Pro's: The game is beautiful. Even on medium settings the game looks great and runs smoothly. The story is actually enthralling and is keeping me interested and I don't find myself speeding through text and skipping cinematics. Atleast, not for the main stories lol. The monsters are really well done and there are a wide variety from cute and cuddly (i.e the Cactus monster thing...) to the scary *** demons. The dungeons are fun and it seems that most of them tie in with the main story so you in a sense have to unlock them. Same goes with getting your first chocoboCons: There are some things that really do bug me in this game which may be just superficial on my part. The first is how the map is. When zoomed out to look at a regional view all you see are name blocks with lines directing which zones are connected. It's not like a google map view that you find in most mmo's. Along with that is trying to find where to go with quests. Some mmos if you have quest lets say 3 zones over, will usually point you to the nearest exit from the current zone into the next. This game doesnt seem to do that. If you have a quest in one zone over, sure it will show you. But if it is 2 zones over then you need to go and track it down. The zones themselvs I wish were not instanced. Even parts of the main cities are instanced. I personally like complete open world games. Or at the very least, the main cities should not be broken into instances. Getting a mount is kind of a pain. You need to progress to roughly lvl 20 before you get the quest to get a mount. Then you need to go farm some tokens in order to get a certificate. That part isnt necessarily hard just annoying. Even if you have the collectors edition and have the two mounts already, you need to get the normal chocobo first before you can use them. My biggest gripe however, is the use/lack there of of voice over for the games. Some main story cinematics will have voice overs, some dont. Some times you will have voices then all of a sudden you dont. It's not my sound card, or computer, or whatever, it's the developers that didnt put in voice acting for the whole game. I hope they do add in more sometime down the line. Overall though this is a very well done game and I am impressed. Even with the nuances I am enjoying the game immensly and definitely recommend playing it even if it's just the trial.

content:
ber 14, 2014
												Ok. First of all I am not an MMORPG fan. I Have played 2 before and not for very long. I swore I would NEVER pay for a subscription fee. Now I have paid for one and do not regret it at all. This game is awesome. The amount of stuff you can do in game is impressive as are the graphics and framerate if your PC can handle it.  I have so far played as 2 different classes and to me they feel different. I play them different, which is a good thing. People are generally pretty helpful to noobs and not total d1ckfaces, Although you do get some of those too to be fair.The community seems to be pretty tightly knit and friendly. Within a few minutes on each of 2 servers I have played on, I have been invited to join Free Companys. Or Guilds if you prefer.There does seem to be a fairly steep learning curve with menus and such, and the game doesn't really explain them very well if at all. Stick with it, ask questions and experiment and after a while you will get the hang of it. The map can be daunting at times. I find I'm getting better at it all of the time, but initially it can really mess you up. Especially when there can be different height levels in some areas such as towns. The map does not shift up or down to accomodate your vantage point. When playing with a party, it seems you will share/split experience. That can be pretty cool. Audio is good and has some classic FF music, which is nice.Graphics are incredibly vibrant and colorful, like you'd expect from a FF game.Character interactions are a little tedious. You read alsmot EVERYTHING. Even most cutscenes are not voiced. Although there are a few. Account creation is a  little weird. Especially when you have to use the game client+the website+subscribe and link your account. This could have been a little less confusing. When a friend wants to join you and they just got  the game it is entirely possible that they may not be able to join you. The  world you are on might be full. They can't wait for someone just to logoff. That doesn't seem to work. They have to hope that someone deletes a character at some point I have a lvl 12 character in one world and my friend cannot join me. I had to create a new character on a new world to play with them. One last thing: I believe, (and I might be wrong about this), that you get 8 character slots per world. To give you an idea, there are roughly 8 worlds per server area and about 7 server areas. That is pretty impressive. Would I recommend this game to people? Sure if you are a Final Fantasy fan or an MMO fan. Not for everybody...but I'm loving it so far.

y 23, 2016
												my recommendation is a 51/49 yesthe game is fun up until you get to end-game (at least from when this review is written, we'll see future updates)but they are abusing player's timeif you wanna do end-game things, you better not have a IRL job and no friends to play with, because you're never going to get maxed jobs/classes (jobs as in gathering + crafting) with all fully equippedthere's not enough time to do all that, mainly because of how limited you are, /450 gathering/crafting points a week for example...also for the anima weapon (the very end-game weapon you can get) there are, at the moment, 3 steps to level it... one is doing some fates... that... ok... takes maybe 2-3 hours for each things in that step (like on 5-6 maps)then it's doing dungeons, also easythen you need to farm different things, but if you wanna play more casually, like me and my friend, you need to farm EVERY DAY NON STOP FOR 3 MONTHS!! no joking, it's about 87 days... the tribe quests (not the last, vanu one, which would be even worst) but the 4 other tribesthose tribe quests takes like 30 mins to do a day... IF you're lucky and not get into fate quests because some of them can take 30 mins or even 1h to 1h30 to pop (that one in sylph tribe...)ok i'll be nice and inform about the reason of it being so slow : i sometimes do them at night and there's no one playing, so no one doing the fates and so it takes longer to pop those ones you needso farm it for 3 months is the best casual-wayand in that same step afterwards you need to craft 4 times each 4 different items (each one of a different crafting job) in high quality...so you already need to get your crafting and gathering jobs up to that point... and you can only have 3 job crystals at a time, with that 450 point limit a week it will take forever even with the best items equipped -_-so basically end game = work-at-farm festand this is in "game" categoryworking isn't playing

												It's funny how I read forums from 3 years ago about how people will be surprised if this game becomes big and successful... I've been a gamer since 1995 (5 years old) playing red alert, tiberium, starcraft and diablo so on. I play good games only! The first MMO I played was Rangarok, it was a frigging cocain at that time. Realm Reborn is a ♥♥♥♥in Opium. If you are willing to experience and accept the quality in the game for the first 2 hourse outside of character creation, you will understand why the subscription is actually reasonable.What MMO put Final Fantasy quality cinematic ingame? 


YouTube™ Video: FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn - End of an Era 

			Views: 0		

			Witness the end of an era as the Eorzean Alliance clashes with the Garlean Empire in a bid to deliver the realm from certain destruction. The saga will continue in FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn.		

Answer: none. Pro:-lvling system: Bravely Default-Boss battling system: semi-tales mmo style-Story: Final Fantasy-Cinematic: Final Fantasy-Regular MMO battle: Guild Wars-Living world, stories, quests, end game content and item update almost every patch. -Miqo'teNeutral:-Looting: rolling base (Need - almost garaunteed get it if no one else pick need vs Greed - not a gear for your role want it anyway Vs Pass). Con:- Subscriptions.....so ♥♥♥♥in what? If you don't pay, you just can't play. They don't delete your account btw...unlikes *cough cough* ESO.- Grindfest starting at lvl40+...I just want to go through stories QQ. - The que time in early lvl quests (aka dungeons) usually take forever. Too many people got sucked into end game content. - This is not the actual world we live in.*EDIT1*CON- Just finish realm reborn final mission. HUGE MISTAKE: Too many people required and reward elite players to come back and play with you. Meaning they will force you to skip either all the cutscenes or all the fight. They even have an audacity to tell you to go watch cutscenes in the inn as if they ever do that first time in the dungeon. Few would even try to kick you out.I heard they fix for story content after this, but we'll see what I find out. Major dissapointing ending mission. Great ending content, ♥♥♥♥ system..... What's with these games these days that ♥♥♥♥ing up ending one way or the other?*Side note*Just put down your stupid Destiny, ESO or whatever lame game that got hyped out into the outer space and play this damn good game already.*Edit after Heavensward*- So they actually fix the ending missions issues where elites force you to skip all battles or all cutscenes.1) They reduce the players required to normal of 4 players.2) the cutscenes are off higher quality, more efficient and less time consuming. All the more intense cutscenes are put in your private main quest while.3) Dungeon quest cutscenes are not only shorten, but elites that come for delicious delicious tomestone will have to wait for you otherwise, they will have to fight the boss with less people (which is impossible).I haven't done raid yet...♥♥♥♥, 261hrs and I've only done all main quests up to date.....OH patch 3,2 is coming. LOL.... QQ

content:
5, 2016
												A top contender for one of the best-worst MMO's ever.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -FFXIV had a bit of a rough start when it first launched which prompted Square to create an end-of-the-world Event that ended Version 1.0 ( 1.23 or higher ). This event is always shown as the intro to the game in form of a fantastic CGI video with a rather sad sounding song. However, if you ask me, I dare to say that they planned it from the start as it would give them a great amount of publicity.Here are some of my top complaints of the game.* There is no freedom. It's another Hallway-game.* The storyline is absolutely atrocious, but it does have a few gems.* It feels like work, without pay. You work, and you gain nothing.What I mean when I say there's no freedom, is that just like FFXI it isn't an open world game. You walk from zone to zone. This was fine when it was in FFXI because of it's role as one of the first MMO's. This is NOT okay in an MMO of 2010+. For example, every single town is split up into two separate zones, usually as one top and one lower section. In Limsa Lominsa, this can become utter ridiculous where the lower Limsa crystal can have 20 people standing around, yet because of it's divide you'll never see any people if you are on the upper half because the lower part when watching from upper is a separate instance.This was done I recon in order to make things run smoothly or whatever, but it's just stupid in all honesty.This leads us into the other part. Jumping is a lie. You don't actually jump in the game - You just display a Jump animation. Let me explain: There's no true Z-axis in FFXIV that measures if you are moving vertical. If you can walk it, you can jump it. But if you can't walk it, you can never jump it. Combine this with the fact that everything is divided into zones and we find out the true nightmare of a player of the explorer type - A gilded Cage.Which leads us into the expansion, Heavensward where they introduced flying mounts. They work differently in that they do count the Z-axis, but your jumping still don't. And the most damning fact of it all that everyone I know hate - Aether Currents. A completely, arbitrary thing that Square Enix pulled out of their asses just to spite players. If you want to fly, you better hunt each and everyone down in ONE ZONE in order to fly in just THAT zone. And the hilarious part of this is that usually when you've found all Currents, you're done with that zone so why would you ever go back to it? This makes it so that the only zone worth spending time finding them in is the Churning Mists because at least there, you can fate grind from like 52 to 60Make no mistakes. FFXIV is work. It's not a journey to gain strength, it's just good ol' labor for everything except by the end of the day, you'll have gained nothing of true worth. You're not stronger, you're not more skillful - You're just screwed over.Finally, and here's the golden anaconda of it all.The storyline, is rancid. You really need to try hard to make a story that sucks this much. Just about every single NPC has a special kind of stupidity to them that's out of this world. I have heard D&D players who made joke characters still be better than these numbnuts! And just like how Square usually makes games these days,You are not the Hero.People have joked around about MMO's always telling how everyone is special and they are the chosen ones and all that. FFXIV does this the opposite way. It makes you do all the work, but you are never the hero of this tale. Even after you complete a full storyline and have your fame reach the far wides of Eorzea, you're still going to be everyone's errand boy and if some special NPC shows up, they'll push you aside and go " No! This is something I must do! I who haven't lifted a single finger since you saw me must deal with this enemy!  " or " No -Name-! This enemy is too strunk for us! We must flee! " even though you just eliminated an entire army just to get to that point.It's like Square looked at Mystic Quest and went " Oh man! This is amazing! Let's take ideas from this game! "= = =In conclusion, I cannot recommend FFXIV to anyone.I have spent over 800 hours with the game.I've had some good moments, and I have screamed from the top of my lungs about the story.I have met friends, I got a random guy and his girlfriend to get into the game and they love it, but my hate only grew.If you think you can stand all these things, then I implore you to try the trial out.But otherwise, I cannot recommend this game to anyone with two braincells.PS. I am slightly wrong about Jumping, but in grand gist of it I am right. Jumping in FFXIV is largely a pointless ordeal.
